column7: An Homely, of the creation and fall of man.
column8: an Homely, of the creation and fallen of man.

column7: T He Prophette, Dauid in his forescore and ninteth psalme, exhortyng all people to synge prayse to almighti god, to serue hi in gladnes, and reioyse in his sight, alledgeth thys as a sufficient cause thereof.
column8: THe THe Prophet, David in his forescore and ninteth psalm, exhorting all people to sing praise to almighty god, to serve him in gladness, and rejoice in his sighed, allegeth this as a sufficient cause thereof.

column7: Scitote quoniam ipse est dominus,
column8: Scitote quoniam ipse est dominus,

column7: ipse fecit nos et non ipsi nos. which is to saye.
column8: ipse fecit nos et non ipsi nos. which is to say.

column7: Know you that he is our Lord it is he that made vs, and we made not our selfes.
column8: Know you that he is our Lord it is he that made us, and we made not our selves.

column7: And in dede, who yt diligently wayeth ye creatio of man, can not but therin most highly laude,
column8: And in deed, who that diligently wayeth you Creation of man, can not but therein most highly laud,

column7: & prayse almighty god, his creator.
column8: & praise almighty god, his creator.

column7: For wher in the creation of al other visible thinges, he did but onely commaunde,
column8: For where in the creation of all other visible things, he did but only command,

column7: & will that they should be made, and incontinet they were made, in the creatyng of man, he vsed great solempnitie, and many notable circumstaunces.
column8: & will that they should be made, and incontinet they were made, in the creating of man, he used great solemnity, and many notable Circumstances.

column7: Fyrst touchyng ma, he said, let vs make ma, which words be as it were the wordes of god the father, to God the sonne,
column8: Fyrst touching ma, he said, let us make ma, which words be as it were the words of god the father, to God the son,

column7: & to the holy ghost, spoken after the maner of men, when they go about some great matter, at what time they take good aduisement or they begyn, and doo ioyne with the best,
column8: & to the holy ghost, spoken After the manner of men, when they go about Some great matter, At what time they take good advisement or they begin, and do join with the best,

column8: & Wisest counsellors, that they can get.

column7: Thys circumstaunce (not beyng necessary of goddes parte, as withoute the which he might haue created man) doth most manifestly declare the special fauour, of almyghty god towardes mankynde:
column8: This circumstance (not being necessary of God's part, as without the which he might have created man) does most manifestly declare the special favour, of almighty god towards mankind:

column7: but that nexte circumstaunce, which doth immediatly folowe thys fyrst, is a more surer profe, and declaration of gods tender loue, towardes ma, whe he sayth.
column8: but that Next circumstance, which does immediately follow this fyrst, is a more Surer proof, and declaration of God's tender love, towards ma, when he say.

column7: Let vs make man to our owne similitude & likenes,
column8: Let us make man to our own similitude & likeness,

column7: Now mark, good people, howe much god dyd for vs in our creation.
column8: Now mark, good people, how much god did for us in our creation.

column7: He made vs in very dede like vnto himselfe,
column8: He made us in very deed like unto himself,

column7: & in so doynge what could he haue done more for vs?
column8: & in so doing what could he have done more for us?

column7: A wonderfull excellet benefite & comfort is it vnto vs, to consyder that man was made like vnto god.
column8: A wonderful excellet benefit & Comfort is it unto us, to Consider that man was made like unto god.

column7: And to vnderstand this thyng the better, you shall know that the similitude, and likenes of man to god, was not in the body of man (for this you must moost certenly beleue, yt the godhed is a spirite,
column8: And to understand this thing the better, you shall know that the similitude, and likeness of man to god, was not in the body of man (for this you must most Certainly believe, that the godhead is a Spirit,

column7: & not a bodely substaunce) but this similitude and likenes was in ye soule, which was endued, with most heuenly & godlike qualities, as vnderstandyng, memory, and wil, with sondry gyftes also of grace.
column8: & not a bodily substance) but this similitude and likeness was in the soul, which was endued, with most heavenly & godlike qualities, as understanding, memory, and will, with sundry Gifts also of grace.

column7: And here is to be noted by the way, that where almighty god sayeth,
column8: And Here is to be noted by the Way, that where almighty god Saith,

column7: Let vs make man to our owne similitude,
column8: Let us make man to our own similitude,

column7: & lykenes, he geueth vs to vnderstad, yt there be three parsons in trinitie,
column8: & likeness, he Giveth us to Understand, that there be three parsons in trinity,

column7: & yet but one god.
column8: & yet but one god.

column7: For in that he sayeth let vs make man, therein is signified, a pluralitie, or number of persones:
column8: For in that he Saith let us make man, therein is signified, a plurality, or number of Persons:

column7: agayne, in that he sayeth to our similitude and likenes, and not to oure similitudes and lykenesses, by thys is signyfyed the vnitie also of one nature and substaunce.
column8: again, in that he Saith to our similitude and likeness, and not to our Similitudes and lykenesses, by this is signyfyed the unity also of one nature and substance.

column7: But to procede further concernyng the creation of man, ye shall vnderstand,
column8: But to proceed further Concerning the creation of man, you shall understand,

column7: <NOTE> that the second chapter of Moyses boke, called genesis, in speciall maner doth recorde the seuerall making, as well of the bodye of man, by it selfe, as also of the soule by it selfe.
column8: that the second chapter of Moses book, called genesis, in special manner does record the several making, as well of the body of man, by it self, as also of the soul by it self.

column7: And as touching the body, scrypture doth there say, that.
column8: And as touching the body, scripture does there say, that.

column7: God fourmed, or shaped it, of ye earthe Noting therby the excellecy of mans body, aboue the bodyes of other liuynge creatures.
column8: God Form, or shaped it, of the earth Noting thereby the excellency of men body, above the bodies of other living creatures.

column7: For we rede not of anye other lyuyng creature, that god shaped, or fourmed, the body of it, but onely that he made it, and that at the comaundement of almighty god,
column8: For we rede not of any other living creature, that god shaped, or Form, the body of it, but only that he made it, and that At the Commandment of almighty god,

column7: the earth brought fourth foure foted beastes,
column8: the earth brought fourth foure footed beasts,

column7: & the water, in like maner, brought fourth fysshes,
column8: & the water, in like manner, brought fourth fishes,

column7: & foules. Only of ye body of ma scripture witnesseth yt God shaped it.
column8: & fowls. Only of you body of ma scripture Witnesseth that God shaped it.

column7: And as cocerning ye soule of ma, it is written of it, in the sayd second chapter of genesis,
column8: And as Concerning the soul of ma, it is written of it, in the said second chapter of genesis,

column7: <NOTE> howe yt god brethed it into the body, which.ii. circumstaunces, as they import a marueylous excellency of man, aboue other bodely creatures, so they most clerely declare thexcedyng great goodnes of God, towardes man.
column8: how that god breathed it into the body, which ii Circumstances, as they import a marvelous excellency of man, above other bodily creatures, so they most clearly declare thexcedyng great Goodness of God, towards man.

column7: Now when god had, in such a singuler fashion, creted man, he gaue hym souereigntie ouer all the fysshes of the sea, ouer the foules of the ayer, and ouer the beastes of the lande, yea and made him a Kyng, and Emperour on the earth.
column8: Now when god had, in such a singular fashion, Created man, he gave him sovereignty over all the fishes of the sea, over the fowls of the air, and over the beasts of the land, yea and made him a King, and Emperor on the earth.

column7: And yet not satisfyed with al this, he placed man in Paradyse, that is in a most pleasaunt garden, where he had planted all kynd of frute, beautifull to beholde, and delicious to eate, for man to fede vpon, onely one kynde of fruyte he charged hym on payne of death, (and that not of the body alone, but of the soule also) vtterlye to refrayne from, which was the fruyte of the tree called in scrypture, the tre of knowledge of good, and euyl.
column8: And yet not satisfied with all this, he placed man in Paradise, that is in a most pleasant garden, where he had planted all kind of fruit, beautiful to behold, and delicious to eat, for man to fede upon, only one kind of fruit he charged him on pain of death, (and that not of the body alone, but of the soul also) utterly to refrain from, which was the fruit of the tree called in scripture, the Tree of knowledge of good, and evil.

column7: And lyke as in a most maruelous sorte he made Adam the fyrste man, so in as marueylous,
column8: And like as in a most marvelous sort he made Adam the First man, so in as marvelous,

column7: & straunge a sort he made Eue the first woman, euen of a rybbe taken out of Adams lefte syde, and her he made parfytte, and furnyshed her with like gyftes as he had done Adame the first man:
column8: & strange a sort he made Eue the First woman, even of a Rib taken out of Adams left side, and her he made parfytte, and furnished her with like Gifts as he had done Adam the First man:

column7: What canne we then thinke, or deuyse, that God might haue don more for vs in our creation, then herein he dyd:
column8: What can we then think, or devise, that God might have dONE more for us in our creation, then herein he did:

column7: He made the soule immortall, that is such as shulde continue for euer without ende.
column8: He made the soul immortal, that is such as should continue for ever without end.

column7: He furnished it with moste singuler gyftes both of nature and of special grace also The body of man, in the estate of originall innocencie, had in it helth, strength, cumlines, and other like qualities, in the highest degre of perfection, it had in it selfe then, no fond lust, or concupiscens, no pronitie or inclination to euyl, no lothsumnes in doing good, no infirmitie or wekenesse, no lacke or want of any qualitie fyt and decent for it.
column8: He furnished it with most singular Gifts both of nature and of special grace also The body of man, in the estate of original innocence, had in it health, strength, comeliness, and other like qualities, in the highest degree of perfection, it had in it self then, no found lust, or concupiscens, no pronity or inclination to evil, no lothsumnes in doing good, no infirmity or wekenesse, no lack or want of any quality fit and decent for it.

column7: The body of man was then obediente to the soule, the soule altogether obedient to God.
column8: The body of man was then obedient to the soul, the soul altogether obedient to God.

column7: So that on Gods parte, oure maker and creator, there is nothyng towardes vs but all perfection, all great kyndnes, al fatherly loue,
column8: So that on God's part, our maker and creator, there is nothing towards us but all perfection, all great kindness, all fatherly love,

column7: & fauour, Holy scrypture most euydently affyrmeth yt al creatures were made good in their creation, saying.
column8: & favour, Holy scripture most evidently Affirmeth that all creatures were made good in their creation, saying.

column7: Vidit deus omnia que fecerat et erant ualde bona.
column8: Vidit deus omnia que fecerat et Erant Valde Bona.

column7: Gene. i. That is. God sawe al things which he had made, and they were very good.
column8: Gene. i. That is. God saw all things which he had made, and they were very good.

column7: Which thyng as it is generally true in all creatures concerning their creation, so is it in a certen degre of excellencye to be verified in man touchyng the estate of his originall innocency.
column8: Which thing as it is generally true in all creatures Concerning their creation, so is it in a certain degree of excellency to be verified in man touching the estate of his original innocency.

column7: Thus we may perceaue yt in the creation of man, al was excellent & parfytte, whiche oughte greatly to inflame vs the more to loue and serue almighty God our most louynge creator.
column8: Thus we may perceive that in the creation of man, all was excellent & parfytte, which ought greatly to inflame us the more to love and serve almighty God our most loving creator.

column7: But for asmuche as that blessed estate is lost,
column8: But for asmuch as that blessed estate is lost,

column7: & mankynd by ye losse thereof, fell into extreme miserie and wretchednes, it is consequently to be well considered of our part, by what meanes man was brought from soo good and blessed a case, to so euyll and miserable an estate, whiche poynte well wayed, is a sufficiente grounde to cause vs on the other syde vtterly to detest & abhorre al synne.
column8: & mankind by you loss thereof, fell into extreme misery and wretchedness, it is consequently to be well considered of our part, by what means man was brought from so good and blessed a case, to so evil and miserable an estate, which point well weighed, is a sufficient ground to cause us on the other side utterly to detest & abhor all sin.

column7: For that greuous fal of man came of synne.
column8: For that grievous fall of man Come of sin.

column7: Synne it was, for which God thrust man oute of paradyse, synne it was that caused the fleshe to striue agaynste the spirite, and the spirite, agaynst the fleshe, synne it was that broughte vnto mankynde necessitie of bodyly death, and all the infirmities and diseases, which man in thys transitory lyfe sustayneth, synne fynally it was, that caused all the posteritie of Adam and Eue to be borne in state of dampnation.
column8: Sin it was, for which God thrust man out of paradise, sin it was that caused the Flesh to strive against the Spirit, and the Spirit, against the Flesh, sin it was that brought unto mankind necessity of bodily death, and all the infirmities and diseases, which man in this transitory life sustaineth, sin finally it was, that caused all the posterity of Adam and Eue to be born in state of damnation.

column7: But some perchaunce are desyrous fardar to knowe, by what meanes man was fyrst brought to commytte synne.
column8: But Some perchance Are desirous fardar to know, by what means man was fyrst brought to commit sin.

column7: For the vnderstandyng whereof, <NOTE> lette vs haue recourse to the iii. chap. of Genesis, where it is wrytten:
column8: For the understanding whereof, let us have recourse to the iii. chap. of Genesis, where it is written:

column7: how that ye wyly serpent the deuyll came vnto Eue and sayde vnto her:
column8: how that you wily serpent the Devil Come unto Eue and said unto her:

column7: Why hath God gyuen you commaundement not to eate of euery tree in paradyse?
column8: Why hath God given you Commandment not to eat of every tree in paradise?

column7: where vnto the woman answered and sayde:
column8: where unto the woman answered and said:

column7: of the fruyte which is in paradise we eate, but of the frute of that tree yt groweth in the myddest of paradyse,
column8: of the fruit which is in paradise we eat, but of the fruit of that tree that grows in the midst of paradise,

column7: GOD hath charged vs not to eate or touche it?
column8: GOD hath charged us not to eat or touch it?

column7: leste, perchaunce we dye.
column8: lest, perchance we die.

column7: Then sayde the serpente to the woman:
column8: Then said the serpent to the woman:

column7: Naye, you shall not dye.
column8: Nay, you shall not die.

column7: For God knoweth that whatsoeuer daye you shall eate thereof, youre eyes shalbe opened, and you shalbe like Gods, knowynge good and euyll.
column8: For God Knoweth that whatsoever day you shall eat thereof, your eyes shall opened, and you shall like God's, knowing good and evil.

column7: The woman therefore saw that the tree was good to eate of, and beautifull to the eye, and pleasaunte to beholde, and she tooke of the fruyte thereof and dyd eate, and gaue part to her husbad, who also dyd eate.
column8: The woman Therefore saw that the tree was good to eat of, and beautiful to the eye, and pleasant to behold, and she took of the fruit thereof and did eat, and gave part to her Husband, who also did eat.

column7: Thus through the prouocation of the deuyll, man first fell into synne.
column8: Thus through the provocation of the Devil, man First fell into sin.

column7: Wherefore as we must alwayes abhorre synne and forbeare it, bycause of the greate misery it brought vs vnto, so should we no les hate, and to the vttermost of our power, fly the deuyl and all his suggestions, knowing that thereby we were fyrst induced to commytte synne.
column8: Wherefore as we must always abhor sin and forbear it, Because of the great misery it brought us unto, so should we not les hate, and to the uttermost of our power, fly the Devil and all his suggestions, knowing that thereby we were fyrst induced to commit sin.

column7: For as thys oure aduersary was busye at the begynnynge with oure fyrst parentes, so is he no les,
column8: For as this our adversary was busy At the beginning with our fyrst Parents, so is he no less,

column7: <NOTE> but rather more busye with vs at thys present, as wytnesseth Saynt Peter in the.v. chapiter of his first epystle, saying.
column8: but rather more busy with us At this present, as Witnesseth Saint Peter in the v chapter of his First epistle, saying.

column7: Youre aduersary the deuyl, as a roryng lion goeth about, seking whom he may deuour.
column8: Your adversary the Devil, as a roaring Lion Goes about, seeking whom he may devour.

column7: Thys aduersary of mankynde, disdaynynge at the greate felycytye that Adam and Eue were in, neuer ceasyd questionynge, and craftyng with the woman, being the weker and trayler vessell, vntyll he had made them disobey gods commaundement:
column8: This adversary of mankind, disdaining At the great felycytye that Adam and Eue were in, never ceased questioning, and craftyng with the woman, being the weker and trailer vessel, until he had made them disobey God's Commandment:

column7: by which their doyng, they lost the orygynall great innocency which they had at there creation, which being lost, nether the body woulde be obedient to ye soule, nor the soule to god, but al was in man turned vpsidoune:
column8: by which their doing, they lost the original great innocency which they had At there creation, which being lost, neither the body would be obedient to you soul, nor the soul to god, but all was in man turned vpsidoune:

column7: yea therby they fel also into necessitie of temporall death of body, and (which is worst of all) into the estate of eternall damnation, and euerlasting death, both of body and soule.
column8: yea thereby they fell also into necessity of temporal death of body, and (which is worst of all) into the estate of Eternal damnation, and everlasting death, both of body and soul.

column7: But now, because it maye paraduenture seme in some mans iudgement, that seyng the thing that Adam and Eue did;
column8: But now, Because it may Peradventure seem in Some men judgement, that sing the thing that Adam and Eue did;

column7: was but the eatynge of an appell, therefore their faut was not great, nor deserued so greuous punishment, let vs consider the circumstaunces, and we shall sone perceyue the offence not lyght, but verye sore and heynous.
column8: was but the eating of an Appeal, Therefore their fault was not great, nor deserved so grievous punishment, let us Consider the Circumstances, and we shall soon perceive the offence not Light, but very soar and heinous.

column7: Fyrst the thyng which god commaunded man to forbeare, was a thyng most easye for hym to forbeare, and so much was his faute the greater.
column8: Fyrst the thing which god commanded man to forbear, was a thing most easy for him to forbear, and so much was his fault the greater.

column7: Besides this, whan a man is tolde before of great peryll and daunger that shall lyght vpon him if he doo this or that, in case after such warnyng he offende therein, his fault is thereby made the greuouser.
column8: Beside this, when a man is told before of great peril and danger that shall Light upon him if he do this or that, in case After such warning he offend therein, his fault is thereby made the greuouser.

column7: Thyrdly, the lesse inclination a man hath to any synne, the more he synneth yf he doo the same.
column8: Thirdly, the less inclination a man hath to any sin, the more he Sinneth if he do the same.

column7: Nowe Adam and Eue, had in them no inclination at al, nother to one vice nor to other.
column8: Now Adam and Eue, had in them no inclination At all, neither to one vice nor to other.

column7: Fourthly, when a man hath late receyued great benefites at hys soueraygns handes, if he incontinently breake his expresse wyll, the contempt and disobedience is made therby the greater.
column8: Fourthly, when a man hath late received great benefits At his sovereigns hands, if he incontinently break his express will, the contempt and disobedience is made thereby the greater.

column7: The thyng that Adam and Eue dyd eate, was in dede but an appell, yet the eatyng thereof in that case, was an high disobediece against god, and the corrupting of all mankynd, for as much as they two were the very route, whereof all men must ryse, and the route being once naughte, howe can the tree or braunches, cummynge of that route, be good?
column8: The thing that Adam and Eue did eat, was in deed but an Appeal, yet the eating thereof in that case, was an high disobedience against god, and the corrupting of all mankind, for as much as they two were the very rout, whereof all men must rise, and the rout being once naught, how can the tree or branches, coming of that rout, be good?

column7: Therfore S. Paule in his Epistle to ye Romaines in the.v. chapiter thereof saieth.
column8: Therefore S. Paul in his Epistle to the Romans in the v chapter thereof Saith.

column7: By the offence of one man, synne came vpon all men, to condempnacion, and in the same chapiter immediatly after, he sayeth to lyke purpose, throughe the disobedience of one man, manye became synners.
column8: By the offence of one man, sin Come upon all men, to condemnation, and in the same chapter immediately After, he Saith to like purpose, through the disobedience of one man, many became Sinners.

column7: And within a lytle after he saieth.
column8: And within a little After he Saith.

column7: Sinne came into this world by one man,
column8: Sin Come into this world by one man,

column7: & through synne came death,
column8: & through sin Come death,

column7: & so death passed to al me.
column8: & so death passed to all me.

column7: Thus haue you hard fyrste the louynge kyndnes of God to man, in that he created hym in so worthye a maner, nexte ye haue harde the myschyfe that commeth to mankynd by synne, and thirdly what an extreme enemy also the deuyll is vnto vs.
column8: Thus have you heard First the loving kindness of God to man, in that he created him in so worthy a manner, Next you have harden the myschyfe that comes to mankind by sin, and Thirdly what an extreme enemy also the Devil is unto us

column7: In an other homily hereafter, ye shal heare of the exceding great mercy of god, in deliuering makind by a meruelous maner, out of the estate of this dampnatio.
column8: In an other homily hereafter, you shall hear of the exceeding great mercy of god, in delivering makind by a marvelous manner, out of the estate of this dampnatio.

column7: Wherfore to conclude for thys presente tyme, this shalbe to exhort you, that you fayle not daylye and howrelye to geue most harty thankes to almyghty God, for that he of his mere goodnes created you,
column8: Wherefore to conclude for this present time, this shall to exhort you, that you fail not daily and howrelye to give most hearty thanks to almighty God, for that he of his mere Goodness created you,

column7: & created you, not without sense, as the stones, not without reason as the brute beastes, but hathe gyuen you all notable qualities and powers that other corporall creatures haue, and besydes, hathe perticularlye planted in you reason and vnderstading, and sondry goodly qualities of body and soule, seuerall to the nature of man only, and not commo to man, and other erthly creatures.
column8: & created you, not without sense, as the stones, not without reason as the brutus beasts, but hath given you all notable qualities and Powers that other corporal creatures have, and besides, hath particularly planted in you reason and understanding, and sundry goodly qualities of body and soul, several to the nature of man only, and not Common to man, and other earthly creatures.

column7: This is furthermore also to exhorte you, that remembryng what miserye came to mankynde by synne, and by such a synne, as in some mes iudgement might seme to be but very smale, it is to wytte, by eatynge of an appel, you wyl be circumspecte in auoiding of al kinde of synne, and disobedience, be the thinge in hys owne nature neuer so smale a thynge, whyche is by God hym selfe, or by suche as we owe obedience vnto, commaunded.
column8: This is furthermore also to exhort you, that remembering what misery Come to mankind by sin, and by such a sin, as in Some mes judgement might seem to be but very small, it is to wit, by eating of an appeal, you will be circumspect in avoiding of all kind of sin, and disobedience, be the thing in his own nature never so small a thing, which is by God him self, or by such as we owe Obedience unto, commanded.

column7: Fynallye and laste of al, this is to exhorte you, to consyder dilygently that we haue a deadly ennemy, which is ye deuil, who desyreth oure destruction, and doth moost craftely and busely trauayle by all meanes wyth vs, to worke the same, of whose mooste subtyll and wilye traynes, we muste principally take hede of, whiche graunt vnto vs all, the blessed trinitie, the father, the Sonne, and the holye ghoste, to whome be all honoure and glorye worlde withoute ende.
column8: Finally and laste of all, this is to exhort you, to Consider diligently that we have a deadly enemy, which is the Devil, who desireth our destruction, and does most craftily and busily travail by all means with us, to work the same, of whose most subtle and wily trains, we must principally take heed of, which grant unto us all, the blessed trinity, the father, the Son, and the holy ghost, to whom be all honour and glory world without end.

column7: Amen. Io. Harpesfeld sacrae theologiae professor Arch.
column8: Amen. Io. Harpesfeld Sacrae Theologiae professor Arch.

column7: London.
column8: London.

column7: An homely of the misery of all mankinde, and of hys condempnation to euerlastynge deathe, by hys owne synne.
column8: an homely of the misery of all mankind, and of his condemnation to everlasting death, by his own sin.

column7: T He holye ghoste, in wryting the holy scripture, is in nothyng more diliget, then to pull downe mannes vayne glory, and pryde, which of all vices, is moost vniuersallye graffed in mankynde, euen from the fyrste infection of our fyrste father Adam.
column8: THe THe holy ghost, in writing the holy scripture, is in nothing more diliget, then to pull down Man's vain glory, and pride, which of all vices, is most universally graffed in mankind, even from the First infection of our First father Adam.

column7: And therefore, we reade in many places of scripture, many notable lessons agaynst this olde rooted vyce, to teache vs ye moost comedable vertue of humilitie, howe to know our selues,

column8: Howe oft, how earnestly, and how lamentably doth he desire God's great mercy, for his great offences, and that God should not enter in to judgement with him?

column8: He Teaches us in our Prayers, to reacknowledge our selves Sinners, and to ask forgiveness, and deliverance from all evils, At our heavenly Father's hand.

column7: He declareth that the synnes of oure owne hartes, doo defyle oure owne selues.
column8: He Declareth that the Sins of our own hearts, do defile our own selves.

column8: He Teaches that an evil word, or Thought, deserves condemnation, affirming, that we shall give an accompt, for every idle word:

column7: He sayth, he came not to saue, but the shepe that were vtterlye lost, and cast awaye.
column8: He say, he Come not to save, but the sheep that were utterly lost, and cast away.

column8: Wherefore good people, let us beware of such Hypocrisy, vainglory, and justicing of our selves.

column8: And let us earnestly Repent, and humble our selves heartily, to cry to God for mercy.

column8: Let us know our own works, of what imperfection they be, and then we shall not stand folyshely, and arrogantly, in our own conceits.

column7: For truely, there is imperfections, in our beste woorkes:
column8: For truly, there is imperfections, in our best works:

column7: we doo not feare God so muche as we ought to doo:
column8: we do not Fear God so much as we ought to do:

column7: we doo not praye to God, but with great and many imperfections.
column8: we do not pray to God, but with great and many imperfections.

column8: Oh Lord, righteousness belongeth to thee, unto us belongeth confusion.

column7: We haue synned, we haue bene naughtie, we haue offended, we haue fled from the, wee haue gone backe from all thy preceptes, and iudgementes.
column8: We have sinned, we have be naughty, we have offended, we have fled from thee, we have gone back from all thy Precepts, and Judgments.

column7: So we learne of all good men, in holy scripture, to humble oure selues, and to exalte, extoll, prayse, magnifye, and glorifye God.
column8: So we Learn of all good men, in holy scripture, to humble our selves, and to exalt, extol, praise, magnify, and Glorify God.

column7: Thus ye haue hearde, howe euil we be of our selues, how of our selues,
column8: Thus you have heard, how evil we be of our selves, how of our selves,

column7: & by our selues, we haue no goodnes, helpe, nor saluation:
column8: & by our selves, we have no Goodness, help, nor salvation:

column7: but contrarywyse, synne, dampnation, and deathe euerlastynge:
column8: but contrariwise, sin, damnation, and death everlasting:

column7: whyche, yf wee depely weyghe, and consyder, we shall the better vnderstande, the great mercy of God, and howe our saluacion commeth onely by Christe:
column8: which, if we deeply weyghe, and Consider, we shall the better understand, the great mercy of God, and how our salvation comes only by Christ:

column7: for in oure selues, as of our selues, we fynde nothynge, whereby we may be delyuered from this miserable captiuitye, into the whyche we were caste throughe the enuye of the deuyll, by transgression of Gods commaundement, in our fyrste parent Adam.
column8: for in our selves, as of our selves, we find nothing, whereby we may be Delivered from this miserable captivity, into the which we were cast through the envy of the Devil, by Transgression of God's Commandment, in our First parent Adam.

column7: We are al become vncleane:
column8: We Are all become unclean:

column7: but we al of our selues, are not hable to clese our selues, nor to make one an other of vs cleane.
column8: but we all of our selves, Are not able to clese our selves, nor to make one an other of us clean.

column7: We are by nature, the chyldren of Gods wrathe:
column8: We Are by nature, the children of God's wrath:

column7: we are not hable of oure selues, to make vs the children and inheritours of Gods glorye.
column8: we Are not able of our selves, to make us the children and inheritors of God's glory.

column7: We are shepe that runne astray:
column8: We Are sheep that run astray:

column7: we canot without goddes grace,
column8: we canot without God's grace,

column7: <NOTE> and helpe, come agayne to the shepe folde:
column8: and help, come again to the sheep fold:

column7: so great is our imperfection and weakenes.
column8: so great is our imperfection and weakness.

column7: In our selues therefore, maye not we glorye, which of oure selues are nothynge but synnefull, neyther maye we bragge of our woorkes that we doo, whyche all be so vnperfecte and vnpure, that they are not of them selues, hable to stande before the ryghteous throne of GOD, as the holye Prophete Dauid sayeth:
column8: In our selves Therefore, may not we glory, which of our selves Are nothing but sinful, neither may we brag of our works that we do, which all be so unperfect and unpure, that they Are not of them selves, able to stand before the righteous throne of GOD, as the holy Prophet David Saith:

column7: Enter not into iudgemente wyth thy seruaunte,
column8: Enter not into judgement with thy servant,

column7: O Lorde, for no man that lyueth, shalbe founde ryghtuous in thy syghte.
column8: Oh Lord, for no man that liveth, shall found righteous in thy sight.

column7: To God therefore, muste wee flye, or els shall we neuer fynde peace, rest, and quyetnes of conscience, in oure hartes.
column8: To God Therefore, must we fly, or Else shall we never find peace, rest, and quietness of conscience, in our hearts.

column7: For he is the father of mercyes, and God of all consolation, he is the Lord, wyth whome is plenteouse redemption.
column8: For he is the father of Mercies, and God of all consolation, he is the Lord, with whom is plenteous redemption.

column7: <NOTE> He is the God, whyche of his owne mercy saueth vs, and setteth out hys charitie, and exceadyng loue toward vs, in that of his owne voluntary goodnes, when we were peryshed, he saued vs, and prouyded an euerlastynge kyngedome for vs.
column8: He is the God, which of his own mercy Saveth us, and sets out his charity, and exceeding love towards us, in that of his own voluntary Goodness, when we were perished, he saved us, and provided an everlasting Kingdom for us

column7: And all these heauenly treasures are giue vs, of hys mere mercy, freelye.
column8: And all these heavenly treasures Are give us, of his mere mercy, freely.

column7: And for whose sake? Trulye,
column8: And for whose sake? Truly,

column7: for Iesus Christes sake, that pure, and vndefiled Lambe of God.
column8: for jesus Christ's sake, that pure, and undefiled Lamb of God.

column7: He is that dearely beloued sonne, for whose sake,
column8: He is that dearly Beloved son, for whose sake,

column7: God is fullye pacifyed, satysfyed, and set at one with man.
column8: God is Fully pacified, satisfied, and Set At one with man.

column7: He is the Lambe of God,
column8: He is the Lamb of God,

column7: <NOTE> whyche taketh away the synnes of the worlde, of whome it maye be truely spoken, that he dyd all thynges well, and in his mouthe was founde no crafte, nor subteltye.
column8: which Takes away the Sins of the world, of whom it may be truly spoken, that he did all things well, and in his Mouth was found no craft, nor subtlety.

column7: Lykewyse he maye saye: the prynce of the world came, and in me he hath nothyng.
column8: Likewise he may say: the Prince of the world Come, and in me he hath nothing.

column7: He maye say also: whiche of you shall reproue me of anye faulte:
column8: He may say also: which of you shall reprove me of any fault:

column7: He is that hyghe and euerlastynge priest, whyche hathe offred him selfe to God, when he instituted the sacrament of the Aultar, and once for all, in a bloudye sacrifyce, doone vpon the crosse, with which oblation, he hath made perfecte for euermore, theim that are sanctifyed.
column8: He is that high and everlasting priest, which hath offered him self to God, when he instituted the sacrament of the Altar, and once for all, in a bloody sacrifice, done upon the cross, with which oblation, he hath made perfect for evermore, them that Are sanctified.

column7: He is the mediatoure, <NOTE> betwene God and man, which payed our raunsome to God, wyth hys owne bloude, and wyth that, hathe clensed vs from synne.
column8: He is the Mediator, between God and man, which paid our ransom to God, with his own blood, and with that, hath cleansed us from sin.

column7: He is the Phisition, whiche healeth all our diseases.
column8: He is the physician, which heals all our diseases.

column7: He is that sauioure, <NOTE> whiche saueth the people from al theyr sinnes.
column8: He is that Saviour, which Saveth the people from all their Sins.

column7: To be short, he is that flowing, and moost plenteous fountayne, of whose fulnes, all we haue receyued.
column8: To be short, he is that flowing, and most plenteous fountain, of whose fullness, all we have received.

column7: For in him are all the treasures of the wysedome, and knowledge of God hydden.
column8: For in him Are all the treasures of the Wisdom, and knowledge of God hidden.

column7: And in hym, and by him, haue we from God the father, al good thinges, perteyning eyther to the bodye, or to the soule.
column8: And in him, and by him, have we from God the father, all good things, pertaining either to the body, or to the soul.

column7: O how muche then, are we bounde to this oure heauenlye father, for these, his greate mercyes, whiche he hathe so plenteously declared vnto vs, in Christe Iesu oure Lorde, and sauioure:
column8: O how much then, Are we bound to this our heavenly father, for these, his great Mercies, which he hath so plenteously declared unto us, in Christ Jesu our Lord, and Saviour:

column7: What thankes, worthy, and sufficiente, can we giue to him?
column8: What thanks, worthy, and sufficient, can we give to him?

column7: Let vs all with one accorde, burste oute wyth ioyful voices, euer praysynge, and magnifyenge this Lorde of mercy, for hys tender kyndenes shewed to vs, in hys dearely beloued sonne Iesus Christ oure Lorde.
column8: Let us all with one accord, burst out with joyful voices, ever praising, and magnifyenge this Lord of mercy, for his tender kindness showed to us, in his dearly Beloved son jesus christ our Lord.

column7: Let vs nowe learne to know our selues, our frayltie, and weakenes, withoute anye ostentation, or boastynge of oure owne good deedes, and merites.
column8: Let us now Learn to know our selves, our frailty, and weakness, without any ostentation, or boasting of our own good Deeds, and merits.

column7: Let vs also knowledge the exceadynge mercye of God, towarde vs, and confesse, that as of our selues commeth all euyll, and dampnation, so lykewyse of hym, commeth all goodnes and saluation, as God him selfe saieth by the Prophet Oze:
column8: Let us also knowledge the exceeding mercy of God, toward us, and confess, that as of our selves comes all evil, and damnation, so likewise of him, comes all Goodness and salvation, as God him self Saith by the Prophet Oze:

column7: O Israel, thy destruction commeth of thy selfe, but in me onely is thy helpe and comforte.
column8: Oh Israel, thy destruction comes of thy self, but in me only is thy help and Comfort.

column7: If wee thus humbly submyt our selues in the syghte of God, we maye be sure, that in the tyme of hys visitacio, he wil lyfte vs vp, vnto the kyngedome of hys dearely beloued sonne,
column8: If we thus humbly submit our selves in the sight of God, we may be sure, that in the time of his visitacio, he will lift us up, unto the Kingdom of his dearly Beloved son,

column7: Christe Iesu our Lorde: to whome with the father, and the holy gooste, be all honoure and glorye, for euer.
column8: Christ Jesu our Lord: to whom with the father, and the holy ghost, be all honour and glory, for ever.

column7: Amen. Io. Harpesfeld sacrae theologiae professor.
column8: Amen. Io. Harpesfeld Sacrae Theologiae professor.

column7: Arch. London.
column8: Arch. London.

column7: An Homelye of the redemption of man.
column8: an Homely of the redemption of man.

column7: IT was declared vnto you, good christen people, in ye last homelye, howe oure fyrste parentes Ada and Eue, were by the synguler goodnes, and especiall fauoure of almyghtye God, created ryghte worthye creatures, and in the estate of parfytte innocencye.
column8: IT was declared unto you, good christian people, in the last homely, how our First Parents Ada and Eue, were by the singular Goodness, and especial favour of almighty God, created right worthy creatures, and in the estate of parfytte innocency.

column7: It was also shewed howe thorough disobedience to theyr creator, they broughte them selues, and all mankind, into the estate of euerlastynge damnation.
column8: It was also showed how thorough disobedience to their creator, they brought them selves, and all mankind, into the estate of everlasting damnation.

column7: Nowe shall you consequentlye heare, of the delyueraunce of man, out of that dampnable estate, that is, of oure redemption.
column8: Now shall you consequently hear, of the deliverance of man, out of that damnable estate, that is, of our redemption.

column7: For the vnderstandynge whereof, you must perfytlye beare in mynde, that the whole nature of man, both in bodye and soule, was thorough orygynall synne, greatelye defiled.
column8: For the understanding whereof, you must perfectly bear in mind, that the Whole nature of man, both in body and soul, was through original sin, greatly defiled.

column7: For the soule (which is the cheif part of man) loste thereby the especiall gyftes of grace, with whiche it was indued in the creation, and besydes that, it was also maymed in the gyftes of nature, as in memorye, intelligence, wyll, and other lyke.
column8: For the soul (which is the chief part of man) lost thereby the especial Gifts of grace, with which it was endued in the creation, and besides that, it was also maimed in the Gifts of nature, as in memory, intelligence, will, and other like.

column7: And the body (whiche is the inferior parte) it also was by the meanes of orygynall synne, brought to the necessarye estate of mortalitie, so that it muste nedes die,
column8: And the body (which is the inferior part) it also was by the means of original sin, brought to the necessary estate of mortality, so that it must needs die,

column7: and was throughe that synne of our sayde fyrste parentes, made weke, and brought to be subiecte, to sodrye kyndes of infirmities, and syckenes:
column8: and was through that sin of our said First Parents, made Week, and brought to be Subject, to sodrye Kinds of infirmities, and sickness:

column7: and nother coulde God, of his iustice, receaue man agayne to fauor, and state of eternall lyfe (beynge thus in bodye and soule, by his owne defaulte defyled) vnles he were fyrst made pure, and cleane, againe nether man was able to helpe him selfe herein, no, nor yet anye angell at al.
column8: and neither could God, of his Justice, receive man again to favour, and state of Eternal life (being thus in body and soul, by his own default defiled) unless he were fyrst made pure, and clean, again neither man was able to help him self herein, no, nor yet any angel At all

column7: Wherefore, almyghty God (whose mercy excedeth all his workes) pytienge the wretched case that mankynde was in, dyd appoynt, euen from the begynnynge, his onely sonne, the seconde person in trinitie, to be the sauiour of the worlde, and to restore man againe, to perfit clennes, both in body, and soule, and that, by the way of very iustice, in making a full amendes, and payinge a sufficiente raunsome for synne.
column8: Wherefore, almighty God (whose mercy exceedeth all his works) pytienge the wretched case that mankind was in, did appoint, even from the beginning, his only son, the seconde person in trinity, to be the Saviour of the world, and to restore man again, to perfect cleanness, both in body, and soul, and that, by the Way of very Justice, in making a full amends, and paying a sufficient ransom for sin.

column7: And this sonne of God (accordynge to the wyll of his father,) dyd take vpon hym the nature of man, ioyninge to his euerlastynge Godheade, the whole, and perfyte nature of manhode, not making that nature of man, which he toke, a new of nothing, as he dyd heauen and earth, nor yet makynge it, of a clod of earth, as he dyd ye body of Adam, but he toke the nature of man, of the very substaunce of the vyrgyn Mary his mother, that lyke as Adam and Eue, brought them selues,
column8: And this son of God (according to the will of his father,) did take upon him the nature of man, joining to his everlasting Godhead, the Whole, and perfect nature of manhood, not making that nature of man, which he took, a new of nothing, as he did heaven and earth, nor yet making it, of a clod of earth, as he did the body of Adam, but he took the nature of man, of the very substance of the Virgae Marry his mother, that like as Adam and Eue, brought them selves,

column7: & all theyr posteritie, through sinne, into the estate of eternal dampnatio:
column8: & all their posterity, through sin, into the estate of Eternal dampnatio:

column7: so Christ, takynge vpon him, the very selfe same nature, beyng descended from Adam and Eue, vnto. the Vyrgin Mary, and of her beynge taken, and ioyned in hym to the godhead, in vnitie of person, should by his innocency,
column8: so christ, taking upon him, the very self same nature, being descended from Adam and Eue, unto. the Virgin Marry, and of her being taken, and joined in him to the godhead, in unity of person, should by his innocency,

column7: & through death, wyllyngly suffered in that his most innocent bodye, not only hym self, become immortal ma,
column8: & through death, willingly suffered in that his most innocent body, not only him self, become immortal ma,

column7: & haue glory euerlasting, but make so many also, partakers of lyke blessednes, as shuld enioye the merites of his passion.
column8: & have glory everlasting, but make so many also, partakers of like blessedness, as should enjoy the merits of his passion.

column7: Wherefore, it is a very pernicious errour, to thynke that christ tooke not his fleshe, of the verye fleshe of the blessed Vyrgyn Mary his mother.
column8: Wherefore, it is a very pernicious error, to think that Christ took not his Flesh, of the very Flesh of the blessed Virgae Marry his mother.

column7: Howe could his death haue done me good, if it were not of the same nature that I am of?
column8: Howe could his death have done me good, if it were not of the same nature that I am of?

column7: <NOTE> & therefore S.
column8: & Therefore S.

column7: Paule in his seconde chapiter of his Epistle to the Hebrues sayeth.
column8: Paul in his seconde chapter of his Epistle to the Hebrews Saith.

column7: Qui sanctificat, et qui sanctificantur, ex vno omnes, that is.
column8: Qui sanctificat, et qui sanctificantur, ex vno omnes, that is.

column7: He that sanctyfyeth, and they which are sanctifyed, are all of one:
column8: He that sanctyfyeth, and they which Are sanctified, Are all of one:

column7: and within a lyttle after he sayeth farther,
column8: and within a little After he Saith farther,

column7: Debuit per omnia fratribus assimulari, vt misericors fieret, et fidelis pontifex, ad deum, vt repropitiaret delicta populi, that is,
column8: Debt per omnia fratribus assimulari, vt misericors fieret, et Fidelis pontifex, ad God, vt repropitiaret Delicta People, that is,

column7: Christe muste in all poyntes, become lyke to his brethren, that he myght be a merciful and fruteful Bisshop to Godward, to procure mercy for the sinnes of the people.
column8: Christ must in all points, become like to his brothers, that he might be a merciful and fruitful Bishop to Godward, to procure mercy for the Sins of the people.

column7: If Christ tooke not the flesh of ye Virgin Marye, howe is that promyse fulfylled, which God made immediatly after the falle of our first paretes, when he thrust them out of paradise, at which tyme, he said vnto the serpente (as it is written in ye thyrde chapiter of Genesis.) I wyl set enmitie betwixt the, and the womans sede,
column8: If christ took not the Flesh of the Virgae Marye, how is that promise fulfilled, which God made immediately After the fall of our First paretes, when he thrust them out of paradise, At which time, he said unto the serpent (as it is written in you Third chapter of Genesis.) I will Set enmity betwixt thee, and the woman's seed,

column7: and it shall treade downe thy hedde:
column8: and it shall tread down thy head:

column7: Lo, how mercifully God dealeth wyth mankynde,
column8: Lo, how mercifully God deals with mankind,

column7: He promysed that one shoulde be borne of the sede and stocke of Eue, which should vanquyshe our ghostly enemy the diuell.
column8: He promised that one should be born of the seed and stock of Eue, which should vanquish our ghostly enemy the Devil.

column7: Nowe in that he calleth hym the sede of the woman, he moste playnely declareth, that he must nedes haue in him the selfe same nature that the woman had.
column8: Now in that he calls him the seed of the woman, he most plainly Declareth, that he must needs have in him the self same nature that the woman had.

column7: Agayne God makyng the second promyse of the same sede, to come of the stocke of Abraham the patriarke, said vnto Abraham, (as is wytnessed in the.xxii. of Genesys) In thy sede shall all the nations of the world be blessed,
column8: Again God making the second promise of the same seed, to come of the stock of Abraham the patriarch, said unto Abraham, (as is witnessed in the xxii of Genesis) In thy seed shall all the Nations of the world be blessed,

column7: <NOTE> & many hudred yeares after yt, he promyssed lykewyse to Kyng Dauyd, that, that sede should come of hym to.
column8: & many hudred Years After that, he promised likewise to King David, that, that seed should come of him to.

column7: Which promyses of almyghty God, were not to be verified in Chryst, if he toke not ye substauce of his flesh, of the Virgin Mary his mother.
column8: Which promises of almighty God, were not to be verified in Christ, if he took not you substance of his Flesh, of the Virgae Marry his mother.

column7: But here it may seme strauge to some, yt almighty god (seing he inteded from ye beginninge, to sed his sonne into ye world, to be incarnate for mans redeption) did defer the sendinge of hym soo longe, that is, the space of foure thousande yeares or theraboute.
column8: But Here it may seem strauge to Some, that almighty god (sing he inteded from you begin, to said his son into you world, to be incarnate for men Redemption) did defer the sending of him so long, that is, the Molle of foure thousande Years or theraboute.

column7: To whome it is to be aunswered, that the long taryinge of Chryste, before he was incarnate, came not of lacke of good wyl in god, towardes vs, but of vnredines, and lacke of good disposition, to receyue hym on oure partes.
column8: To whom it is to be answered, that the long tarrying of Christ, before he was incarnate, Come not of lack of good will in god, towards us, but of unreadiness, and lack of good disposition, to receive him on our parts.

column7: For if Chryste shoulde haue commen in the begynnyng of the worlde, men would haue thought, that if God had suffered them to vse theyr owne natural powers, they would haue attayned saluation well inough, without any other helpe on Gods parte.
column8: For if Christ should have come in the beginning of the world, men would have Thought, that if God had suffered them to use their own natural Powers, they would have attained salvation well enough, without any other help on God's part.

column7: Agayne, thoughe after longe experience, and trauayle of man, folowing the onelye lyghte of nature, it was euydente, that he neded a speciall ayde from God, to the attaynynge of euerlastynge lyfe, yet the worlde myghte haue demed, that in case God of hys goodnes, had geuen vnto manne some speciall lyghte, and knowledge of hys wyll and pleasure, that then vndoughtedlye, without farther helpe, he folowynge suche specyall lyght, and knowledge, myght be able well inoughe to attayne to euerlastynge lyfe.
column8: Again, though After long experience, and travail of man, following the only Light of nature, it was euydente, that he needed a special aid from God, to the attaining of everlasting life, yet the world might have deemed, that in case God of his Goodness, had given unto man Some special Light, and knowledge of his will and pleasure, that then vndoughtedlye, without farther help, he following such special Light, and knowledge, might be able well enough to attain to everlasting life.

column7: Therefore, to take all suche excuses awaye, and that we should plainelye vnderstande, that after we once fell into sinne, neither the light of nature in vs, neyther the knowledge of the wyll of God, by speciall reuelation opened vnto vs, was able to helpe vs, god suffred mankynde to trauel, fyrst by the light of nature, secondly by the lawe of Moyses, and yet man ranne styll farther, and farther, into damnation.
column8: Therefore, to take all such excuses away, and that we should plainly understand, that After we once fell into sin, neither the Light of nature in us, neither the knowledge of the will of God, by special Revelation opened unto us, was able to help us, god suffered mankind to travel, fyrst by the Light of nature, secondly by the law of Moses, and yet man ran still farther, and farther, into damnation.

column7: Whereby it appereth, that though knowledge of the truth be necessarye, to the attayninge of euerlastinge lyfe, yet suche knowledge (be it neuer so great) beyng in a man corrupted with synne, is to feble and to weake to purge him of sinne.
column8: Whereby it appeareth, that though knowledge of the truth be necessary, to the attaining of everlasting life, yet such knowledge (be it never so great) being in a man corrupted with sin, is to feeble and to weak to purge him of sin.

column7: For purgation & clensing of synne, commeth by some other meanes, besides ye knowledge of the truth:
column8: For purgation & cleansing of sin, comes by Some other means, beside the knowledge of the truth:

column7: and therfore S. Paule in the fyrste chapiter of his epistle to the Romaines, most plainly affirmeth, that in the time of ye law of nature, men knew inough of God, but yet, not withstanding theyr knoledge, they fell into abhominable idolatry.
column8: and Therefore S. Paul in the First chapter of his epistle to the Romans, most plainly Affirmeth, that in the time of the law of nature, men knew enough of God, but yet, not withstanding their knowledge, they fell into abominable idolatry.

column7: The wordes of S. Paule, in that place are these.
column8: The words of S. Paul, in that place Are these.

column7: So much as may be knowen of god, is manifest in the (that is to say, in those whiche liued vnder the lawe of nature, from Adam vnto Moyses) For his inuisible thinges, euen his eternal power,
column8: So much as may be known of god, is manifest in the (that is to say, in those which lived under the law of nature, from Adam unto Moses) For his invisible things, even his Eternal power,

column7: & godhed, were sene of the, being vnderstanded by the works of the creatio of the world, so that they are without excuse, bicause, that when they knew God, they glorified hym not as god nether were thankeful, but becamful of vanitie in their imaginacions.
column8: & godhead, were seen of thee, being understanded by the works of the Creation of the world, so that they Are without excuse, Because, that when they knew God, they glorified him not as god neither were thankful, but becamful of vanity in their Imaginations.

column7: And as ye lyght whiche men had by the lawes of nature, was not of force, to kepe them from synne, so nether the lawe of Moyses, beyng opened from god him selfe by special reuelatio, could suffice to ryde ma from sinne (as S.
column8: And as you Light which men had by the laws of nature, was not of force, to keep them from sin, so neither the law of Moses, being opened from god him self by special reuelatio, could suffice to ride ma from sin (as S.

column7: Paule in the second chapiter of his foresayde epistle testifieth saying) Behold thou art a Iew,
column8: Paul in the second chapter of his foresaid epistle Testifieth saying) Behold thou art a Jew,

column7: and thou doest rest in the law, and doest glory in god, and doest know his wyl and pleasure,
column8: and thou dost rest in the law, and dost glory in god, and dost know his will and pleasure,

column7: & being instructed in the lawe, thou doest allowe that is best, and doest truste that thou art a guyde of the blinde, a light to the which are in darkenes, an instructour of the folyshe, a mayster of the ignorante, and that thou knowest by the lawe the fourme of sciens & truth:
column8: & being instructed in the law, thou dost allow that is best, and dost trust that thou art a guide of the blind, a Light to the which Are in darkness, an instructor of the foolish, a master of the ignorant, and that thou Knowest by the law the Form of sciens & truth:

column7: but yet thou that teachest other, teachest not thy selfe, thou yt prechest against aduoutri, art an aduoutrer thy self, thou that dooest defye Idoles, commyttest sacriledge thy selfe, thou that doest glorye in the lawe, through transgressing of the lawe, doest dyshoner God, for the name of God, throughe you, is blasphemed amongest the gentyles.
column8: but yet thou that Teachest other, Teachest not thy self, thou that prechest against aduoutri, art an aduoutrer thy self, thou that dost defy Idols, commyttest sacrilege thy self, thou that dost glory in the law, through transgressing of the law, dost dyshoner God, for the name of God, through you, is blasphemed amongst the Gentiles.

column7: Thus it is euydente, by the doctryne of Saynte Paule, that nother by the common lawe of nature, nether by the special knowledge of the law of Moises, man was able to auoyde eternal dapnation, but that he neded, besides such knowledge, of some other helpe that is, of amendes, to be made for his sinnes, and thereby, to be reduced into the fauour of god agayne, and to haue aboundaunce of grace geuen vnto hym, by which grace he should both in his knowledg be ye better established,
column8: Thus it is euydente, by the Doctrine of Faint Paul, that neither by the Common law of nature, neither by the special knowledge of the law of Moses, man was able to avoid Eternal dapnation, but that he needed, beside such knowledge, of Some other help that is, of amends, to be made for his Sins, and thereby, to be reduced into the favour of god again, and to have abundance of grace given unto him, by which grace he should both in his knowledge be the better established,

column7: & be able also, according to knowledge of ye truth, to walke in the truth.
column8: & be able also, according to knowledge of the truth, to walk in the truth.

column7: For this amendes to be made, the second person in trinitie, being god immortal, became mortal man,
column8: For this amends to be made, the second person in trinity, being god immortal, became Mortal man,

column7: & was made in all partes like vnto one of vs (sinne only excepted) and he did vnite vnto his godhead, the body and soule of man, in vnitie of person, in such a meruelous sort, that as in vs, the body being of one nature, and the soule being of an other nature, doo make yet but one person, so in hym the nature of God, and the whole perfect nature of man, doo make but one person.
column8: & was made in all parts like unto one of us (sin only excepted) and he did unite unto his godhead, the body and soul of man, in unity of person, in such a marvelous sort, that as in us, the body being of one nature, and the soul being of an other nature, do make yet but one person, so in him the nature of God, and the Whole perfect nature of man, do make but one person.

column7: Of this incomprehensible vnion of ye godhed,
column8: Of this incomprehensible Union of the godhead,

column7: & manhed in Christ, <NOTE> S. Ihon speaketh in the fyrst chapiter of his gospell, saying.
column8: & manhood in christ, S. John speaks in the fyrst chapter of his gospel, saying.

column7: Verbum caro factum est, et habitauit in nobis, the worde, (that is the sonne of God) Was made fleshe,
column8: Verbum Caro factum est, et habitauit in nobis, the word, (that is the son of God) Was made Flesh,

column7: ) (that is man) & dwelt amogest vs. he dwelt here on the earth, (as scripture declareth,) aboue.xxxiij. yeares, and when he had fulfylled al thynges, accordyng to the sayinges of the holy prophetes, whiche were to be fulfylled of hym before his passion, then he suffred death willingly, yea, the death of the crosse, by suche payne, (wrongefullye procured of the deuil against him) to raunsome mankynde oute of captiuitie, whiche it sustayned vnder the deuyll moost iustly:
column8: ) (that is man) & dwelled Amongst us he dwelled Here on the earth, (as scripture Declareth,) above xxxiij Years, and when he had fulfilled all things, according to the sayings of the holy Prophets, which were to be fulfilled of him before his passion, then he suffered death willingly, yea, the death of the cross, by such pain, (wrongfully procured of the Devil against him) to ransom mankind out of captivity, which it sustained under the Devil most justly:

column7: and that this raunsome shold be perfyt, he suffred sondry sortes of mooste spytefull wronges, and intollerable paynes,
column8: and that this ransom should be perfect, he suffered sundry sorts of most spiteful wrongs, and intolerable pains,

column7: & tormentes, in his most pure, and innocent body, as buffeting, bindinge, scourgyng, plattynge on his head, a crowne of thorne, hanginge on the crosse, pearcing of his handes and fete with nayles, openynge of his syde with a speare, and shedynge of his mooste precious bloude, whiche passion of his, as it is a moost parfyt myrrour, and glasse for vs, therein to beholde the excedynge great loue of god towarde vs, whiche spared not his onelye sonne, but for vs all gaue hym to dye, so it is a sufficient occasion, to brynge all men in extreme hatred of the deuyll, and synne:
column8: & torments, in his most pure, and innocent body, as buffeting, binding, scourging, platting on his head, a crown of thorn, hanging on the cross, piercing of his hands and feet with nails, opening of his side with a spear, and shedding of his most precious blood, which passion of his, as it is a most parfyt mirror, and glass for us, therein to behold the exceeding great love of god toward us, which spared not his only son, but for us all gave him to die, so it is a sufficient occasion, to bring all men in extreme hatred of the Devil, and sin:

column7: from daunger of whome, mankynde coulde not be rydde, but onely by so paynefull a death, of the sonne of God.
column8: from danger of whom, mankind could not be rid, but only by so painful a death, of the son of God.

column7: What can we loke for at gods handes, yf we synne from hence forth, but wrath and vengeaunce, seynge he hath once delyuered vs from synne, by so merciful a meanes?
column8: What can we look for At God's hands, if we sin from hence forth, but wrath and vengeance, sing he hath once Delivered us from sin, by so merciful a means?

column7: All that our sauyoure Christe suffered, he wyllingely suffered for our synnes, hym selfe hauing neuer deserued anye whyt of payne, as who neuer synned.
column8: All that our Saviour Christ suffered, he willingly suffered for our Sins, him self having never deserved any whyt of pain, as who never sinned.

column7: And yet his passion, though it be in it selfe a sufficiente raunsome, for the synnes of the whole worlde, yet it taketh not place in all men:
column8: And yet his passion, though it be in it self a sufficient ransom, for the Sins of the Whole world, yet it Takes not place in all men:

column7: not for insufficiencie in it selfe, but for defaute in them, that shoulde condignely receaue the merites thereof.
column8: not for insufficiency in it self, but for default in them, that should condignly receive the merits thereof.

column7: For this you must know, that God requyreth in vs certayne thinges, to be accomplished by our owne wil, and consent, without the whiche, we can not be saued, no more, than yf Christ had neuer dyed for vs.
column8: For this you must know, that God requireth in us certain things, to be accomplished by our own will, and consent, without the which, we can not be saved, no more, than if christ had never died for us

column7: What thinges these are, shalbe hereafter declared vnto you.
column8: What things these Are, shall hereafter declared unto you.

column7: In the meane season, lyft vp your hartes, and open them awyde, to receaue in, vnto them, a great loue towardes God, who so nobylye created vs, and when we, through our owne defaute, were fallen into the estate of endles misery, and wretchednes, so mercyfully redemed vs, by the passion, and death of his onely sonne our sauiour Christ.
column8: In the mean season, lift up your hearts, and open them awyde, to receive in, unto them, a great love towards God, who so nobylye created us, and when we, through our own default, were fallen into the estate of endless misery, and wretchedness, so mercifully redeemed us, by the passion, and death of his only son our Saviour christ.

column7: Remember that synne, and nought els, brought vs fyrst oute of Gods fauour, and that to take awaye synne, the sonne of God was incarnate, and suffered mooste paynefull death on the crosse, and therefore hereafter, flee you all kynde of synne, and fight incessantly, agaynst your ghostly enemye the deuyll, who being vanquished by Christ, is not able now to ouerthrow vs, if we, in the right fayth of Christ, valiantly withstande hym, whiche to doo, graunt vnto vs, the blessed trinitie, the father, the sonne, and the holy ghost, to whome be all honour, and glory, worlde without ende.
column8: remember that sin, and nought Else, brought us fyrst out of God's favour, and that to take away sin, the son of God was incarnate, and suffered most painful death on the cross, and Therefore hereafter, flee you all kind of sin, and fight incessantly, against your ghostly enemy the Devil, who being vanquished by christ, is not able now to overthrow us, if we, in the right faith of christ, valiantly withstand him, which to do, grant unto us, the blessed trinity, the father, the son, and the holy ghost, to whom be all honour, and glory, world without end.

column7: Amen. Io. Harpesfelde, sacrae theologiae professor.
column8: Amen. Io. Harpesfelde, Sacrae Theologiae professor.

column8: Arch. London.

column8: an Homely declaring how the redemption in christ is appliable to us

column7: A Lthough the death and passion of our sauiour christ, be in value a sufficient raunsome for the synnes of the whole world, yet in effect it taketh not place in ye whole world.
column8: ALthough ALthough the death and passion of our Saviour Christ, be in valve a sufficient ransom for the Sins of the Whole world, yet in Effect it Takes not place in you Whole world.

column7: For neyther Turke, Iew, nor infidell, wating beleif in Christe, can take good by the death and passio of Christ, the scripture most manifestly affyrming in the.xvi.
column8: For neither Turk, Jew, nor infidel, wating belief in Christ, can take good by the death and passio of christ, the scripture most manifestly affirming in the xvi

column7: chapter of S. Marke, that Whosoeuer doth not beleue shall be dapned.
column8: chapter of S. Mark, that Whosoever does not believe shall be dapned.

column7: Agayne, euyll lyfe, bryngeth to the euyl lyuer, eternall death, beleue he neuer soo wel.
column8: Again, evil life, bringeth to the evil liver, Eternal death, believe he never so well.

column7: As S. Paule witnesseth, in the.v. chapiter of his Epistle to the Galathians,
column8: As S. Paul Witnesseth, in the v chapter of his Epistle to the Galatians,

column7: <NOTE> where he sayth:
column8: where he say:

column7: Walke after the spirite, and fulfyll not the lustes of the fleshe.
column8: Walk After the Spirit, and fulfil not the lusts of the Flesh.

column7: For the flesh lusteth contrary to the spirit, and the spirit contrary to the fleshe.
column8: For the Flesh Lusteth contrary to the Spirit, and the Spirit contrary to the Flesh.

column7: These are cotrary one to another, so that you do not what ye woulde:
column8: These Are contrary one to Another, so that you do not what you would:

column7: But and yf ye be led of the spirit, then are ye not vnder the law.
column8: But and if you be led of the Spirit, then Are you not under the law.

column7: The dedes of the fleshe are manifest which are these aduoutry, fornicatio, vnclennes, watonnes,
column8: The Deeds of the Flesh Are manifest which Are these aduoutry, Fornication, uncleanness, watonnes,

column7: ydolatry, wytchcrafte, hatred, variauce, contencion, wrath, stryfe, sedition, sectes, enuye, murder, dronkennes, glotony, and such like, of which I tel you before (as I haue told you in tyme past) that they which commit suche thinges, shal not inherit the kingdo of heaue Thus you perceaue that to ye enioying of the death, and passion of Christe, these two poyntes are requisit of our behalf, the one, to beleue rightly, the other, to lyue vpryghtlye, whiche two poyntes, no man is able otherwyse to knowe (except it be by speciall reuelation from God) but onely by the catholike churche, whiche catholyke churche, our sauioure Christe hath appoynted, to be the onely scoole, for all men to come and repayre vnto, to learne suche truth, as is mete for them to know, for the attayning of euerlastyng life.
column8: idolatry, wytchcrafte, hatred, variance, contention, wrath, strife, sedition, Sects, envy, murder, Drunkenness, gluttony, and such like, of which I tell you before (as I have told you in time passed) that they which commit such things, shall not inherit the Kingdom of heave Thus you perceive that to you enjoying of the death, and passion of Christ, these two points Are requisite of our behalf, the one, to believe rightly, the other, to live vpryghtlye, which two points, no man is able otherwise to know (except it be by special Revelation from God) but only by the catholic Church, which catholic Church, our Saviour Christ hath appointed, to be the only School, for all men to come and repair unto, to Learn such truth, as is meet for them to know, for the attaining of everlasting life.

column7: This catholike church, and no other company, hath ye true vnderstandinge of scripture,
column8: This catholic Church, and no other company, hath the true understanding of scripture,

column7: & the knowledge of all thinges necessary to saluation.
column8: & the knowledge of all things necessary to salvation.

column7: To this church, Christ maketh promis, in ye.xvi. of Iohn,
column8: To this Church, christ makes promise, in you xvi of John,

column7: saying: Whe that spirite of truth shal come, he shal teache you al truth.
column8: saying: When that Spirit of truth shall come, he shall teach you all truth.

column7: To this churche also he maketh that other promis, written in the.xxviii. of Mathew, where he sayth:
column8: To this Church also he makes that other promise, written in the xxviii of Matthew, where he say:

column7: Beholde I am with you, to the ende of the world.
column8: Behold I am with you, to the end of the world.

column7: This Catholyke churche, thus gouerned by the holy Ghost,
column8: This Catholic Church, thus governed by the holy Ghost,

column7: & assisted alwayes, of Christ him selfe, neuer yet fayled, fro the tyme of the Apostles, hitherto, ne shal fayl, to ye worldes ende, nether can it be deceaued in any necessarye truth, accordyng as Chryst promyseth in the.xvi. of Mathewe,
column8: & assisted always, of christ him self, never yet failed, from the time of the Apostles, hitherto, ne shall fail, to the world's end, neither can it be deceived in any necessary truth, according as Christ promiseth in the xvi of Matthew,

column7: saying. That hell gates shal not preuayle agaynst the churche. where, by hel gates he meaneth errour, as yf he had sayd, that the catholyke churche shall neuer be ouercome with erroure.
column8: saying. That hell gates shall not prevail against the Church. where, by hell gates he means error, as if he had said, that the catholic Church shall never be overcome with error.

column7: For this cause S. Paule in the third chapiter of his first epistle to Timothe,
column8: For this cause S. Paul in the third chapter of his First epistle to Timothy,

column7: calleth the catholike church, the piller and grounde of truth.
column8: calls the catholic Church, the pillar and ground of truth.

column7: This catholike churche, must in al ages nedes be an open knowen churche, and such a company, as among whych, the trueth is openly preached, ells Chryst woulde not haue sayd, (as it is wrytten in the.v. of Mathewe) A citie that is set on a hyl,
column8: This catholic Church, must in all ages needs be an open known Church, and such a company, as among which, the truth is openly preached, Else Christ would not have said, (as it is written in the v of Matthew) A City that is Set on a hyl,

column7: can not be hyd, nether do men lyght a candel, and put it vnder a bushel but on a candelstycke, and it geueth lyght vnto all that are in the house.
column8: can not be hid, neither do men Light a candle, and put it under a bushel but on a candelstycke, and it Giveth Light unto all that Are in the house.

column7: Wherfore they do great iniury to Chryst, which saye, that the catholyke churche is an vnknowen churche, seing it is that citie, which our sauiour there ment, and that candell, of whiche he there speaketh.
column8: Wherefore they do great injury to Christ, which say, that the catholic Church is an unknown Church, sing it is that City, which our Saviour there meant, and that candle, of which he there speaks.

column7: So manye as deuyde them selues fro this open knowen Churche of Chryste, and refuse the doctryne thereof, thoughe they be neuer so diligent in readyng of scrypture, yet shall they neuer truely vnderstande scrypture, but runne continually farther and farther into erroure, and ignoraunce, eue as a man that is once out of his way, the farther, and faster he goeth furth, the more he loseth his labour. <NOTE> Saint Peter therefore in the fyrst Chapiter of his second epistle, geueth vs a most certayne and sure rule, which if we folowe, we shall not fayle, ryghtly to vnderstande scripture:
column8: So many as divide them selves from this open known Church of Christ, and refuse the Doctrine thereof, though they be never so diligent in reading of scripture, yet shall they never truly understand scripture, but run continually farther and farther into error, and ignorance, eve as a man that is once out of his Way, the farther, and faster he Goes forth, the more he loses his labour. Saint Peter Therefore in the fyrst Chapter of his second epistle, Giveth us a most certain and sure Rule, which if we follow, we shall not fail, rightly to understand scripture:

column7: his rule is thys. We haue (sayth he) A ryght sure worde of prophecie, wherevnto yf ye take hede, as vnto a lighte yt shineth in a darke place, you doo wel, vntyl the day dawne, and the daye starre aryse in your hartes.
column8: his Rule is this. We have (say he) A right sure word of prophecy, whereunto if you take heed, as unto a Light that shines in a dark place, you do well, until the day dawn, and the day star arise in your hearts.

column7: So that you first knowe this, that no prophecie in ye scripture hath any priuate interpretation.
column8: So that you First know this, that no prophecy in you scripture hath any private Interpretation.

column7: For ye scripture came neuer by the wil of man, but holy men of God spake, as they were moued by the holi ghost.
column8: For you scripture Come never by the will of man, but holy men of God spoke, as they were moved by the holy ghost.

column7: Here you se, how saynt Peter willeth euery man, fyrst of all, to knowe, that scripture must be vnderstanded after the generall meanynge of Chrystes churche, and not after the priuate interpretation of any seuerall man, or companye:
column8: Here you see, how saint Peter wills every man, fyrst of all, to know, that scripture must be understanded After the general meaning of Christ's Church, and not After the private Interpretation of any several man, or company:

column7: And in the thyrde chapiter of the same Epystle, he sayeth further, that in S.
column8: And in the Third chapter of the same Epistle, he Saith further, that in S.

column7: Paules epistles, are manye thinges harde to be vnderstanded, whych they that are vnlearned,
column8: Paul's Epistles, Are many things harden to be understanded, which they that Are unlearned,

column7: & vnstable, doo peruerte, as they doo also the other scriptures, to theyr owne destruction:
column8: & unstable, do pervert, as they do also the other Scriptures, to their own destruction:

column7: ye therefore beloued (seing you be warned afore hand) beware, leaste ye, with other men, be also plucked a waye through the errour of the wicked, and fall from your owne stedfastnesse.
column8: you Therefore Beloved (sing you be warned afore hand) beware, jest you, with other men, be also plucked a Way through the error of the wicked, and fallen from your own steadfastness.

column7: Lo here S. Peter telleth the very cause, why men mysvnderstand scrypture, which is lacke of knoweledge, and lacke of constancie, when men ether thorowe ignoraunce, or thoroughe inconstancie, swerue from the catholyke meanyng, and folowe pryuate interpretation.
column8: Lo Here S. Peter Telleth the very cause, why men mysvnderstand scripture, which is lack of knowledge, and lack of constancy, when men either thorough ignorance, or thorough inconstancy, swerve from the catholic meaning, and follow private Interpretation.

column7: Such men, he sayeth, do peruerte the scriptures to theyr owne destruction.
column8: Such men, he Saith, do pervert the Scriptures to their own destruction.

column7: Saynte Paule also wrytyng to Tymothe, and willing hym to be earnest in the study of scripture, <NOTE> geueth him withal this foresayd rule, saying in the very ende of his fyrst epistle:
column8: Faint Paul also writing to Timothy, and willing him to be earnest in the study of scripture, Giveth him withal this foresaid Rule, saying in the very end of his fyrst epistle:

column7: O Timothie, kepe sure that, whiche is committed to thy custody, and auoide newe fangled termes, and bosting of science, falsely so called, which science whyle some dyd professe, they haue erred from the fayth.
