column8: Oh Timothy, keep sure that, which is committed to thy custody, and avoid new fangled terms, and boasting of science, falsely so called, which science while Some did profess, they have erred from the faith.

column7: The thinge, whiche S. Paule sayth was commytted to Timothies custody, was the truth of the catholyke fayth, which he sayth, some fell frome, by reasone of new fangled termes, and by reason also, that they tooke vpon them knowledge, beinge in dede ignoraunte.
column8: The thing, which S. Paul say was committed to Timothies custody, was the truth of the catholic faith, which he say, Some fell from, by reason of new fangled terms, and by reason also, that they took upon them knowledge, being in deed ignorant.

column7: And in the thyrd chapiter of his seconde epistle to Timothie, <NOTE> he farther sayeth.
column8: And in the Third chapter of his seconde epistle to Timothy, he farther Saith.

column7: Contynue thou in the thinges which thou hast learned which also were commytted vnto the.
column8: Continue thou in the things which thou hast learned which also were committed unto thee.

column7: S. Ireneus also (a blessed martyr, and very nyghe to the tyme of the Apostles, a man of greate learning, and no lesse vertue, and such a one, as by the consente of all men, had the perfyt knowledge and vnderstandynge of scryptures) in his third boke agaynst Valentyne the arche heretyke, and in the fowrth chapiter of the same boke sayeth,
column8: S. Irenaeus also (a blessed martyr, and very High to the time of the Apostles, a man of great learning, and no less virtue, and such a one, as by the consent of all men, had the perfect knowledge and understanding of Scriptures) in his third book against Valentine the arch heretic, and in the fowrth chapter of the same book Saith,

column7: <NOTE> touchyng the catholyke churche in thys maner.
column8: touching the catholic Church in this manner.

column7: We must not seke ye trueth among other, seing we may easely take it of the church, for as much as the Apostels haue fully lefte with it (as in a rych tresury) all truth, yt who so listeth, may thence take the drinkes of lyfe, for this is the entre to life.
column8: We must not seek you truth among other, sing we may Easily take it of the Church, for as much as the Apostles have Fully left with it (as in a rich treasury) all truth, that who so lists, may thence take the drinks of life, for this is the entre to life.

column7: All other are theues, and robbers, wherfore them must we auoyd:
column8: All other Are thieves, and robbers, Wherefore them must we avoid:

column7: & that doctryne that the church teacheth, we muste loue,
column8: & that Doctrine that the Church Teaches, we must love,

column7: & with great diligence embrace the tradition of the truth.
column8: & with great diligence embrace the tradition of the truth.

column7: For what and yf a controuersy should happen to ryse vpon neuer so smal a questio ought not men in that case to haue recourse to the most auncient churches, in which the Apostles were conuersaunt, and ther learne the truth in that controuersy?
column8: For what and if a controversy should happen to rise upon never so small a Question ought not men in that case to have recourse to the most ancient Churches, in which the Apostles were conversant, and there Learn the truth in that controversy?

column7: ye, what & yf the Apostles had lefte behynde them no writyng at all, must we then not haue folowed the order of tradition, delyuered by them to such as they committid the churches vnto?
column8: you, what & if the Apostles had left behind them no writing At all, must we then not have followed the order of tradition, Delivered by them to such as they committed the Churches unto?

column7: to which tradition manye barbarous nations, beleuing in Christ, do giue credite, with out any other wrytyng, then that which is in their hartes wrytten.
column8: to which tradition many barbarous Nations, believing in christ, do give credit, with out any other writing, then that which is in their hearts written.

column7: Al this wryteth Ireneus, and within a lytle after he sayeth.
column8: All this writes Irenaeus, and within a little After he Saith.

column7: Yf to these barbarous nations, any man should preach in their owne language, these inuentions of heretikes, by and by they would stoppe their eares, and flye as farre as they could fro him and not once here his blasphemous talke, thus sayeth S.
column8: If to these barbarous Nations, any man should preach in their own language, these Inventions of Heretics, by and by they would stop their ears, and fly as Far as they could from him and not once Here his blasphemous talk, thus Saith S.

column7: Ireneus. Now yf christen people at this preset, would folow this trade, which this blessed martir here speaketh of, the should no ma runne into heresy, but al me shold cleue fast vnto ye wholesome doctrine of the catholike church,
column8: Irenaeus. Now if christen people At this preset, would follow this trade, which this blessed Martyr's Here speaks of, the should no ma run into heresy, but all me should cleve fast unto you wholesome Doctrine of the catholic Church,

column7: & abhorre and detest, whatsoeuer any precher wold vtter vnto the, contrary to the same.
column8: & abhor and detest, whatsoever any preacher would utter unto thee, contrary to the same.

column7: For whosoeuer preacheth any doctrine, not agreable to ye general receiued doctrine in the open knowen church, he it is,
column8: For whosoever Preacheth any Doctrine, not agreeable to you general received Doctrine in the open known Church, he it is,

column7: & such as be like to him, of who our sauiour biddeth vs to beware, saiyng in ye.vii. of Mathewe.
column8: & such as be like to him, of who our Saviour bids us to beware, saying in you vii of Matthew.

column7: Beware of false prophets,
column8: Beware of false Prophets,

column7: which come to you in shepes clothing but inwardly they are rauenynge wolues.
column8: which come to you in Sheep clothing but inwardly they Are ravening wolves.

column7: Our sauior calleth them wolues, for yt they deuoure ye soules, of so many as giue credite vnto the, he sayeth fardar of them, that they come in lambes skins, because they pretend the woord of God, and therewith bleare the eyes of poore simple men, and make them beleue, that it is as they saye, where in dede, whatsoeuer is taught contrary to that, that al christendome openly teacheth, and from tyme to tyme hath taught, is false, and cannot possible be true, vnlesse we wold say, yt christ him selfe were not true.
column8: Our Saviour calls them wolves, for that they devour you Souls, of so many as give credit unto thee, he Saith fardar of them, that they come in Lambs skins, Because they pretend the word of God, and therewith blear the eyes of poor simple men, and make them believe, that it is as they say, where in deed, whatsoever is taught contrary to that, that all Christendom openly Teaches, and from time to time hath taught, is false, and cannot possible be true, unless we would say, that Christ him self were not true.

column7: For he promyseth yt hym selfe wilbe for euer wt ye churche, and yt the holy ghost, shal for euer gouerne the same.
column8: For he promiseth that him self will for ever with you Church, and that the holy ghost, shall for ever govern the same.

column7: Forasmuch than, as there is no other schole on the earth, for men to learne theyr duety, towardes God, and the world, but the catholyke churche:
column8: Forasmuch than, as there is no other school on the earth, for men to Learn their duty, towards God, and the world, but the catholic Church:

column7: nor no other doctryne, auayleable to eternall lyfe, but that whiche the catholyke churche teacheth, therefore all christe people are requyred, to make a solempne vow at theyr baptisme, to beleue the catholyke churche.
column8: nor no other Doctrine, available to Eternal life, but that which the catholic Church Teaches, Therefore all Christ people Are required, to make a solemn Voelli At their Baptism, to believe the catholic Church.

column7: And he that so doeth, is in an assured trade of saluation, if in his conuersation, he folowe the same, but contrarywyse, he that beleueth it not, is in a mooste certayne estate of euerlastynge dampnation.
column8: And he that so doth, is in an assured trade of salvation, if in his Conversation, he follow the same, but contrariwise, he that Believeth it not, is in a most certain estate of everlasting damnation.

column7: Wherefore, that you maye knowe, what the catholyke churche dothe in all poyntes beleue, there shalbe hereafter particularly, set forth vnto you, the seuerall matters, requisit to be beleued, and practised of all Christen people, that no man, maye haue iuste cause hereafter, to pretende ignoraunce, but all men beynge sufficiently instructed, maye, by folowynge suche doctryne, attayne to euerlastynge lyfe, whiche sende vnto vs all, the blessed trinitie, the father, the Sonne, and the holye Ghoste, to whom be all honoure, and glorye, worlde without ende.
column8: Wherefore, that you may know, what the catholic Church doth in all points believe, there shall hereafter particularly, Set forth unto you, the several matters, requisite to be believed, and practised of all christian people, that no man, may have just cause hereafter, to pretend ignorance, but all men being sufficiently instructed, may, by following such Doctrine, attain to everlasting life, which send unto us all, the blessed trinity, the father, the Son, and the holy Ghost, to whom be all honour, and glory, world without end.

column7: Amen. Io. Harpesfelde, sacrae theologiae professor.
column8: Amen. Io. Harpesfelde, Sacrae Theologiae professor.

column7: Arch. London.
column8: Arch. London.

column7: An Homely of Christian loue, or Charitye.
column8: an Homely of Christian love, or Charity.

column7: F Orasmuch as the pithe, and summe, of all thinges, which be conteyned, eyther in the lawe, or in the prophetes, doth stad, and cosist, in the loue of God, and in the loue of oure neyghboure, as our sauiour Christ dothe plainely testifye, in the.xxii.
column8: FOrasmuch FOrasmuch as the pith, and sum, of all things, which be contained, either in the law, or in the Prophets, does stad, and cosist, in the love of God, and in the love of our neighbour, as our Saviour christ doth plainly testify, in the xxii

column7: Chapiter of sainct Mathewe, sayenge, One of the Pharises beynge a doctoure of the lawe, tepting, did aske him, and say, mayster, what is the great comaudemet in ye law?
column8: Chapter of saint Matthew, saying, One of the Pharisees being a Doctor of the law, tepting, did ask him, and say, master, what is the great comaudemet in you law?

column7: Iesus, answerynge, sayd vnto hym.
column8: jesus, answering, said unto him.

column7: Thou shalte loue thy Lorde God, wyth all thy harte, wyth al thy soule, and wyth all thy hole mynde, this is (sayeth he) the greatest, and fyrste commaundement.
column8: Thou shalt love thy Lord God, with all thy heart, with all thy soul, and with all thy hold mind, this is (Saith he) the greatest, and First Commandment.

column7: And the seconde is lyke vnto it.
column8: And the seconde is like unto it.

column7: Thou shalte loue thy neyghboure, as thy selfe, and of these two commaundementes al the lawe dothe hange, and the Prophetes.
column8: Thou shalt love thy neighbour, as thy self, and of these two Commandments all the law doth hang, and the prophets.

column7: And forasmuche also, as we can not loue God well, except we doo loue oure neyghboure, in a due order ne yet loue oure neyghboure well, excepte we doo loue God, in that due order, that we oughte to doo, (Sainct Ihon the Euangelist so testifyeng, and declarynge,
column8: And forasmuch also, as we can not love God well, except we do love our neighbour, in a due order ne yet love our neighbour well, except we do love God, in that due order, that we ought to do, (Saint John the Evangelist so testifying, and declaring,

column7: <NOTE> in the thyrde and fourthe Chapiters of his fyrst canonicall Epistle.) And finally, forasmuche as he that loueth not after this sorte, is (by the testimonye of the sayde sainct Iohn, in the sayde thyrd Chapiter) iudged to be in death, therefore it is ryghte expediente, and necessarye, to haue alwayes this loue, whiche nowe in oure vulgare tongue, and common talke, is ofte named, by the name of Charitie, but very megerly, and coldely practised, and set fourthe in dede, as it shoulde be.
column8: in the Third and Fourth Chapiters of his fyrst canonical Epistle.) And finally, forasmuch as he that loves not After this sort, is (by the testimony of the said saint John, in the said Third Chapter) judged to be in death, Therefore it is right expedient, and necessary, to have always this love, which now in our Vulgar tongue, and Common talk, is oft nam, by the name of Charity, but very megerly, and coldly practised, and Set Fourth in deed, as it should be.

column7: And of trouthe, yf we woulde iudge vpryghtly, and well, we ought to saye, that of all thinges that be good, to be taught vnto Christen people, there is nothynge more necessarye to be spoken of, and daylye called vpon, then charitie:
column8: And of truth, if we would judge vpryghtly, and well, we ought to say, that of all things that be good, to be taught unto christian people, there is nothing more necessary to be spoken of, and daily called upon, then charity:

column7: aswell for that all maner of woorkes of righteousnes, be coteyned in it, as also, that the decaye thereof, is the ruyne of the worlde, the banyshement of vertue, and the cause of all vice.
column8: aswell for that all manner of works of righteousness, be coteyned in it, as also, that the decay thereof, is the ruin of the world, the banishment of virtue, and the cause of all vice.

column7: And forasmuche, as almost euery ma maketh,
column8: And forasmuch, as almost every ma makes,

column7: & frameth to him selfe a charity, after his owne appetyte, and howe detestable so euer his lyfe be, bothe vnto God, and man, yet he perswadeth with hym selfe styll, that he hathe charitye:
column8: & frameth to him self a charity, After his own appetite, and how detestable so ever his life be, both unto God, and man, yet he Persuadeth with him self still, that he hath charity:

column7: Therefore you shall heare nowe a true, and playne descripcion of charitie, not of mens ymagination, but of the very woordes, and example of oure sauioure Iesus Christe.
column8: Therefore you shall hear now a true, and plain description of charity, not of men's ymagination, but of the very words, and Exampl of our Saviour jesus Christ.

column7: In whyche description, euerye man (as it were in a glasse) may consyder hym selfe, and see plainely, without errour, whether he be in the true Charitye or not.
column8: In which description, every man (as it were in a glass) may Consider him self, and see plainly, without error, whither he be in the true Charity or not.

column7: charitie is to loue God, with all oure harte, withall our life, with al our powers,
column8: charity is to love God, with all our heart, withal our life, with all our Powers,

column7: & with all our strength.
column8: & with all our strength.

column7: With all our harte, that is to say, that our hartes, mynde,
column8: With all our heart, that is to say, that our hearts, mind,

column7: & studie, be set to beleue his woorde, to truste in hym, and to loue hym aboue all other thynges, whyche we doo loue best in heauen or in earthe.
column8: & study, be Set to believe his word, to trust in him, and to love him above all other things, which we do love best in heaven or in earth.

column7: Wyth all oure lyfe, that is to saye, that our chief ioye, and delyte, be sette vpon hym, and his honoure, and oure hole lyfe gyuen vnto the seruice of hym, aboue all thynges:
column8: With all our life, that is to say, that our chief joy, and delight, be Set upon him, and his honour, and our hold life given unto the service of him, above all things:

column7: wyth hym to lyue, and wyth hym to dye, yea, and to forsake all other thynges, rather then hym.
column8: with him to live, and with him to die, yea, and to forsake all other things, rather then him.

column7: For he that loueth hys father or mother, sonne, or doughter, house or lad, more then me (saieth Christ) is not worthy to haue me.
column8: For he that loves his father or mother, son, or daughter, house or lad, more then me (Saith christ) is not worthy to have me.

column7: Wyth all oure powers, that is to saye, that with our handes, and feete, wyth our eyes, and eares, oure mouthes and tongues, and wyth all other partes & powers, bothe of body and of soule, we shoulde be gyuen to the kepynge, and fulfyllynge of hys commaundementes.
column8: With all our Powers, that is to say, that with our hands, and feet, with our eyes, and ears, our mouths and tongues, and with all other parts & Powers, both of body and of soul, we should be given to the keeping, and fulfilling of his Commandments.

column7: This is the fyrste, and the principal parte of charity, but it is not the whole.
column8: This is the First, and the principal part of charity, but it is not the Whole.

column7: For charitie, is also to loue euery man, good, and euyll, frende, and fooe:
column8: For charity, is also to love every man, good, and evil, friend, and foe:

column7: And what soeuer cause be gyuen to the contrarye, yet neuertheles, to beare good will, and harte vnto euerye man, to vse oure selues wel vnto the, aswel in woordes, and countenauce, as in all our outeward actes, and dedes.
column8: And what soever cause be given to the contrary, yet nevertheless, to bear good will, and heart unto every man, to use our selves well unto thee, aswell in words, and countenance, as in all our outward acts, and Deeds.

column7: For so Christ hym selfe taught, and so also he perfourmed in dede.
column8: For so christ him self taught, and so also he performed in deed.

column7: And of this loue that we ought to haue amongest oure selues, eche to other, he instructeth vs thus. (Mathew. v.) You haue harde it taught in tymes paste?
column8: And of this love that we ought to have amongst our selves, eke to other, he Instructeth us thus. (Matthew. v.) You have harden it taught in times past?

column7: Thou shalte loue thy frende, and hate thy fooe:
column8: Thou shalt love thy friend, and hate thy foe:

column7: but I tell you, loue your enemyes, speake wel of them that diffame you, and doe speake euil of you:
column8: but I tell you, love your enemies, speak well of them that diffame you, and do speak evil of you:

column7: doo well to them that hate you, praye for the that vexe and persecute you, that you may be the children of your father, that is in heauen.
column8: do well to them that hate you, pray for the that vex and persecute you, that you may be the children of your father, that is in heaven.

column7: For he maketh the sunne to ryse bothe vpon the euyl, and good, and sendeth rayne to the iuste, and to the vniust.
column8: For he makes the sun to rise both upon the evil, and good, and sends rain to the just, and to the unjust.

column7: For if you loue them that loue you, what rewarde shal you haue?
column8: For if you love them that love you, what reward shall you have?

column7: Doo not the publicans lykewyse?
column8: Doo not the Publicans likewise?

column7: And yf you speake well onely of them, that be your brethren, and derely beloued frendes, what greate matter is that?
column8: And if you speak well only of them, that be your brothers, and dearly Beloved Friends, what great matter is that?

column7: doo not the heathe the same also?
column8: do not the heathen the same also?

column7: These be the very woordes of oure sauioure Christ him selfe, touching the loue of our neighbour.
column8: These be the very words of our Saviour christ him self, touching the love of our neighbour.

column7: And forasmuche as the Phariseis (wyth theyr moost pestilent traditions, false interpretacions, and gloses) had corrupted, and almooste clerelye stopped vp, this pure well, of Gods lyuely woorde, teaching that this loue, and charitye, pertayned onely to a mans frendes, and that it was sufficiente for a man to loue them whyche doo loue hym, and to hate hys fooes:
column8: And forasmuch as the Pharisees (with their most pestilent traditions, false interpretations, and gloss) had corrupted, and almooste clearly stopped up, this pure well, of God's lively word, teaching that this love, and charity, pertained only to a men Friends, and that it was sufficient for a man to love them which do love him, and to hate his foes:

column7: therefore Christe dyd open this well agayne, purged it, and scoured it, by gyuynge vnto hys godlye lawe of Charitie, a true and clere interpretation, which is this:
column8: Therefore Christ did open this well again, purged it, and scoured it, by gyving unto his godly law of Charity, a true and clear Interpretation, which is this:

column7: that we ought to loue euery ma, bothe frende, and fooe:
column8: that we ought to love every ma, both friend, and foe:

column7: addynge thereto, what commodity we shal haue thereby, and what in comodity by dooynge the contrarye.
column8: adding thereto, what commodity we shall have thereby, and what in commodity by doing the contrary.

column7: What thynge can we wysshe so good for vs, as the heauenlye father, to repute, and take vs, for hys chyldren?
column8: What thing can we wish so good for us, as the heavenly father, to repute, and take us, for his children?

column7: And this shall we be sure of (sayeth Christ,) yf we loue euery man, without exception.
column8: And this shall we be sure of (Saith christ,) if we love every man, without exception.

column7: And yf we doo otherwyse (sayeth he,) we be no better tha Phariseis,
column8: And if we do otherwise (Saith he,) we be no better than Pharisees,

column7: Publicans, and heathen persons, and shall haue oure rewarde with them:
column8: Publicans, and heathen Persons, and shall have our reward with them:

column7: that is, to be excluded from the number of gods elect chyldren, and from hys euerlastyng inheritaunce in heauen.
column8: that is, to be excluded from the number of God's elect children, and from his everlasting inheritance in heaven.

column7: Thus of true Charitye, Christ taughte, that euery man is bounde to loue God aboue al thinges, and to loue euery man, frende, and fooe.
column8: Thus of true Charity, christ taught, that every man is bound to love God above all things, and to love every man, friend, and foe.

column7: And thus lykewyse, he dyd vse hym selfe, exhortynge hys aduersaries, rebukynge the faultes of hys aduersaryes, and whan he coulde not amende them, yet he prayed for theim.
column8: And thus likewise, he did use him self, exhorting his Adversaries, rebuking the Faults of his Adversaries, and when he could not amend them, yet he prayed for them.

column7: Fyrste he loued God his father, aboue al thinges, so muche, that he sought not hys owne glorye, and wyll, but the glorye, and wyll of hys father:
column8: First he loved God his father, above all things, so much, that he sought not his own glory, and will, but the glory, and will of his father:

column7: I seke not (sayde he.
column8: I seek not (said he.

column7: Iohn. v.) myne owne wyll, but the wyll of hym that sent me:
column8: John. v.) mine own will, but the will of him that sent me:

column7: Nor he refused not to dye, to satysfye hys fathers wyll,
column8: Nor he refused not to die, to satisfy his Father's will,

column7: <NOTE> sayeng. Math. xxvi.
column8: saying. Math. xxvi.

column7: Yf it may be, let this cuppe of death goo from me, yf not, thy wyll be doone, and not myne.
column8: If it may be, let this cup of death goo from me, if not, thy will be done, and not mine.

column7: He loued also not onely hys frendes, but also hys enemyes, whyche in their hartes dyd beare exceding great hatred, agaist hym, and in theyr tongues spake all euyll of him, and in theyr actes, and dedes, pursued hym wyth al their myght, and power, eue vnto death.
column8: He loved also not only his Friends, but also his enemies, which in their hearts did bear exceeding great hatred, aghast him, and in their tongues spoke all evil of him, and in their acts, and Deeds, pursued him with all their might, and power, eve unto death.

column7: Yet al this notwythstandynge, he withdrewe not hys fauour from theim, but styll loued them, preached vnto them, of loue rebuked theyr false doctryne, theyr wycked lyuynge, and dyd good vnto them, pacientlye acceptynge what soeuer they spake, or dyd, agaynste him.
column8: Yet all this notwithstanding, he withdrew not his favour from them, but still loved them, preached unto them, of love rebuked their false Doctrine, their wicked living, and did good unto them, patiently accepting what soever they spoke, or did, against him.

column7: When they gaue hym euell woordes, he gaue none euyll agayne, when they dyd stryke hym, he dyd not smyte agayne:
column8: When they gave him evil words, he gave none evil again, when they did strike him, he did not smite again:

column7: And when he suffred deathe, he dyd not slea them, nor threaten them, but prayed for the, and referred all thynges to hys fathers wyll.
column8: And when he suffered death, he did not slay them, nor threaten them, but prayed for thee, and referred all things to his Father's will.

column7: And as a shepe that is led vnto the shambles to be slayne,
column8: And as a sheep that is led unto the shambles to be slain,

column7: <NOTE> and as a lambe that is shorne of hys flese, dyd make no noyse, nor resistence:
column8: and as a lamb that is shorn of his flese, did make no noise, nor resistance:

column7: euen so wente he vnto hys deathe, wythoute any repugnaunce, or openynge of hys mouthe, to saye anye euyll.
column8: even so went he unto his death, without any repugnance, or opening of his Mouth, to say any evil.

column7: Thus haue I described vnto you, what charitye is, aswell by the doctryne, as by the example of Christ hym selfe.
column8: Thus have I described unto you, what charity is, aswell by the Doctrine, as by the Exampl of christ him self.

column7: Whereby also, euery man may without erroure, know hym selfe, what state and condition he standeth in:
column8: Whereby also, every man may without error, know him self, what state and condition he Stands in:

column7: whether he be in charitye, (and so the chylde of the father in heauen) or not.
column8: whither he be in charity, (and so the child of the father in heaven) or not.

column7: For, althoughe almoste euery man perswadeth him selfe to be in Charity, yet let him examyne none other man, but hys owne harte, his life, and conuersation, and he shall not be deceyued, but truly decerne, and iudge, whether he be in perfyte charitye, or not.
column8: For, although almost every man Persuadeth him self to be in Charity, yet let him examine none other man, but his own heart, his life, and Conversation, and he shall not be deceived, but truly decern, and judge, whither he be in perfect charity, or not.

column7: For he that foloweth not hys owne appetite, and wyll, but gyueth hym selfe earnestly to God, to doo all hys wyll, and commaundementes, he maye be sure, that he loueth God, aboue all thynges, and els suerlye he loueth hym not, what so euer he pretende:
column8: For he that Followeth not his own appetite, and will, but gyveth him self earnestly to God, to do all his will, and Commandments, he may be sure, that he loves God, above all things, and Else surly he loves him not, what so ever he pretend:

column7: <NOTE> As Chryste sayd:
column8: As Christ said:

column7: If ye loue me, kepe you my comaundementes.
column8: If you love me, keep you my Commandments.

column7: For he that knoweth my commaundementes,
column8: For he that Knoweth my Commandments,

column7: & dothe kepe them, he it is (sayeth Christ) that loueth me.
column8: & doth keep them, he it is (Saith christ) that loves me.

column7: And agayne he sayeth: He that loueth me, wyl kepe my woorde, and my father wyll loue hym, and we wyll bothe come to hym, and dwel wyth hym.
column8: And again he Saith: He that loves me, will keep my word, and my father will love him, and we will both come to him, and dwell with him.

column7: And he that loueth me not, wyll not kepe my woordes.
column8: And he that loves me not, will not keep my words.

column7: And lykewyse, he that beareth good harte and mynde, and vseth well hys tongue, and dedes vnto euery man, frende, and fooe, he maye knowe thereby, that he hathe charity.
column8: And likewise, he that bears good heart and mind, and uses well his tongue, and Deeds unto every man, friend, and foe, he may know thereby, that he hath charity.

column7: And then he is sure also, that almyghty God taketh hym for hys dere beloued sonne, as Saincte Ihon sayeth, in the thyrde Chapiter of hys fyrste canonicall Epistle.
column8: And then he is sure also, that almighty God Takes him for his dear Beloved son, as Saint John Saith, in the Third Chapter of his First canonical Epistle.

column7: Hereby, manifestlye are knowen, the chyldren of God, from the children of the deuyll.
column8: Hereby, manifestly Are known, the children of God, from the children of the Devil.

column7: For who so euer dothe not loue hys brother, belongeth not vnto God.
column8: For who so ever doth not love his brother, belongeth not unto God.

column7: But the peruerse nature of man, corrupte wyth synne, and destitute of Gods woorde, and grace, thinketh it against all reason, that a man shoulde loue hys enemye, and hathe many perswasions, whyche induceth hym to the contrarye.
column8: But the perverse nature of man, corrupt with sin, and destitute of God's word, and grace, Thinketh it against all reason, that a man should love his enemy, and hath many persuasions, which induceth him to the contrary.

column7: Agaynste all whyche reasons, we oughte aswell to set the teachynge, as the lyuynge of oure sauioure Christe, who louynge vs (when we were hys enemyes) dothe teache vs to loue our enemyes.
column8: Against all which Reasons, we ought aswell to Set the teaching, as the living of our Saviour Christ, who loving us (when we were his enemies) doth teach us to love our enemies.

column7: He dyd paciently take for vs many reproches,
column8: He did patiently take for us many Reproaches,

column7: suffred beatynge, and moost cruell deathe.
column8: suffered beating, and most cruel death.

column7: Therfore we be no members of hym, yf we wyll not folowe hym.
column8: Therefore we be no members of him, if we will not follow him.

column7: For as S. Peter sayeth,
column8: For as S. Peter Saith,

column7: Christe suffered for vs, leauynge vs an example, that we should folowe him.
column8: Christ suffered for us, leaving us an Exampl, that we should follow him.

column7: Furthermore we must consider, that to loue oure frendes, is no more but that which theues, adulterers, homicides, and all wycked persons doo:
column8: Furthermore we must Consider, that to love our Friends, is no more but that which thieves, Adulterers, homicides, and all wicked Persons do:

column7: in so muche that Iewes,
column8: in so much that Jews,

column7: Turkes, Infidels, and all brute beastes, doo loue them that bee theyr frendes, of whome they haue theyr lyuynge, or any other benefytes.
column8: Turkes, Infidels, and all brutus beasts, do love them that be their Friends, of whom they have their living, or any other benefits.

column7: But to loue our enemies, is the proper codition onely of them, that be the children of God, the disciples and folowers of Christ.
column8: But to love our enemies, is the proper condition only of them, that be the children of God, the Disciples and followers of christ.

column7: Notwithstanding, mans frowarde and corrupte nature, wayeth ouer depely many times, the offence and displeasure done vnto hym by enemyes, and thynketh it a burden intollerable, to be bounde to loue them, that hate him.
column8: Notwithstanding, men forward and corrupt nature, wayeth over deeply many times, the offence and displeasure done unto him by enemies, and Thinketh it a burden intolerable, to be bound to love them, that hate him.

column7: But the burden shoulde be easye ynoughe, yf (on the other syde) euery man woulde consyder, what dyspleasure he hath done to hys enemy agayne,
column8: But the burden should be easy enough, if (on the other side) every man would Consider, what displeasure he hath done to his enemy again,

column7: & what pleasure he hathe receyued of hys enemye.
column8: & what pleasure he hath received of his enemy.

column7: And yf we fynde no egall recompence, neyther in receyuing pleasures of our enemy, nor in rendryng dyspleasure vnto hym agayne:
column8: And if we find no equal recompense, neither in receiving pleasures of our enemy, nor in rendering displeasure unto him again:

column7: then let vs ponder the displeasures, whyche we haue done agaynste almighty God:
column8: then let us ponder the displeasures, which we have done against almighty God:

column7: Howe often, and howe greuously, we haue offended hym.
column8: How often, and how grievously, we have offended him.

column7: Whereof, yf we wyll haue of God forgyuenes, there is none other remedye, but to forgyue the offeces done vnto vs, whyche be very small in comparison of oure offences done agaynste God.
column8: Whereof, if we will have of God forgiveness, there is none other remedy, but to forgive the offences done unto us, which be very small in comparison of our offences done against God.

column7: And yf we consyder that be, whych hath offended vs, deserueth not to be forgyuen of vs, let vs consyder againe, that we muche lesse deserue to be forgyuen of God.
column8: And if we Consider that be, which hath offended us, deserves not to be forgiven of us, let us Consider again, that we much less deserve to be forgiven of God.

column7: And althoughe our enemy deserue not to be forgyuen for hys owne sake, yet we oughte to forgyue hym, for gods loue, consyderynge howe great, and manyfest benefytes we haue receyued of hym, withoute oure desertes, and that Christe hathe deserued of vs, that for his sake, we should forgyue them their trespasses, commytted agaynst vs.
column8: And although our enemy deserve not to be forgiven for his own sake, yet we ought to forgive him, for God's love, considering how great, and manifest benefits we have received of him, without our deserts, and that Christ hath deserved of us, that for his sake, we should forgive them their Trespasses, committed against us

column7: But here may ryse a necessary question, to be dyssolued.
column8: But Here may rise a necessary question, to be dyssolued.

column7: If charity requyre to thinke, speake, and doo well vnto euery man, bothe good and euyl, how can magystrates execute iustyce vpon malefactours, with charitye?
column8: If charity require to think, speak, and do well unto every man, both good and evil, how can Magistrates execute Justice upon malefactors, with charity?

column7: Howe can they caste euyll men into prison, take away theyr goodes, and sometime their lyues, accordynge to lawes:
column8: Howe can they cast evil men into prison, take away their goods, and sometime their lives, according to laws:

column7: yf Charitye wyll not suffer them so to doo?
column8: if Charity will not suffer them so to do?

column7: Herevnto is a playne and brief answere, that plages and punishementes be not euel of themselues, yf they be well taken of innocentes:
column8: Hereunto is a plain and brief answer, that plagues and punishments be not evil of themselves, if they be well taken of innocentes:

column7: and to an euyll man, they are bothe good and necessarye:
column8: and to an evil man, they Are both good and necessary:

column7: and may be executed accordynge to charitie, and with charitye should be executed.
column8: and may be executed according to charity, and with charity should be executed.

column7: For declaracion whereof, you shall vnderstande, that charity hath two offices, the one contrarye to the other:
column8: For declaration whereof, you shall understand, that charity hath two Offices, the one contrary to the other:

column7: and yet bothe necessarye to be vsed, vpon men of contrarye sorte, and dysposition. The one office of Charitye, is, to cheryshe good, and innocent men.
column8: and yet both necessary to be used, upon men of contrary sort, and dysposition. The one office of Charity, is, to cherish good, and innocent men.

column7: Not to oppresse them, with false accusations, but to incourage them, wyth rewardes to doo well,
column8: Not to oppress them, with false accusations, but to encourage them, with rewards to do well,

column7: & perseuer in well dooynge:
column8: & persever in well doing:

column7: defendynge them wyth the sworde, fro theyr aduersaryes.
column8: defending them with the sword, from their Adversaries.

column7: And the offyce of Byshops, and pastours, is to laude good men, for wel doynge, that they maye perseuer therein, and to rebuke and correct, by the woorde of God, the offences, and crymes of all euyll disposed persons.
column8: And the office of Bishops, and Pastors, is to laud good men, for well doing, that they may persever therein, and to rebuke and correct, by the word of God, the offences, and crimes of all evil disposed Persons.

column7: The other office is, to rebuke, correcte,
column8: The other office is, to rebuke, correct,

column7: & punysh, vyce, without acceptation of parsons, and this is to be vsed, against theim onely, that be euyll men, and malefactours.
column8: & Punish, vice, without acceptation of parsons, and this is to be used, against them only, that be evil men, and malefactors.

column7: And it is aswell the offyce of charitye, to rebuke, punyshe, and correcte them, that be euyll, as it is to cheryshe, and rewarde them that be good, and innocent.
column8: And it is aswell the office of charity, to rebuke, Punish, and correct them, that be evil, as it is to cherish, and reward them that be good, and innocent.

column7: Sainct Paule soo declareth, writing to the Romaynes, and sayenge, the hyghe powers are ordeyned of GOD,
column8: Saint Paul so Declareth, writing to the Romans, and saying, the high Powers Are ordained of GOD,

column7: <NOTE> not to be dreadefull to them that doo well, but vnto malefactours, to drawe the swoorde, to take vengeaunce of hym that commytteth the synne.
column8: not to be dreadful to them that do well, but unto malefactors, to draw the sword, to take vengeance of him that Committeth the sin.

column7: And saincte Paule byddeth Tymothye constantlye,
column8: And saint Paul biddeth Timothy constantly,

column7: <NOTE> and vehementlye, to rebuke synne, by the woorde of GOD:
column8: and vehemently, to rebuke sin, by the word of GOD:

column7: So that bothe offyces shoulde be dylygently executed, to impugne the kyngdom of the deuyl:
column8: So that both Offices should be diligently executed, to impugn the Kingdom of the Devil:

column7: the preacher wyth the woorde, and the Gouernoure wyth the swoorde.
column8: the preacher with the word, and the Governor with the sword.

column7: Els they loue neyther God, nor them whome they gouerne, yf for lacke of correction, they wylfully suffer God to be offended, and them whom they gouerne to perishe.
column8: Else they love neither God, nor them whom they govern, if for lack of correction, they wilfully suffer God to be offended, and them whom they govern to perish.

column7: For as euery louynge father correcteth his natural sonne, when he dothe amysse, or els he loueth hym not:
column8: For as every loving father Correcteth his natural son, when he doth amiss, or Else he loves him not:

column7: So all gouernours of Realmes,
column8: So all Governors of Realms,

column7: Countreys, Townes, and houses, shoulde louynglye correcte them, who be offendours vnder theyr gouernaunce.
column8: Countries', Towns, and houses, should lovingly correct them, who be offenders under their governance.

column7: And cheryshe them who doo liue innocently:
column8: And cherish them who do live innocently:

column7: yf they haue any respecte, eyther vnto God, and theyr office, or loue vnto them, of whome they haue gouernauce.
column8: if they have any respect, either unto God, and their office, or love unto them, of whom they have governance.

column7: And suche rebukes, and punyshementes, of them that doo offende, muste be done in due tyme, least by delaye, the offender fall headlinges into all maner of myschiefe, and not onely bee euyll theimselues, but also doo hurte vnto many men, drawynge other by theyr euyll example, to synne,
column8: And such rebukes, and punishments, of them that do offend, must be done in due time, lest by Delay, the offender fallen headlinges into all manner of mischief, and not only be evil themselves, but also do hurt unto many men, drawing other by their evil Exampl, to sin,

column7: & outrage, after them. As one theef maye bothe robbe manye men, and also make many theues, and one sediciouse person may allure many, and noye a hole towne or countre.
column8: & outrage, After them. As one thief may both rob many men, and also make many thieves, and one seditious person may allure many, and noy a hold town or country.

column7: And suche euil persons, that be so great offenders of god, and the common wealth, charitie requireth to be cut of, from the body of the common weale, lest they corrupte other good, and honest persons:
column8: And such evil Persons, that be so great offenders of god, and the Common wealth, charity requires to be Cut of, from the body of the Common weal, lest they corrupt other good, and honest Persons:

column7: like as a good surgeon cutteth away a putrifyed, and festred member, for the loue he hath to ye hole body, least it infecte other members, adioynynge to it.
column8: like as a good surgeon cutteth away a Putrified, and festered member, for the love he hath to you hold body, lest it infect other members, adjoining to it.

column7: Thus it is declared vnto you, what true charitie, or christian loue is, so plainely, that no man nede to be deceyued.
column8: Thus it is declared unto you, what true charity, or christian love is, so plainly, that no man need to be deceived.

column7: Whyche loue whosoeuer kepeth, bothe towardes God (whom he is bounde to loue aboue al thinges) and also towardes hys neyghboure, aswell frende as fooe, it shal surely kepe hym fro all offence of God, and iuste offence of man.
column8: Which love whosoever Keepeth, both towards God (whom he is bound to love above all things) and also towards his neighbour, aswell friend as foe, it shall surely keep him from all offence of God, and just offence of man.

column7: Therefore beare wel away this one shorte lesson, that by true christian charitye,
column8: Therefore bear well away this one short Lesson, that by true christian charity,

column7: God oughte to be loued, aboue all thynges, and all men oughte to be loued, good and euyll, frende, and foo, and to al suche we ought (as we may) doo good:
column8: God ought to be loved, above all things, and all men ought to be loved, good and evil, friend, and foe, and to all such we ought (as we may) do good:

column7: those that be good, of loue we ought to encorage, and cherysh, bicause they be good:
column8: those that be good, of love we ought to encourage, and cherish, Because they be good:

column7: And those that be euil, of loue, we ought to procure vnto them theyr correction, and dewe punyshement, that they may therby, either be brought to goodnes, or at the lest, that god, and the common welthe maye be the lesse hurte, and offended, hating alwaies, the vyce, or offence, but louynge the person alwayes, as the creature of God, and as one who by nature is ioyned in kynred vnto vs.
column8: And those that be evil, of love, we ought to procure unto them their correction, and dew punishment, that they may thereby, either be brought to Goodness, or At the lest, that god, and the Common wealth may be the less hurt, and offended, hating always, the vice, or offence, but loving the person always, as the creature of God, and as one who by nature is joined in kindred unto us

column7: And yf we thus directe oure lyfe, by christian loue and Charitye, then Chryste doothe promyse, and assure vs, that he loueth vs, and that we be the Chyldren of our heauenlye father, and reconciled to his fauor, being very members of Christ, and that after the shorte tyme, of this presente and mortall lyfe, we shall haue with him, eternall lyfe, in his euerlastyng kingdome of heauen:
column8: And if we thus Direct our life, by christian love and Charity, then Christ doth promise, and assure us, that he loves us, and that we be the Children of our heavenly father, and reconciled to his favour, being very members of christ, and that After the short time, of this present and Mortal life, we shall have with him, Eternal life, in his everlasting Kingdom of heaven:

column7: Therfore to hym, with the father, and the holy Ghost, be al honor and glorye, nowe & euer Amen.
column8: Therefore to him, with the father, and the holy Ghost, be all honour and glory, now & ever Amen.

column7: E. B.
column8: E. B.

column7: An Homely declaryng howe daungerous a thynge, the breache of Charitye is
column8: an Homely declaring how dangerous a thing, the breach of Charity is

column7: O Vr Sauiour Christ in ye.v. of Mathew, setteth forth an vniuersal doctrine,
column8: Our Our Saviour christ in the v of Matthew, sets forth an universal Doctrine,

column7: <NOTE> that is, a doctrine, apperteyning indifferently to al Christen me, and there he declareth, how great perfection of lyfe, ought to be in one of vs, sayinge in this maner.
column8: that is, a Doctrine, aPPERTAINING indifferently to all christian me, and there he Declareth, how great perfection of life, ought to be in one of us, saying in this manner.

column7: Nisi abundauerit iustitia uestra plus quam Scribarum,
column8: Nisi abundaverit iustitia uestra plus quam Scribes,

column7: & Pharisaeorum, non intrabitis in regnum coelorum.
column8: & Pharisees, non intrabitis in Kingdom Coelorum.

column7: That is to saye: Except your rightuousnes excede the rightuousnes of the Scribes,
column8: That is to say: Except your righteousness exceed the righteousness of the Scribes,

column7: & the Phariseis, ye cannot entre into the kyngedome of heaue.
column8: & the Pharisees, you cannot enter into the Kingdom of heave.

column7: For the ryght vnderstandynge of whiche wordes, it is to be noted, that rightuousnes in this texte, doth signifye all kynde of vertue, and goodnes, and that by the Scribes, and Phariseis,
column8: For the right understanding of which words, it is to be noted, that righteousness in this text, does signify all kind of virtue, and Goodness, and that by the Scribes, and Pharisees,

column7: Christe doth here meane, certayne companies, whiche were amonge the Iewes, and dyd lyue accordynge to the letter of Moyses lawe, so vpryghtly, in the face of the world, that they were commenly taken for parfyt men.
column8: Christ does Here mean, certain companies, which were among the Jews, and did live according to the Letter of Moses law, so vpryghtly, in the face of the world, that they were commonly taken for parfyt men.

column7: Oecumenius, <NOTE> an auncient father of ye greke churche, doth so declare the foresayde wordes.
column8: Oecumenius, an ancient father of you greek Church, does so declare the foresaid words.

column7: Wherefore, when our sauioure requireth of vs, that we, in rightuousnes,
column8: Wherefore, when our Saviour requires of us, that we, in righteousness,

column7: shoulde passe the Scribes and Phariseis, he meaneth, that we Christen folke shoulde not onely outwardely, seme good in the sight of the worlde, (as did the Scribes,
column8: should pass the Scribes and Pharisees, he means, that we christian folk should not only outwardly, seem good in the sighed of the world, (as did the Scribes,

column7: & the Phariseis,) but inwardlye also in our hartes, shoulde be lykewyse good, in the syght of almyghtye God, whiche they were not.
column8: & the Pharisees,) but inwardly also in our hearts, should be likewise good, in the sight of almighty God, which they were not.

column7: And because no faute is more greuouse, then the breache of Christen Loue, and Charitie, therefore immediately after the foresayde generall sentence, he instructeth vs, afore all other thinges, in our dutye, touchinge Charitie, sayinge:
column8: And Because no fault is more grievous, then the breach of christian Love, and Charity, Therefore immediately After the foresaid general sentence, he Instructeth us, afore all other things, in our duty, touching Charity, saying:

column7: Dictum est antiquis, non occides, qui autem occiderit, reas erit iudicii,
column8: Dictum est antiquis, non occides, qui autem occiderit, reas erit Judges,

column7: Ego autem dico nobis, quia omnis qui irascitur fratrisuo, reus erit iudicio.
column8: Ego autem dico nobis, quia omnis qui irascitur fratrisuo, Rhesus erit Judicio.

column7: That is to saye: It was sayde to them of olde tyme,
column8: That is to say: It was said to them of old time,

column7: Thou shalte not sleye whosoeuer doth sley, shalbe in daunger of iudgemet.
column8: Thou shalt not slay whosoever does slay, shall in danger of Judgement.

column7: But I saye vnto you, that whosoeuer is angry with his brother, shalbe in daunger of iudgement.
column8: But I say unto you, that whosoever is angry with his brother, shall in danger of judgement.

column7: Behold, good Christe people, how perfit a charitie Christ requireth in vs.
column8: Behold, good Christ people, how perfect a charity christ requires in us

column7: For to vs he maketh the leaste breache of Charitie, as daungerous, as in olde tyme, was the greatest breache to the Iewes.
column8: For to us he makes the jest breach of Charity, as dangerous, as in old time, was the greatest breach to the Jews.

column7: The greateste breache of Charitie, is murdre, and the punyshmente thereof amongest the Iewes, was iudgemente.
column8: The greatest breach of Charity, is murder, and the punishment thereof amongst the Jews, was judgement.

column7: The leaste breache of Charitie, is anger, and yet the punyshmet appoynted for it to vs Christians, by oure sauyoure hym selfe, is lykewyse iudgement.
column8: The jest breach of Charity, is anger, and yet the punyshmet appointed for it to us Christians, by our Saviour him self, is likewise judgement.

column7: Howe greate difference of lyfe then,
column8: Howe great difference of life then,

column7: I pray you, must be betwene vs, nowe lyuynge vnder the newe lawe, and them that of olde tyme, lyued vnder the olde lawe, that is vnder ye lawe of Moyses, when as, the selfe same paine that was then prescrybed vnto them, for the hyghest degre of vncharitablenesse, is nowe dewe to vs, for the lowest degre therof?
column8: I pray you, must be between us, now living under the new law, and them that of old time, lived under the old law, that is under the law of Moses, when as, the self same pain that was then prescribed unto them, for the highest degree of uncharitableness, is now dew to us, for the lowest degree thereof?

column7: Howe is it that men flatter themselues, wyth the pleasaunte name of Christian libertye, and thinke that, because Christ saieth in the xi. of Mathew.
column8: Howe is it that men flatter themselves, with the pleasant name of Christian liberty, and think that, Because christ Saith in the xi. of Matthew.

column7: Iugum meum suaue est, et onus meum leue.
column8: Yoke meum suave est, et onus meum leave.

column7: That is to saye. My yoke is swete, and my burden lyghte, that therefore suche streytnes of lyfe, and paynefull trauell is not requyred of vs, as was before tyme of the Iewes?
column8: That is to say. My yoke is sweet, and my burden Light, that Therefore such streytnes of life, and painful travel is not required of us, as was before time of the Jews?

column7: True it is in dede, that Christen men are not at thys presente, bounde to be cyrcumcysed, or to offer vp vnto almyghtye GOD, calues, oxen, shepe, and Gotes, or to goo thryse a yeare to Ierusalem, or to forbeare swynes fleshe, or to kepe other lyke obseruations of Moyses lawe, but as touchynge the tenne commaundementes, and all morall Preceptes contained in the olde testamente, we Christians are bounde to the obseruation of them,
column8: True it is in deed, that christian men Are not At this present, bound to be cyrcumcysed, or to offer up unto almighty GOD, calves, oxen, sheep, and Goats, or to goo thrice a year to Jerusalem, or to forbear Swine Flesh, or to keep other like observations of Moses law, but as touching the tenne Commandments, and all moral Precepts contained in the old Testament, we Christians Are bound to the observation of them,

column7: & of all other thynges, belongyng to the estate of the new testamente, and so bounde, as that in perfourmance, and fulfyllynge of them, we muste be muche more perfyt, and more exacte, then euer was the Iewes in obeyng Moyses lawe.
column8: & of all other things, belonging to the estate of the new Testament, and so bound, as that in performance, and fulfilling of them, we must be much more perfect, and more exact, then ever was the Jews in obeyng Moses law.

column7: Nether is the yoke of Christe called swete, nor his burden lyghte, for anye ease or remission, that we maye take in oure condition, but for two other consyderations, of whiche the one is, the abundance of grace, gyuen nowe in the tyme of the newe testamente, farre excedynge, the measure of grace gyuen to the Iewes, folowynge Moyses lawe:
column8: Neither is the yoke of Christ called sweet, nor his burden Light, for any ease or remission, that we may take in our condition, but for two other considerations, of which the one is, the abundance of grace, given now in the time of the new Testament, Far exceeding, the measure of grace given to the Jews, following Moses law:

column7: the other is, the greatnes of rewarde, promysed to vs, aboue the Iewes, as wytnesseth amonge manye other aunciente fathers,
column8: the other is, the greatness of reward, promised to us, above the Jews, as Witnesseth among many other ancient Father's,

column7: Oecumenius also, <NOTE> who wrytynge vpon the v. of Mathew, sayeth after this sorte.
column8: Oecumenius also, who writing upon the v. of Matthew, Saith After this sort.

column7: Quoniam infantia in virilem iam transierit etatem, et copiosa hominibus data sit gratia, et maxima proposita sunt premia (neque enim iam possessio terrae terrenorum, quam bonorum, aut prolis faecunditas aut longa vita, seu victoria contrahostes promittitur, sed regnum caeloru, adoptio et victoria contra daemones) merito magna exiguntur certamina.
column8: Quoniam infancy in virilem iam transierit etatem, et Copiosa hominibus data sit Gratia, et maxima proposita sunt premia (neque enim iam possessio terrae terrenorum, quam Bonorum, Or prolis faecunditas Or Longam vita, seu victoria contrahostes promittitur, sed Kingdom caeloru, Adoption et victoria contra daemons) merito Magna exiguntur certamina.

column7: That is to saye. Forasmuche as nowe, infancy is passed into mans age, and grace is plenteouslye giuen to men, and mooste greatest rewardes are promysed (for now nether possession of earth, and earthlye gooddes, nor longe lyfe, nor fecundite of chyldren, nor victory agaynste oure mortall enemyes, is promised, but the kyngdome of heauen, adoptio to God, and victory against deuels) therefore of good reason, great fyghtes are requyred of vs.
column8: That is to say. Forasmuch as now, infancy is passed into men age, and grace is plenteously given to men, and most greatest rewards Are promised (for now neither possession of earth, and earthly God's, nor long life, nor fecundite of children, nor victory against our Mortal enemies, is promised, but the Kingdom of heaven, Adoption to God, and victory against Devils) Therefore of good reason, great fights Are required of us

column7: Thus sayth Oecumenius, concludynge that we christen men must more painfully, and manfully, fyght agaynst oure ghostly enemye, then dyd the Iewes, bycause we receaue more grace then they receaued, and haue promise made to vs of greater rewardes, the they had made to them.
column8: Thus say Oecumenius, concluding that we christen men must more painfully, and manfully, fight against our ghostly enemy, then did the Jews, Because we receive more grace then they received, and have promise made to us of greater rewards, the they had made to them.

column7: For these two causes, we christen men muste thynke the yoke of Christe, swete, and hys burden easye, be the thynges which are requyred of vs, neuer so hard to doo, as this is one, that we may not breake charitie, so muche as in the lowest degree that can be, that is in anger:
column8: For these two Causes, we christen men must think the yoke of Christ, sweet, and his burden easy, be the things which Are required of us, never so hard to do, as this is one, that we may not break charity, so much as in the lowest degree that can be, that is in anger:

column7: whych woord, in the foresaid place of Mathew, dothe sygnify, a violation, or breache of charitye, not vttered or shewed forth by any sygne, but onely conceaued secretlye in the harte, and there lyenge hyd, from knowledge of man, but open, and manyfest to the eye of almyghty God, who seyth eue the inwarde thoughtes of the harte:
column8: which word, in the foresaid place of Matthew, doth sygnify, a violation, or breach of charity, not uttered or showed forth by any Signen, but only conceived secretly in the heart, and there lying hid, from knowledge of man, but open, and manifest to the eye of almighty God, who Saith eve the inward thoughts of the heart:

column7: thys breache of charitye, thoughe it feme to many a smale faute, yet Christe declareth it to be a greuouse faute, and maketh it in the payne, equall with murder, committed of olde tyme by the Iewes.
column8: this breach of charity, though it feme to many a small fault, yet Christ Declareth it to be a grievous fault, and makes it in the pain, equal with murder, committed of old time by the Jews.

column7: Nowe yf Christen men, hauynge conceyued anger in theyr hartes, do not by and by suppresse the same, but proceade to a fardar breache of charitie, that is, to vtter theyr anger by any signe or token, than is this ther faut greater then the other, and the punyshemente due for the same, greater also, accordynge to the woordes of Christe, who in the.v.
column8: Now if christian men, having conceived anger in their hearts, do not by and by suppress the same, but proceed to a fardar breach of charity, that is, to utter their anger by any Signen or token, than is this there fault greater then the other, and the punishment due for the same, greater also, according to the words of Christ, who in the v

column7: <NOTE> of Mathew saieth.
column8: of Matthew Saith.

column7: Qui aute dixerit Racha, reus erit concilio, (that is to saye.
column8: Qui aute dixerit Racha, Rhesus erit Concilio, (that is to say.

column7: He that saieth to hys brother Racha, shalbe in daunger of counsel.
column8: He that Saith to his brother Racha, shall in danger of counsel.

column7: Where, by Racha, we muste vnderstande an outewarde sygne, vttered by the mouth wyth breache of charitye, and yet suche a sygne as dothe sygnifye, no expresse or particular reproche as, to thou our brother, or to tushe at hym.
column8: Where, by Racha, we must understand an outward Signen, uttered by the Mouth with breach of charity, and yet such a Signen as doth sygnifye, no express or particular reproach as, to thou our brother, or to tush At him.

column7: And by councel we muste vnderstand a greater punyshement, then was iudgement.
column8: And by council we must understand a greater punishment, then was judgement.

column7: After this our sauiour procedeth to the thyrd degree of vncharitablenesse, which is in woorde to call our neyghboure, by any euyll name, as to call hym foole.
column8: After this our Saviour Proceedeth to the Third degree of uncharitableness, which is in word to call our neighbour, by any evil name, as to call him fool.

column7: Of this thyrde degre, Christ sayeth.
column8: Of this Third degree, christ Saith.

column7: Qui autem dixerit fratri suo fatue,
column8: Qui autem dixerit fratri Sue fatue,

column7: reus erit gehennae ignis, that is to saye.
column8: Rhesus erit Gehenna ignis, that is to say.

column7: He that calleth his brother foole, shalbe in daunger of hell fyre.
column8: He that calls his brother fool, shall in danger of hell fire.

column7: Beholde Chrystian people, your lyfe in thys lesson, as in a glasse, and you shall see what daunger you stande in.
column8: Behold Christian people, your life in this Lesson, as in a glass, and you shall see what danger you stand in.

column7: Who is there almoost emongest vs, but yt vncharitably calleth his neighbour foole, or som like euyl name?
column8: Who is there almost amongst us, but that uncharitably calls his neighbour fool, or Some like evil name?

column7: yea who is there in maner that doth not far passe thys degree of vncharitablenes?
column8: yea who is there in manner that does not Far pass this degree of uncharitableness?

column7: And yet our sauiour nameth no mo degrees, partely, bicause the paine of this thyrde degree beinge hell fyre, no greater paine coulde be named, for suche as shoulde passe the same degree:
column8: And yet our Saviour names no more Degrees, partly, Because the pain of this Third degree being hell fire, no greater pain could be nam, for such as should pass the same degree:

column7: partly, bycause the Chrystyan man should at the least be soo wary,
column8: partly, Because the Christian man should At the least be so wary,

column7: & circumspecte, in kepyng of brotherly loue, and charitie, yt thoughe he dyd, perchaunce so farre forgette hymselfe, as to call his brother foole vncharitably, yet fardar than so, he should not so much as thinke, throughout his whole lyfe.
column8: & circumspect, in keeping of brotherly love, and charity, that though he did, perchance so Far forget himself, as to call his brother fool uncharitably, yet fardar than so, he should not so much as think, throughout his Whole life.

column7: It is written of one Solon an infidell,
column8: It is written of one Solon an infidel,

column7: <NOTE> but yet a very politike man, howe when he made lawes for the gouerment of ye famous citie of Athes, he in all his lawes, appoynted no punyshment for a parricide, that is for such a one, as shoulde kyll hys father or mother:
column8: but yet a very politic man, how when he made laws for the government of the famous City of Atheists, he in all his laws, appointed no punishment for a Parricide, that is for such a one, as should kill his father or mother:

column7: and when he was demaunded, why he prouided not for that case, he aunswered, yt he veryly, thought and beleued, that no one beynge broughte vp in Athens, vnder hys lawes, wolde at anye tyme attempte suche an heynous synne.
column8: and when he was demanded, why he provided not for that case, he answered, that he verily, Thought and believed, that no one being brought up in Athens, under his laws, would At any time attempt such an heinous sin.

column7: Euen so may we say of our sauiour, that he speaketh but of those foresayd three degrees of vncharitablenes, for that it is not lykely, christen men, being traded in Chrystes most parfyt religion, woulde at anye tyme procede in the violatyng of charitie, fardar then so.
column8: Eve so may we say of our Saviour, that he speaks but of those foresayd three Degrees of uncharitableness, for that it is not likely, christen men, being traded in Christ's most parfyt Religion, would At any time proceed in the violating of charity, fardar then so.

column7: But here may be moued a question whether our sauiour hath so forbydden vs to be angry, to saye Racha, or thou foole, one to an other, that in no wise any man may so doo, but thereby he falleth in daunger of iudgement, of councell, or of hel fyre.
column8: But Here may be moved a question whither our Saviour hath so forbidden us to be angry, to say Racha, or thou fool, one to an other, that in no wise any man may so do, but thereby he falls in danger of judgement, of council, or of hell fire.

column7: For aunswer to thys question, it is to be noted, that our sauiour in thys place, forbiddeth vs all kynde of vncharitablenes, and nothyng els.
column8: For answer to this question, it is to be noted, that our Saviour in this place, forbiddeth us all kind of uncharitableness, and nothing Else.

column7: Forasmuch then, as in ye third of Mathewe.
column8: Forasmuch then, as in you third of Matthew.

column7: <NOTE> S. Ihon Baptist calleth the scrybes and pharisies, adders brode, and S.
column8: S. John Baptist calls the Scribes and Pharisees, Adders broad, and S.

column7: Paule calleth the Galathians fooles,
column8: Paul calls the Galatians Fools,

column7: <NOTE> and men without vnderstading, in the second chapiter of his epistle wrytten to them:
column8: and men without understanding, in the second chapter of his epistle written to them:

column7: <NOTE> yea Chryst himselfe in the.xxiiii. of Luke calleth his dere beloued apostles, fooles, and sloo of belefe, and the thyng which they dyd, cannot be iudged vncharitable, therefore we must saye, that when such as haue aucthoritie, vpon a good and Godlye zeale, rebuke trespassours, and offenders, thereby to make them ashamed of there euyl doynges, and the rather to leaue the same, that thys kynd of rebuking is laweful, and in no wise ment in the foresaid talke of Chryst.
column8: yea Christ himself in the xxiiii of Luke calls his dear Beloved Apostles, Fools, and sloo of belief, and the thing which they did, cannot be judged uncharitable, Therefore we must say, that when such as have Authority, upon a good and Godly zeal, rebuke trespassers, and offenders, thereby to make them ashamed of there evil doings, and the rather to leave the same, that this kind of rebuking is lawful, and in no wise meant in the foresaid talk of Christ

column7: But the onely thing that is there forbydden, is the breache of charitie, when one man meaneth no good at all, to an other, but for the onelye satisfyeng of his vncharitable harte, wysheth hym hurte in his harte, or vtteryng his secret vncharitable mynde, doth thou hym, or tushe at hym, or finally speaketh contumelious wordes, expresly vnto hym, callyng him, foole, idiot or by other lyke opprobrious names:
column8: But the only thing that is there forbidden, is the breach of charity, when one man means no good At all, to an other, but for the only satisfying of his uncharitable heart, wisheth him hurt in his heart, or uttering his secret uncharitable mind, does thou him, or tush At him, or finally speaks contumelious words, expressly unto him, calling him, fool, idiot or by other like opprobrious names:

column7: Wherefore to conclude, seinge you nowe know what parfytte loue and charitie, our sauiour Chryst doth requyre to be in vs, lette all accustomed rancor and malyce from henceforthe be vtterlye banyshed from emongest vs, that we dwellyng in charitie, may dwel in God, and haue here in this lyfe,
column8: Wherefore to conclude, sing you now know what parfytte love and charity, our Saviour Christ does require to be in us, let all accustomed rancour and malice from henceforth be utterly banished from amongst us, that we Dwelling in charity, may dwell in God, and have Here in this life,

column7: GOD dwell in vs, and in the worlde to come, dwell in heauen with hym for euer, which graunte vnto vs, the blessed trinitie, the father, the sonne, and the holye Ghost, to whome be all honor and glory world without ende.
column8: GOD dwell in us, and in the world to come, dwell in heaven with him for ever, which grant unto us, the blessed trinity, the father, the son, and the holy Ghost, to whom be all honour and glory world without end.

column7: Amen Io. Harpesfelde, sacrae theologiae professor.
column8: Amen Io. Harpesfelde, Sacrae Theologiae professor.

column8: Arch. London,

column7: An Homelie of the church, what it is, and of the commoditie thereof.
column8: an Homely of the Church, what it is, and of the commodity thereof.

column7: W Hosoeuer (good people) wyll call to hys remembrauce, ye inestimable goodnes of almightye God, and his inestimable mercye, towardes vs nothing deseruing the same:
column8: Whosoever Whosoever (good people) will call to his remembrance, you inestimable Goodness of almighty God, and his inestimable mercy, towards us nothing deserving the same:

column7: yf ther be any spotte of heuenly grace, in that person, he shall be ashamed of hys owne vnthankefulnes, and disobediens, and be compelled to fal downe in body, and soule, before our Lorde, to aske pardon for his transgression.
column8: if there be any spot of heavenly grace, in that person, he shall be ashamed of his own unthankfulness, and disobedient, and be compelled to fall down in body, and soul, before our Lord, to ask pardon for his Transgression.

column7: Of the which goodnes, and mercy of God, you haue a sufficiente, and moost euident declaration, in these godly, and deuoute homelies, that are set fourth to you, of the creation, and redemption of ma:
column8: Of the which Goodness, and mercy of God, you have a sufficient, and most evident declaration, in these godly, and devout Homilies, that Are Set fourth to you, of the creation, and redemption of ma:

column7: Neuerthelesse, for your further instruction,
column8: Nevertheless, for your further instruction,

column7: & ghostlye comforte in this behalfe,
column8: & ghostly Comfort in this behalf,

column7: I haue thought good to lette you vnderstande, an other hye benefyte, geuen to vs, by our sauioure, and redemer,
column8: I have Thought good to let you understand, an other high benefit, given to us, by our Saviour, and redeemer,

column7: Iesus Chryste, that we, hauynge perfyt knowledge of God, maye euermore prayse, and magnifye hym, accordynge to our moost bounden duetye.
column8: jesus Christ, that we, having perfect knowledge of God, may evermore praise, and magnify him, according to our most bounden duty.

column7: And this hye, and heauenlye benefyte, is the holye catholyke churche, whiche our deare, and dreadfull Sauyour, both before,
column8: And this high, and heavenly benefit, is the holy catholic Church, which our deer, and dreadful Saviour, both before,

column7: and after his paynefull death, dyd ordeyne, and appoynt, to be for euer to vs, a moost louynge,
column8: and After his painful death, did ordain, and appoint, to be for ever to us, a most loving,

column7: & tender mother, a perpetual preseruation for our soule helth, and a pyllar of truth, in al oure doubtfull daungers.
column8: & tender mother, a perpetual preservation for our soul health, and a pyllar of truth, in all our doubtful dangers.

column7: Whiche churche, forsomuche as it hath bene latelye assaulted, by sundry sectes, and heresies, and so sore shaken, that many (more is the pytie) hath separate them selues from the same, and wylfully haue runne a straye, beynge ledde, and caried with euery waue, and wynde of newe lernynge,
column8: Which Church, forsomuch as it hath be lately assaulted, by sundry Sects, and heresies, and so soar shaken, that many (more is the pity) hath separate them selves from the same, and wilfully have run a stray, being led, and carried with every wave, and wind of new learning,

column7: I purpose, by Gods grace, to open shortely to you, what this churche is,
column8: I purpose, by God's grace, to open shortly to you, what this Church is,

column7: <NOTE> maner of churche it is, and what commoditie we haue by it.
column8: manner of Church it is, and what commodity we have by it.

column7: Fyrst, the churche is a conuocation of all people throughout the whole worlde, professynge one fayth of God, and one vse of all the holy sacramentes:
column8: Fyrst, the Church is a convocation of all people throughout the Whole world, professing one faith of God, and one use of all the holy Sacraments:

column7: whiche churche, because it is purchased, and sanctified, by the death of oure Sauyoure Iesus Christe, it is moost derely beloued to God the father, and is called in holy Scripture, by most hie, and excellent names, as Corpus Christi Sponsa Christi,
column8: which Church, Because it is purchased, and sanctified, by the death of our Saviour jesus Christ, it is most dearly Beloved to God the father, and is called in holy Scripture, by most high, and excellent names, as Corpus Christ Sponsa Christ,

column8: Kingdom Coelorum. etc. that is to say:

column8: The body mystical of Christ, the spouse of Christ, the Kingdom of heaven.

column8: For S. Paul, speaking of Christ, faith:

column7: That he hath appoynted sundry officers, to maintayne the holy ones, into the worke of ministration, to the edifieng of the body of Christ.
column8: That he hath appointed sundry Officers, to maintain the holy ones, into the work of ministration, to the edifying of the body of christ.

column7: And kynge Salomon, taught by the holy ghost, did forsee the dignitie, and beutye of this holye churche, and sayde in the name of GOD therebye.
column8: And King Solomon, taught by the holy ghost, did foresee the dignity, and beauty of this holy Church, and said in the name of GOD thereby.

column8: Una est Columbam mea, perfecta mea.

column8: With many other such loving words:

column8: And saint Paul biddeth Husbands to love there wives,

column8: even as Christ loved the Church,

column7: Lykewyse in the holy Gospell, our sauiour Chryste, doth compare the churche, to sondry thynges, vnder the name of the kyngdome of heaue,
column8: Likewise in the holy Gospel, our Saviour Christ, does compare the Church, to sundry things, under the name of the Kingdom of heave,

column7: <NOTE> as vnto a king, which made a maryage for his sonne:
column8: as unto a King, which made a marriage for his son:

column8: sometimes to tenne Virgins, and many such other:

column7: by al which names, and callyngs, we may lerne that the churche is a high and excellent thing, and dearely beloued to almyghty God, who for hys churche sake, dyd giue hys onely sonne, to most vyle death, and for ye which also he hath prepared the kyngdome of heauen.
column8: by all which names, and callings, we may Learn that the Church is a high and excellent thing, and dearly Beloved to almighty God, who for his Church sake, did give his only son, to most vile death, and for you which also he hath prepared the Kingdom of heaven.

column7: Nowe, forasmuche as we rede of an other churche in the holy scrypture, which is called Ecclesia malignantium,
column8: Now, forasmuch as we rede of an other Church in the holy scripture, which is called Ecclesia Malignants,

column7: The churche of the malingnant & noughtye people.
column8: The Church of the malingnant & naughty people.

column7: And yet of late, a great number of scismaticall persones, being in verye dede members of thys malygnant churche, haue vsurped to the selues the name of the true churche:
column8: And yet of late, a great number of scismaticall Persons, being in very deed members of this malygnant Church, have usurped to the selves the name of the true Church:

column7: I intende to gyue you sufficient instruction, to dyscerne and know the true churche of Chryst, from all hereticall and scysmaticall congregations.
column8: I intend to gyve you sufficient instruction, to discern and know the true Church of Christ, from all heretical and scysmaticall congregations.

column7: Fyrst this holye and true churche of Chryst, is called in our Crede, as it is in dede, the catholyke churche.
column8: Fyrst this holy and true Church of Christ, is called in our Crede, as it is in deed, the catholic Church.

column7: That is to saye, the vniuersal church, bycause it is not lurkyng in anye corner, or any one country, but is in all countryes dyspersed:
column8: That is to say, the universal Church, Because it is not lurking in any corner, or any one country, but is in all countries dispersed:

column7: neyther is thys catholyke churche, hid from vs, or inuisible, or vnknowen:
column8: neither is this catholic Church, hid from us, or invisible, or unknown:

column7: but we may easely dyscerne, and know the same.
column8: but we may Easily discern, and know the same.

column8: For Christ does call it,

column8: O Lord, how shall he tell you Church, if it be not known, as the evil do contend Likewise Saint Paul speaking, to the preystes, and Elders At Ephesus,

column7: <NOTE> doth warne the to take hede to them selues, and to al the flocke, amonge whome the holy ghost (sayth he) hath placed you to rule the churche of God.

column7: Thus playnely the scrypture declareth that the catholyke churche, is and oughte to be, manyfestly knowen, yet lest you should anye thynge doute of the vnderstandynge of these scryptures, heare I besech you, howe playnely,
column8: Thus plainly the scripture Declareth that the catholic Church, is and ought to be, manifestly known, yet lest you should any thing doubt of the understanding of these Scriptures, hear I beseech you, how plainly,

column7: Saynt Augustyne, doth wryte hereof.
column8: Saint Augustine, does write hereof.

column7: Sicut per uerba dei nouimus, ubi sit platatus paradisus:

column7: sic per uerba Christi, ubi sit ecclesia, didicimus. As by the woordes of God we know wher paradyse was planted, so by the woordes of Chryst, we haue learned, where the churche is.
column8: sic per uerba Christ, ubi sit Church, didicimus. As by the words of God we know where paradise was planted, so by the words of Christ, we have learned, where the Church is.

column7: Marke here (good people) that Saynt Austen, in thys place, doth write, agaynst an heretike, being one of the donatyste secte:
column8: Mark Here (good people) that Saint Austen, in this place, does write, against an heretic, being one of the donatyste sect:

column7: who denying the catholyke churche, dyd ascrybe the fayth, of chryst, and al saluation, to them selues onely, being a smale parte of Aphrica, lyke as all scismatical congregations, in thys late tyme, haue done:
column8: who denying the catholic Church, did ascribe the faith, of Christ, and all salvation, to them selves only, being a small part of Africa, like as all Schismatical congregations, in this late time, have done:
