column8: and we in England, Here is Christ, and Here is the Church.

column7: Wherof euery one dyssentyng, from an other, and that in maters of great weyght, doth declare, that the spyryte of God, which is the spirite of truth, and vnitie, promysed by Christ, to the catholyke churche, dothe not leade nor gouerne suche sectes:
column8: Whereof every one dyssentyng, from an other, and that in maters of great weight, does declare, that the Spirit of God, which is the Spirit of truth, and unity, promised by christ, to the catholic Church, doth not lead nor govern such Sects:

column7: neyther oughte they to mayntayne, and set furth, false doctryne, to the people, vnder the name of the churche, yet sainte Austen in ye same place, addyth hys, or rather gods threatnyng,
column8: neither ought they to maintain, and Set forth, false Doctrine, to the people, under the name of the Church, yet Saint Austen in you same place, addyth his, or rather God's threatening,

column8: saying, Ab isto uniuerso, ad partem, quamlibet, quisquis separate hominem, Isle Diaboli filius,

column8: & Homicide conuincitur. Whosoever does separate one man, from this Whole, to any part:

column8: he is proved to be the son of the Devil, and a very manqueller.

column8: Alas than in what heavy case, Are those, that have separate from the catholic Church, not one man only, but many thousandes?

column8: surely in heavy and miserable case:

column7: Moreouer to knowe more manyfestly, the catholyke churche, of Chryst, we ought to consider what Saynte Paule wryteth, of the foundation thereof.
column8: Moreover to know more manifestly, the catholic Church, of Christ, we ought to Consider what Faint Paul writes, of the Foundation thereof.

column7: For al scismatycall congregations, though they grounde them selues, apparantly, vpon the holye scrypture, yet haue they there profession, seuerally, taken, of some noughty man, as saynt Augustyne sayth They are called euery one by proper names,
column8: For all scismatycall congregations, though they ground them selves, apparently, upon the holy scripture, yet have they there profession, severally, taken, of Some naughty man, as saint Augustine say They Are called every one by proper names,

column8: But the catholic Church though Heretics have nam it papysticall, yet received it never any other name, but catholic, and christian:

column8: As long as there is among you, envying and strife, or Sects, Are you not carnal?

column8: So that every christen man, and woman, may plainly see by the scripture, that these having such division, and sundry Sects among them selves, Are by S.

column7: Paule, accompted altogether carnal, and farre vnworthy to vse the name of the churche, whiche is the onely, and chaste spouse, of Christ.
column8: Paul, accounted altogether carnal, and Far unworthy to use the name of the Church, which is the only, and chaste spouse, of christ.

column7: <NOTE> But of the catholyke churche, saynt Paule sayth:
column8: But of the catholic Church, saint Paul say:

column7: Now therfore, ye are not straugers, and foreyners:
column8: Now Therefore, you Are not straugers, and foreigners:

column7: but you are citisens with the saynctes, and of the housholde of God, and are buylded vpon the foundation of the Apostles,
column8: but you Are Citizens with the Saints, and of the household of God, and Are builded upon the Foundation of the Apostles,

column7: & prophetes, Iesus Chryst hym selfe being the heade corner stone.
column8: & Prophets, jesus Christ him self being the head corner stone.

column7: And further, bycause saynt Paule throughe the holy Ghost in him, dyd forsee, that all heretykes would callenge to them selfes the aucthoritie of the Apostles,
column8: And further, Because saint Paul through the holy Ghost in him, did foresee, that all Heretics would challenge to them selves the Authority of the Apostles,

column7: & prophetes, and that they wold with out authoritie or knowlege, wraste theyr writinges, euery one to there owne sense:
column8: & Prophets, and that they would with out Authority or knowledge, wraste their writings, every one to there own sense:

column7: therefore this holy apostle, <NOTE> in the same epystle, tellyth vs the order whych Chryst hath apoynted to be obserued in hys church:
column8: Therefore this holy apostle, in the same epistle, Telleth us the order which Christ hath appointed to be observed in his Church:

column7: for he sayth, that Chryst ascending into heauen, dyd gyue gyftes to men, and that he made some apostles, some prophetes, some Euangelystes, some shepardes, and teachers, declarynge thereby, that in the catholyke churche, there are orders, and offycers, some hyer, some lower, whom the rest ought both diligently to heare, and humbly to obey.
column8: for he say, that Christ ascending into heaven, did gyve Gifts to men, and that he made Some Apostles, Some Prophets, Some Evangelists, Some shepherds, and Teachers, declaring thereby, that in the catholic Church, there Are order, and Officers, Some higher, Some lower, whom the rest ought both diligently to hear, and humbly to obey.

column7: So dyd the same S. Paul, <NOTE> before hys death, apoint Timothe, to the offyce of a Byshoppe, and also Tite he dyd leaue in Creta, that he shoulde ordeyne prestes in euery citie, whiche preistes, and Byshoppes should not be dysdained, or litle regarded (as in this tyme of manye they are) but they shoulde (dooyng there duetie) haue double honoure, and faythfully gouerne the church,
column8: So did the same S. Paul, before his death, appoint Timothy, to the office of a Bishop, and also Tite he did leave in Crete, that he should ordain Priests in every City, which Priests, and Bishops should not be dysdained, or little regarded (as in this time of many they Are) but they should (doing there duty) have double honour, and faithfully govern the Church,

column7: <NOTE> as saint Paule sayeth.
column8: as saint Paul Saith.

column7: And writyng to Tite, he byddeth him exhort, and rebuke, with al feruentnes of commaudyng, by these places of the holy scrypture, you may easely see, and vnderstand:
column8: And writing to Tite, he biddeth him exhort, and rebuke, with all feruentnes of commaudyng, by these places of the holy scripture, you may Easily see, and understand:

column7: that in the catholyke churche, there are and ought to be degres and orders, and that whosoeuer doth breake, contemne, or deny the same, he denieth and forsaketh the verye truth, and ordinaunce of Chryste, and his Apostles.
column8: that in the catholic Church, there Are and ought to be Degrees and order, and that whosoever does break, contemn, or deny the same, he Denieth and Forsaketh the very truth, and Ordinance of Christ, and his Apostles.

column7: Nowe further, we oughte to consider, that as S.
column8: Now further, we ought to Consider, that as S.

column7: Paule dyd ordeyne Timothe, and Tyte, yea and other byshoppes, and Preistes, in his tyme, so they by his commaundement, dyd in theyr tyme, ordeyne other, delyueringe also to them, the doctryne whiche they haue receaued of Paule, and by contynuall discurse of tyme, euerye one hath deliuered the fayth, that they from the Apostles haue receaued, and so euen from Chryste, to this presente daye, one fayth hath euer stande stedfaste.
column8: Paul did ordain Timothy, and Tyte, yea and other Bishops, and Priests, in his time, so they by his Commandment, did in their time, ordain other, delivering also to them, the Doctrine which they have received of Paul, and by continual discourse of time, every one hath Delivered the faith, that they from the Apostles have received, and so even from Christ, to this present day, one faith hath ever stand steadfast.

column7: Whiche thoughe it hath sundry tymes bene assayde, and sore pynched, yet euer hath it preuailed at the last, and had the vpper hande, accordynge to Christes promyse,
column8: Which though it hath sundry times be assayed, and soar pinched, yet ever hath it prevailed At the last, and had the upper hand, according to Christ's promise,

column7: <NOTE> neyther ought anye man lesse to credyt the catholike church, because there are in the same, dyuers euyll, and wicked synners.
column8: neither ought any man less to credit the catholic Church, Because there Are in the same, Diverse evil, and wicked Sinners.

column7: For Christ hym selfe, <NOTE> doth compare the churche to a nette, caste into the sea, whiche taketh both good and bad fyshes, but at the ende, the good shalbe reserued, and the euyll cast awaye.
column8: For christ him self, does compare the Church to a net, cast into the sea, which Takes both good and bad fishes, but At the end, the good shall reserved, and the evil cast away.

column7: Was not twelue chosen by Christe, yet one of them, he calleth a deuyll?
column8: Was not twelue chosen by Christ, yet one of them, he calls a Devil?

column7: Doth not Christe also saye,
column8: Does not Christ also say,

column7: <NOTE> that Scribes and Phariseis, doo syt in Moyses chayre, neuerthelesse, he woulde the people should obey theyr lessons?
column8: that Scribes and Pharisees, do fit in Moses chair, nevertheless, he would the people should obey their Lessons?

column7: Euen so, thoughe some members of Christes catholyke churche, doo not lyue accordynge to theyr vocatyon, yet oughte no man therefore the lesse to regarde the fayth and doctryne of the same churche.
column8: Eve so, though Some members of Christ's catholic Church, do not live according to their vocation, yet ought no man Therefore the less to regard the faith and Doctrine of the same Church.

column7: These thynges, good people, thoughe they are sufficiente, to declare the holye Churche, what it is,
column8: These things, good people, though they Are sufficient, to declare the holy Church, what it is,

column7: and howe it may be knowen, yet I besech you most diligently, to note, and carye awaye one rule, which shall neuer deceaue you, but is a sure tryall of the catholyke churche, and the fayth thereof.
column8: and how it may be known, yet I beseech you most diligently, to note, and carry away one Rule, which shall never deceive you, but is a sure trial of the catholic Church, and the faith thereof.

column7: This rule is not myne, but taken out of a learned, auncient, and ryghte godlye father in Christes Churche.
column8: This Rule is not mine, but taken out of a learned, ancient, and right godly father in Christ's Church.

column7: He sayth There are thre meanes to trye a churche,
column8: He say There Are Three means to try a Church,

column7: or doctryne, the fyrst is antiquitie, the second, is vniuersalitie, the thyrde, is vnitie.
column8: or Doctrine, the fyrst is antiquity, the second, is universality, the Third, is unity.

column7: By the fyrst, we are taught, that a true doctrine must be knowe, by that it is not lately spronge vp, or rysen, but commeth from Christ, and his apostles, and hath contynued styll in the churche.
column8: By the fyrst, we Are taught, that a true Doctrine must be know, by that it is not lately sprung up, or risen, but comes from christ, and his Apostles, and hath continued still in the Church.

column7: By the seconde, we maye vnderstande, that a true fayth, or doctryne of the churche is that onelye, whiche vnyuersallye, in all countreys hath ben taught,
column8: By the seconde, we may understand, that a true faith, or Doctrine of the Church is that only, which vnyuersallye, in all Countries' hath been taught,

column7: & beleued. By the thirde we ought to learne, that a true doctryne, or fayth of the church, doth alwayes agre, and is alwayes one.
column8: & believed. By the Third we ought to Learn, that a true Doctrine, or faith of the Church, does always agree, and is always one.

column7: Nowe those three thinges well noted, may instruct and teache any Christen man, to knowe the catholyke churche, whiche euer synce the Apostles tyme, and in all countreys, with one consent (in al thinges concernyng our fayth) hath shewed her self the worthy spouse of Chryst.
column8: Now those three things well noted, may instruct and teach any christian man, to know the catholic Church, which ever since the Apostles time, and in all Countries', with one consent (in all things Concerning our faith) hath showed her self the worthy spouse of Christ

column7: Contrary wyse, false doctryne, and heresye, euer hath doone, and shall doo to the worldes ende, lately arise, & lurke in priuat corners,
column8: Contrary wise, false Doctrine, and heresy, ever hath done, and shall do to the world's end, lately arise, & lurk in private corners,

column7: & neuer agre with itselfe.
column8: & never agree with itself.

column7: Which thyngs I myght easelye at large proue, and open to you, by playne and manifest demonstration.
column8: Which things I might Easily At large prove, and open to you, by plain and manifest demonstration.

column7: But because in the nexte homelie,
column8: But Because in the Next homely,

column7: I intende to speake of the aucthoritie of the churche, and also of the commoditie, and profite that we haue by the same, here I wyll make an ende,
column8: I intend to speak of the Authority of the Church, and also of the commodity, and profit that we have by the same, Here I will make an end,

column7: <NOTE> besechyng all you (good and godly people) to geue your bodyes, and soules, an humble and holy sacryfyce to almyghtye God, prayinge euermore, that we may be altogether lyuelye membres, of oure sauyoure Iesus Chryst, and of his catholyke churche here vpon earth, and after this lyfe, partakers of the ioyfull kyngedome of heauen, through the same our Lorde Iesus Christ, to whom with the father, and the holy ghoste, be all honoure and glorye worlde without ende.
column8: beseeching all you (good and godly people) to give your bodies, and Souls, an humble and holy sacrifice to almighty God, praying evermore, that we may be altogether lively members, of our Saviour jesus Christ, and of his catholic Church Here upon earth, and After this life, partakers of the joyful Kingdom of heaven, through the same our Lord jesus christ, to whom with the father, and the holy ghost, be all honour and glory world without end.

column7: Amen. H. Pendilton sacrae theologiae professoris.
column8: Amen. H. Pendilton Sacrae Theologiae Professoris.

column7: An Homely, of the aucthoritie of the churche, declarynge what commoditie and profit we haue thereby.
column8: an Homely, of the Authority of the Church, declaring what commodity and profit we have thereby.

column7: L Ykewyse, as in the laste homelye, it was declared to you (good chrysten people) what the churche is, and how it maye be knowen:
column8: Likewise Likewise, as in the laste homely, it was declared to you (good christen people) what the Church is, and how it may be known:

column7: soo nowe ye shall learne, the aucthoritie of the same catholyke church, and the commoditie, or profyt that ensueth to vs all, beynge members of the same churche.
column8: so now you shall Learn, the Authority of the same catholic Church, and the commodity, or profit that ensueth to us all, being members of the same Church.

column7: Fyrste, whan oure sauioure Iesus Christ, dyd send forth the twelue apostles to preach, who were, and are, the cheife, and pryncipall pyllers of this catholyke churche, he dyd geue to them great power, and aucthoritie, as saynt Mathewe beareth wytnes,
column8: First, when our Saviour jesus christ, did send forth the twelue Apostles to preach, who were, and Are, the chief, and principal pillars of this catholic Church, he did give to them great power, and Authority, as saint Matthew bears witness,

column7: sayinge: Iesus dyd call together the twelue disciples, and gaue to them power ouer vncleane spirites, that they shoulde cast them out, and shoulde heale all maner of diseases, and infirmities.
column8: saying: jesus did call together the twelue Disciples, and gave to them power over unclean spirits, that they should cast them out, and should heal all manner of diseases, and infirmities.

column7: And sondrye tymes we do rede in the holy Gospell, that our Sauiour Chryste doth speake to his Apostles, after this maner.
column8: And sundry times we do rede in the holy Gospel, that our Saviour Christ does speak to his Apostles, After this manner.

column7: Qui uos audit, me audit,
column8: Qui uos audit, me audit,

column7: & qui uos spernit, me spernit.
column8: & qui uos spernit, me spernit.

column7: That is to saye: He that heareth you,
column8: That is to say: He that hears you,

column7: heareth me and he that dispiseth you, doth dispise me.
column8: hears me and he that despiseth you, does despise me.

column7: Meanynge, <NOTE> and wyllynge thereby, that all the worlde shoulde know and confesse, the aucthoritie of the catholyke church, whiche Christ him selfe dyd buyld in, and vpon these hys holye Apostles.
column8: Meaning, and willing thereby, that all the world should know and confess, the Authority of the catholic Church, which christ him self did build in, and upon these his holy Apostles.

column7: And to the same purpose he sayd to them,
column8: And to the same purpose he said to them,

column7: Iam non dicam uos seruos, sed amicos &c That is to say Nowe I wyll no more call you seruauntes,
column8: Iam non dicam uos seruos, sed amicos etc. That is to say Now I will no more call you Servants,

column7: but frendes:
column8: but Friends:

column7: for al thinges that I haue herde of my father,
column8: for all things that I have herd of my father,

column7: I haue declared to you.
column8: I have declared to you.

column7: <NOTE> And agayne he sayth:
column8: And again he say:

column7: As my father sente me, euen so I sende you.
column8: As my father sent me, even so I send you.

column7: By these, and many such other places, we maye see, that our louynge sauiour, dyd giue greate aucthoritie to his Apostles.
column8: By these, and many such other places, we may see, that our loving Saviour, did give great Authority to his Apostles.

column7: But nowe it is expediente, and nedefull, to declare, in what specyall poyntes this aucthorytie doth consyste, and that the same aucthorytie was not onely geuen to the Apostles of Christe, but also to theyr successours, in the catholyke churche, euer to endure.
column8: But now it is expedient, and needful, to declare, in what special points this aucthorytie does consyste, and that the same aucthorytie was not only given to the Apostles of Christ, but also to their Successors, in the catholic Church, ever to endure.

column7: Whiche aucthoritie, thoughe it be greate, and manyfolde, yet these are the chefest partes thereof, that hereafter doo folowe.
column8: Which Authority, though it be great, and manifold, yet these Are the chiefest parts thereof, that hereafter do follow.

column7: Fyrste, almyghtye God, hath geuen power,
column8: First, almighty God, hath given power,

column7: <NOTE> and aucthoritie, to the catholike churche, to haue the true sense, and vnderstandynge, of the holye Scripture, yea, and to approue also, or reproue al wryting, as Scripture, or no Scripture.
column8: and Authority, to the catholic Church, to have the true sense, and understanding, of the holy Scripture, yea, and to approve also, or reprove all writing, as Scripture, or no Scripture.

column7: Whiche thynge, good christen people, you may well vnderstande to be moost true, yf ye cal to remembraunce, who is the guyde, and gouernour of the churche, that is to wit, the holy Ghost:
column8: Which thing, good christian people, you may well understand to be most true, if you call to remembrance, who is the guide, and governor of the Church, that is to wit, the holy Ghost:

column7: as Christe dyd promyse, sayinge.
column8: as Christ did promise, saying.

column7: Ego rogabo patrem et alium paracletum dabit vobis, vt maneat vobiscum ineternum,
column8: Ego rogabo patrem et Alium Paracletum Dabit vobis, vt Maneat vobiscum ineternum,

column7: <NOTE> that is to saye,
column8: that is to say,

column7: I wyll aske my father, and he wyll giue to you an other comforter, that he maye abyde wyth you for euer.
column8: I will ask my father, and he will give to you an other comforter, that he may abide with you for ever.

column7: And after that our Lord and sauiour had rysen fro death, he dyd breathe vpon hys Apostles, and sayde Accipite spiritum sanctum Take you the holy ghost and also,
column8: And After that our Lord and Saviour had risen from death, he did breathe upon his Apostles, and said Accipite spiritum sanctum Take you the holy ghost and also,

column7: <NOTE> after hys ascension into heauen, accordynge to his merciful promise, he did sende downe the holy Ghost vpon his Apostles,
column8: After his Ascension into heaven, according to his merciful promise, he did send down the holy Ghost upon his Apostles,

column7: <NOTE> as saincte Luke writeth.
column8: as saint Lycia Writeth.

column7: Nowe that the holy ghoste was not gyuen to the Apostles onely, but also to the catholyke churche, to the worldes ende, it is manyfest:
column8: Now that the holy ghost was not given to the Apostles only, but also to the catholic Church, to the world's end, it is manifest:

column7: forasmuche as Chryste dyd promyse the conforter, vt maneat vobiscum inaeternum.
column8: forasmuch as Christ did promise the comforter, vt Maneat vobiscum inaeternum.

column7: That he should abyde (sayeth he) wyth you for euer.
column8: That he should abide (Saith he) with you for ever.

column7: Nowe we are mooste certayne,
column8: Now we Are most certain,

column7: <NOTE> that the Apostles of Christe dyd suffer deathe, for the faythe of Chryste, and that within fewe yeres, after they thus had receyued the holy ghoste.
column8: that the Apostles of Christ did suffer death, for the faith of Christ, and that within few Years, After they thus had received the holy ghost.

column7: Neuertheles, Christ sending furthe hys Apostles to preache, and baptyze, sayd to the:
column8: Nevertheless, christ sending forth his Apostles to preach, and baptyze, said to thee:

column7: Ecce ego vobiscu sum omnibus diebus vsque ad consumation seculi.
column8: Ecce ego vobiscu sum omnibus diebus vsque ad consummation Seculi.

column7: That is, Behold,
column8: That is, Behold,

column7: I am with you at al tymes, euen to the ende of the worlde.
column8: I am with you At all times, even to the end of the world.

column7: Wherefore we maye playnly see, that the holy ghoste beynge promised to the Apostles, to abyde for euer, and to the very ende of the world, was promised and giuen to them, and to their successours in ye churche, where he doth, and shall abide for euer.
column8: Wherefore we may plainly see, that the holy ghost being promised to the Apostles, to abide for ever, and to the very end of the world, was promised and given to them, and to their Successors in you Church, where he does, and shall abide for ever.

column7: Now forasmuche, as the holye ghoste is the gouernour and ruler of the catholyke churche, we ought there onely, and in no other corner, to serche the true vnderstandynge, and dyscernynge of the scryptures.
column8: Now forasmuch, as the holy ghost is the governor and ruler of the catholic Church, we ought there only, and in no other corner, to search the true understanding, and dyscernynge of the Scriptures.

column7: And for this cause, the aucient fathers (were they neuer so godly, and so wel learned) yet woulde they neuer presume vpon theyr owne iudgementes, but euer referred them selues, to the vnderstandyng, and interpretacion of the catholyke churche before them.
column8: And for this cause, the ancient Father's (were they never so godly, and so well learned) yet would they never presume upon their own Judgments, but ever referred them selves, to the understanding, and Interpretation of the catholic Church before them.

column7: Therfore the godly lerned, and ancient father Ireneus,
column8: Therefore the godly learned, and ancient father Irenaeus,

column7: <NOTE> wryting agaynste schismaticall heresyes, sayeth thus.
column8: writing against Schismatical heresies, Saith thus.

column7: Quid enim si qui de aliqua modica, questione disceptatio esset, nonne oporteret, in antiquissimas recurrere,
column8: Quid enim si qui de Any Modica, question Dispute esset, nonne oporteret, in antiquissimas recurrere,

column7: Ecclesias. &c. that is to saye,
column8: Ecclesiastes. etc. that is to say,

column7: but what and yf there were contencion concerning some smal question, were it not necessarye to returne to the mooste auncient churches, and immediatly after, he sayeth:
column8: but what and if there were contention Concerning Some small question, were it not necessary to return to the most ancient Churches, and immediately After, he Saith:

column7: Quid autem si neque apostoli quidem scripturas reliquissent nobis, nonne oportebat ordinem sequi traditionis, quam tradiderunt hijs, quibus committebant Ecclesias?
column8: Quid autem si neque Apostles quidem scripturas reliquissent nobis, nonne Opportune ordinem sequi traditionis, quam tradiderunt hijs, quibus committebant Ecclesiastes?

column7: What (sayeth this holye father) yf the Apostles had lefte to vs no scripture at all, had it not bene necessarye to folowe the order of that tradition, whyche they delyuered to those, to whome they dyd bequethe the churche?
column8: What (Saith this holy father) if the Apostles had left to us no scripture At all, had it not be necessary to follow the order of that tradition, which they Delivered to those, to whom they did bequeath the Church?

column7: Alas (good people) howe farre are manye in these dayes gone from this olde, and aunciet rule?
column8: Alas (good people) how Far Are many in these days gone from this old, and aunciet Rule?

column7: this blessed martir, here exhorteth, or, rather commaundeth, that yf any small dyscorde, (thoughe it be in a matter of lytle importaunce) doo chaunce, that we woulde not, accordyng to our fantasy, iudge therein, but though we haue no scripture for the same, yet (sayeth he) we ought to folowe, kepe,
column8: this blessed Martyr's, Here exhorteth, or, rather commandeth, that if any small discord, (though it be in a matter of little importance) do chance, that we would not, according to our fantasy, judge therein, but though we have no scripture for the same, yet (Saith he) we ought to follow, keep,

column7: and obserue the tradition of the aunciente churches.
column8: and observe the tradition of the ancient Churches.

column7: Where as in these late dayes, the impudente procedars, haue taughte the zely people, that euery man shoulde, and may be a iudge of controuersyes, and that we oughte to obserue no tradition, nor ceremonye, other than we fynde in the holy scrypture.
column8: Where as in these late days, the impudent procedars, have taught the zely people, that every man should, and may be a judge of controversies, and that we ought to observe no tradition, nor ceremony, other than we find in the holy scripture.

column7: Of suche, the same holy Ireneus dooeth speake thus, after many other notable lessons to the same purpose.
column8: Of such, the same holy Irenaeus doth speak thus, After many other notable Lessons to the same purpose.

column7: Omnes autem hij decidunt a veritate, et heritici quidem alienum ignem afferentes ad altare dei, id est, alienas doctrinas, a celesti igne conburentur.
column8: Omnes autem hij decidunt a veritate, et heritici quidem Alienum Ignem afferentes ad altar dei, id est, alienas doctrinas, a celesti Ignite conburentur.

column7: &c. All these (sayeth he) doo fal from the trueth:
column8: etc. All these (Saith he) do fall from the truth:

column7: and the heretykes truely, bryngynge straunge fyre to the aulter of God, that is to saye, straunge doctrine, shalbe brent with the heuenly fyre.
column8: and the Heretics truly, bringing strange fire to the alter of God, that is to say, strange Doctrine, shall brent with the heavenly fire.

column7: With suche lyke threatnynges in the same place, to those that disobey the authoritie of the churche.
column8: With such like threatnynges in the same place, to those that disobey the Authority of the Church.

column7: Lykewyse sainct Augustyne speakynge of the baptysme of chyldren, and howe that sacrament, can profyte them, seynge many die before they know the effecte of the same:
column8: Likewise saint Augustine speaking of the Baptism of children, and how that sacrament, can profit them, sing many die before they know the Effect of the same:

column7: affyrmeth, that the faythe of those that brynge the chylde to christenynge, shall profyte the childe that is broughte:
column8: Affirmeth, that the faith of those that bring the child to christening, shall profit the child that is brought:

column7: but for his probacion, <NOTE> he bryngeth thys.
column8: but for his probation, he bringeth this.

column7: Hoc commendat ecclesie saluberrima authoritas.
column8: Hoc commendat Churches saluberrima Authoritas.

column7: This thynge the mooste holsome aucthoritye of the churche doethe commende.
column8: This thing the most wholesome Authority of the Church doth commend.

column7: And euen wyth lyke reuerence, the same saincte Augustyne, dooth many tymes submytte all hys iudgementes,
column8: And even with like Reverence, the same saint Augustine, doth many times submit all his Judgments,

column7: <NOTE> and woorkes to the catholyke churche.
column8: and works to the catholic Church.

column7: And fynally to declare hys iudgemente, concernynge the aucthoritye of the catholyke churche.
column8: And finally to declare his judgement, Concerning the Authority of the catholic Church.

column7: He saieth thus. Ego vero Euagelio no crederem nisi me catholicae Ecclesiae commoueret authoritas, yt is to say,
column8: He Saith thus. Ego vero Evangel no crederem nisi me Catholic Ecclesiae commoueret Authoritas, that is to say,

column7: Truely, I would not beleue the Gospell, onles that the aucthoritye of the catholyke churche dyd moue me thereto.
column8: Truly, I would not believe the Gospel, unless that the Authority of the catholic Church did move me thereto.

column7: And we ought here to consyder, that after the ascension of our sauioure Christe, for the space of certayne yeares, there was no gospell at all wrytten:
column8: And we ought Here to Consider, that After the Ascension of our Saviour Christ, for the Molle of certain Years, there was no gospel At all written:

column7: but all thynges, concernynge the faythfull christians, were ruled, and gouerned by the dyscyples of Christ, beyng than, the heades of the church.
column8: but all things, Concerning the faithful Christians, were ruled, and governed by the Disciples of christ, being than, the Heads of the Church.

column7: Afterwarde, we rede that dyuers of the dyscyples of Christe, dyd wryte Gospelles:
column8: Afterward, we rede that Diverse of the Disciples of Christ, did write Gospels:

column7: as sainct Bartylmew, Nicodemus, and an other Gospel was called Euangelium Nazareorum.
column8: as saint Bartholomew, Nicodemus, and an other Gospel was called Evangelium Nazareorum.

column7: But the authorite of the churche, dyd onely admitte those fower euangelistes:
column8: But the Authority of the Church, did only admit those fower Evangelists:

column7: which nowe the whole churche dooth retayne.
column8: which now the Whole Church doth retain.

column7: Whyche thing might well seme maruelous, seynge that bothe saincte Bartylmew, and Nicodemus, were present, and dyd see the woorkes of Christ, and also dyd here hys doctryne, where as sainct Luke dyd learne hys gospell of saincte Paule, and other, and so lykewyse dyd S. marke but hereby it dooeth moost playnly appere, that the catholike churche onely, hathe this hye aucthorite, to dyscerne scriptures, and that scriptures allowed by the church shoulde not be refused of anye particulare persons.
column8: Which thing might well seem marvelous, sing that both saint Bartholomew, and Nicodemus, were present, and did see the works of christ, and also did hear his Doctrine, where as saint Lycia did Learn his gospel of saint Paul, and other, and so likewise did S. mark but hereby it doth most plainly appear, that the catholic Church only, hath this high Authority, to discern Scriptures, and that Scriptures allowed by the Church should not be refused of any particular Persons.

column7: Nowe therefore, seynge that the catholyke churche, bothe hathe delyuered, to vs the scripture, and in all ages and tymes, hath bene taken of all Godly lerned men, for the true iudge thereof.
column8: Now Therefore, sing that the catholic Church, both hath Delivered, to us the scripture, and in all ages and times, hath be taken of all Godly learned men, for the true judge thereof.

column7: I exhort, and beseche all you (good christen people), that in all doutes, opinions, and controuersies, ye would resort to the holy churche, and there learne what the same catholyke church hath beleued, and taught, from time to time, concernynge doutes, or controuersies, and yf wyth lowly and meke hartes ye wyll so doo, surely the holy ghoste wyll instructe you, he wyll comforte you, and he wyl leade you, into al trueth.
column8: I exhort, and beseech all you (good christian people), that in all doubts, opinions, and controversies, you would resort to the holy Church, and there Learn what the same catholic Church hath believed, and taught, from time to time, Concerning doubts, or controversies, and if with lowly and meek hearts you will so do, surely the holy ghost will instruct you, he will Comfort you, and he will lead you, into all truth.

column7: But yf in suche case, ye wil fly from the catholike church,
column8: But if in such case, you will fly from the catholic Church,

column7: & aske cousell of your selues, or of any that dooth swarue from the sayd churche, than for so muche as the holy ghost is not your guyde, you shall fall from ignoraunce to errour, and from doutyng, and dysputyng, to playne heresy, and so from one, to another, to the vtter confusion,
column8: & ask Counsel of your selves, or of any that doth swerve from the said Church, than for so much as the holy ghost is not your guide, you shall fallen from ignorance to error, and from doubting, and disputing, to plain heresy, and so from one, to Another, to the utter confusion,

column7: <NOTE> of bothe body and soule.
column8: of both body and soul.

column7: Yet beside this great authoritie of the churche, whereof you haue hearde, there is an other gyuen by God, of mooste hye excellencye, that is, power to forgyue, and pardon, the penitent synner, and to punishe, and correcte, the obstinate or frowarde synner:
column8: Yet beside this great Authority of the Church, whereof you have heard, there is an other given by God, of most high excellency, that is, power to forgive, and pardon, the penitent sinner, and to Punish, and correct, the obstinate or forward sinner:

column7: which power and aucthorite, <NOTE> as it was fygured in the preesthood of the olde lawe, as in Iudgynge of leprose persons, and in punyshynge to death, those that did not obey the priest:
column8: which power and Authority, as it was figured in the preesthood of the old law, as in Judging of leprose Persons, and in punishing to death, those that did not obey the priest:

column7: eue so is it giuen by our sauiour Christ in very dede,
column8: eve so is it given by our Saviour christ in very deed,

column7: <NOTE> in the gospel, to his Apostles, and to all theyr successours.
column8: in the gospel, to his Apostles, and to all their Successors.

column7: For after that our sauioure hadde rysen from deathe:
column8: For After that our Saviour had risen from death:

column7: he came amonges hys Apostles, and brethed vpon them, and sayde Accipite spiritum sanctum, quorum dimiseritis peccata,
column8: he Come among his Apostles, and breathed upon them, and said Accipite spiritum sanctum, quorum dimiseritis Peccata,

column7: dimittuntur eis, et quorum retinueritis, retenta sunt. (That is,) take you the holy ghost, whose sinnes you shall forgyue, they are forgyuen to them, and whose synnes you doo retayne,
column8: dimittuntur eis, et quorum retinueritis, retenta sunt. (That is,) take you the holy ghost, whose Sins you shall forgive, they Are forgiven to them, and whose Sins you do retain,

column7: they are retayned. Whyche aucthorite, by playne woordes gyuen by Christ, though some hath, or doo, contemne, and set at noughte,
column8: they Are retained. Which Authority, by plain words given by christ, though Some hath, or do, contemn, and Set At nought,

column7: <NOTE> yet saincte Cyrill byddeth them cease to merueyle, that Christ should giue, suche power, for he sayeth,
column8: yet saint Cyril biddeth them cease to marvel, that christ should give, such power, for he Saith,

column7: Certe absurdum non est, peccata remitti posse ab illis, qui spiritum sanctum in seipsis habeant.
column8: Certain absurdum non est, Peccata remitti posse ab illis, qui spiritum sanctum in seipsis habeant.

column7: Surelye, (sayeth he) it is no absurdyte, yt synnes are forgyue by the which haue ye holy ghost in the.
column8: Surely, (Saith he) it is no absurdyte, that Sins Are forgive by the which have you holy ghost in thee.

column7: Nowe yf you wyll marke, that not the preest onely, but also the holy Ghost dothe woorke, in remitting, and pardonyng synnes, than I trust you wyll see,
column8: Now if you will mark, that not the priest only, but also the holy Ghost doth work, in remitting, and pardoning Sins, than I trust you will see,

column7: & graunte, this aucthoritie of Christes catholike churche, which thyng euery chrysten man dothe confesse dayly in his crede, saying, not onely I beleue the holy catholyke churche, the communion of saynctes, but addyth also, the remyssion of synnes, to be in ye same catholike churche.
column8: & grant, this Authority of Christ's catholic Church, which thing every christen man doth confess daily in his crede, saying, not only I believe the holy catholic Church, the communion of Saints, but addyth also, the remission of Sins, to be in you same catholic Church.

column7: <NOTE> Doo not we rede that saynt Paule dyd vse this aucthoritie, whan he did excommunicate Hymeneus and Alexander?
column8: Do not we rede that saint Paul did use this Authority, when he did excommunicate Hymenaeus and Alexander?

column7: dyd not the holye Byshoppe saynt Ambrose, vse this aucthoritie in euery poynt, vpon the emperoure Theodosius?
column8: did not the holy Bishop saint Ambrose, use this Authority in every point, upon the emperor Theodosius?

column7: <NOTE> Which holy byshoppe perceyuynge the emperoure had greuouslye offended, dyd not spare to excommunicate hym:
column8: Which holy bishop perceiving the emperor had grievously offended, did not spare to excommunicate him:

column7: yea and though he offered him selfe obedientlye to be receyued, yet was it after longe penaunce, that he was absolued, this holy byshoppe dyd vse the authoritie giuen to him by God,
column8: yea and though he offered him self obediently to be received, yet was it After long penance, that he was absolved, this holy bishop did use the Authority given to him by God,

column7: & thys christen emperoure, knowing, the same, dyd with al humilitie obey.
column8: & this christian emperor, knowing, the same, did with all humility obey.

column7: Yf the bishopes and preistes in time past, and also the layitee, had lerned and practsied there duetyes and vocations, by this example, surelye the churche of Chryste shoulde not haue come to such great disordre as we see, neyther shoulde vyce and wyckednes, so frely haue bene vsyd:
column8: If the Bishops and Priests in time past, and also the layitee, had learned and practsied there duties and vocations, by this Exampl, surely the Church of Christ should not have come to such great disorder as we see, neither should vice and wickedness, so freely have be used:

column7: but bicause this mater, is largely and lernedly, set fourth in the sacramet of penance,
column8: but Because this mater, is largely and learnedly, Set fourth in the Sacrament of penance,

column7: I wil cease to speake any more hereof, and nowe it remayneth to declare, what comoditie and profytte we haue by thys catholyke church, our lorde and mayster chryste in the gospell, of saincte Iohn,
column8: I will cease to speak any more hereof, and now it remaineth to declare, what commodity and profit we have by this catholic Church, our lord and master Christ in the gospel, of saint John,

column7: <NOTE> doeth compare hym selfe to the vyne tree, and all vs to the braunches:
column8: doth compare him self to the vine tree, and all us to the branches:

column7: and sayeth. Manete in me, et ego in vobis.
column8: and Saith. Manete in me, et ego in vobis.

column7: Abyde you in me, (that is to saye, in the faythe of my churche.) And I wyll abyde in you.
column8: Abide you in me, (that is to say, in the faith of my Church.) And I will abide in you.

column7: Oh mercyful Lord, what comfort, and commoditye is this, for a christen man, to haue Christe to abyde wt hym?
column8: O merciful Lord, what Comfort, and commodity is this, for a christian man, to have Christ to abide with him?

column7: And farther he sayeth. Yf you abide in me,
column8: And farther he Saith. If you abide in me,

column7: & my wordes abide in you, aske what you wyl,
column8: & my words abide in you, ask what you will,

column7: & it shalbe graunted to you.
column8: & it shall granted to you.

column7: Here are we sure, yt if we abyde in christes catholike churche,
column8: Here Are we sure, that if we abide in Christ's catholic Church,

column7: & embrace the faythe, and doctryne therof, both Christ hym selfe by grace, wyll abyde in vs, and also oure prayers, shal euermore be hearde.
column8: & embrace the faith, and Doctrine thereof, both christ him self by grace, will abide in us, and also our Prayers, shall evermore be heard.

column7: And wythoute all doute, there is no abiding in Christe, vnles we abide in the vnyte of hys catholyke churche.
column8: And without all doubt, there is no abiding in Christ, unless we abide in the vnyte of his catholic Church.

column7: For as saynct Cipriane sayeth: <NOTE>
column8: For as saint Cyprian Saith:

column7: Non potest habere deum patrem qui non nouit Ecclesiam matrem:
column8: Non potest habere God patrem qui non Novit Church matrem:

column7: He cannot haue God hys father, yt knoweth not the churche to be his mother:
column8: He cannot have God his father, that Knoweth not the Church to be his mother:

column7: But a child of God, knowig ye churche to be his mother,
column8: But a child of God, knowig you Church to be his mother,

column7: & lyinge in the bosome thereof, may be sure that Christ the spouse of the churche,
column8: & lying in the bosom thereof, may be sure that christ the spouse of the Church,

column7: <NOTE> wyll neuer forgette hys nedefull requestes.
column8: will never forget his needful requests.

column7: And as no lyuely creature, was saued from death, but suche onely as were in the arcke of Noe,
column8: And as no lively creature, was saved from death, but such only as were in the Ark of Noah,

column7: <NOTE> so is there none saued from dampnation, but those that are in the vnyte of Christes churche.
column8: so is there none saved from damnation, but those that Are in the vnyte of Christ's Church.

column7: And therefore, to gyue vs warnynge, the holye doctoure Saincte Augustyne, speaketh in thys maner mooste playnlye.
column8: And Therefore, to gyve us warning, the holy Doctor Saint Augustine, speaks in this manner most plainly.

column7: Quisquis ergo ab hac catholica ecclesia fuerit seperatus qua tu libet laudabiliter se uiuere existimet,
column8: Quisquis ergo ab hac catholica Church fuerit seperatus qua tu libet laudabiliter se uiuere existimet,

column7: hoc folo scelere quod a Christi Vnitate disiunctus est no habebit uitam, sedir a dei manet super cu That is in englysh,
column8: hoc folo Scelere quod a Christ Vnitate disiunctus est no habebit uitam, sedir a dei manet super cu That is in english,

column7: Whosoeuer therfore shal be seperatid fro this catholike church, although he think himself to liue neuer so worthely, yet for this onelye crime yt he is separated fro ye vnitie of Christ, he shal not haue life, but ye wrath of god abideth, vpon hym.
column8: Whosoever Therefore shall be separated from this catholic Church, although he think himself to live never so worthily, yet for this only crime that he is separated from you unity of christ, he shall not have life, but you wrath of god Abideth, upon him.

column7: But what nede is it, to allege saincte Augustine, or any other auncient father herein, seing almyghty God by hys prophet Esay, hath set furthe to vs a lytle picture of hys churche,
column8: But what need is it, to allege saint Augustine, or any other ancient father herein, sing almighty God by his Prophet Isaiah, hath Set forth to us a little picture of his Church,

column7: <NOTE> vnder the name of a vyneyarde, and the house of Israell?
column8: under the name of a vineyard, and the house of Israel?

column7: There maye we see, that thynge that we by experience doo knowe.
column8: There may we see, that thing that we by experience do know.

column7: For almyghty God, in that parable declareth by hys Prophete, howe muche he had doone for the house of Israell, a fygure of Christes churche, in that he had planted them in a batsome, and frutefull countrey, and had gyuen to them good gouernours, and orders, wherein they myghte haue lyued, and pleased hym, but forasmuche as they dyd wylfullye breake the lawes of God,
column8: For almighty God, in that parable Declareth by his Prophet, how much he had done for the house of Israel, a figure of Christ's Church, in that he had planted them in a batsome, and fruitful country, and had given to them good Governors, and order, wherein they might have lived, and pleased him, but forasmuch as they did wylfullye break the laws of God,

column7: & hys ordinance, he threatned them saying:
column8: & his Ordinance, he threatened them saying:

column7: Auferam sepem eius, et erit in direptionem.
column8: Auferam sepem eius, et erit in direptionem.

column7: &c. I wyll (sayeth oure Lorde) take awaye the hedge of my vyneyarde, that it may peryshe.
column8: etc. I will (Saith our Lord) take away the hedge of my vineyard, that it may perish.

column7: Euen so hathe our sauioure Christe dealed wyth vs, ye people of his churche.
column8: Even so hath our Saviour Christ dealed with us, you people of his Church.

column7: For where as by his preciouse deathe and passion, he dyd purchase vs, and lefte vs in the custodye of his catholyke church, as is before sayde, leauynge also to vs, lawes to obserue, and sacramentes, wherewith we should be preserued.
column8: For where as by his precious death and passion, he did purchase us, and left us in the custody of his catholic Church, as is before said, leaving also to us, laws to observe, and Sacraments, wherewith we should be preserved.

column7: And we naughty people, haue dyspysed al his moost godly, and holsome decrees, and ordinances, he hathe of his iustyce, and accordynge to hys promyse, euen in oure tyme punished vs:
column8: And we naughty people, have despised all his most godly, and wholesome decrees, and ordinances, he hath of his Justice, and according to his promise, even in our time punished us:

column7: and hath suffred the wicked, to plucke downe the pale or hedge of his vineyarde:
column8: and hath suffered the wicked, to pluck down the pale or hedge of his vineyard:

column7: I meane all good order, as well in the churche, as in the common wealthe, and that for the space of many yeares paste.
column8: I mean all good order, as well in the Church, as in the Common wealth, and that for the Molle of many Years past.

column7: Nowe here christen people, thoughe you doo not consyder the plage of sundrye synnes, that hathe in this late scysme, possessed manye mens soules, yet doo not dyssemble, nor forgette the miserye, that we all haue suffered outewardelye, synce we were separate from the churche of Christe:
column8: Now Here christen people, though you do not Consider the plague of sundry Sins, that hath in this late Schism, possessed many men's Souls, yet do not dyssemble, nor forget the misery, that we all have suffered outewardelye, since we were separate from the Church of Christ:

column7: alas, what Christen bloude wythin this Realme, euen by oure owne countreimen, hath bene shed?
column8: alas, what christian blood within this Realm, even by our own countreimen, hath be shed?

column7: Oh Lord, how many poore wydowes without comforte haue bene lefte?
column8: O Lord, how many poor Widows without Comfort have be left?

column7: Howe many fatherlesse children without soccoure?
column8: Howe many fatherless children without soccoure?

column7: I leaue here to speake, of the vnshameles breakynge of the deade mennes testamentes, and theyr mooste godly intentes,
column8: I leave Here to speak, of the unshameless breaking of the dead men's Testaments, and their most godly intentes,

column7: & ordinances: Abbais, are poulled downe:
column8: & ordinances: Abbess, Are poulled down:

column7: Collegis, and Chantrees are ouerthrowe:
column8: Collegs, and Choirs Are overthrown:

column7: churches are robbed, and poore Christ, (that is to saye,) the hungry, and nedefull people, famyshe,
column8: Churches Are robbed, and poor christ, (that is to say,) the hungry, and needful people, famish,

column7: and crye oute therefore. All these surely, wyth many mo, haue come vpon vs, bicause we haue bene oute of the house of God.
column8: and cry out Therefore. All these surely, with many more, have come upon us, Because we have be out of the house of God.

column7: Wherefore, in the name of our Lorde Iesus Christe, let vs all togyther lament, and be sory for oure goynge astraye, let vs come, and fal downe before God oure father, and confesse oure transgression, and humblye desyre,
column8: Wherefore, in the name of our Lord jesus Christ, let us all together lament, and be sorry for our going astray, let us come, and fall down before God our father, and confess our Transgression, and humbly desire,

column7: <NOTE> that we maye be receyued into hys house, whyche is the churche, thoughe we shoulde all the dayes of oure lyues, be but hyrelynges.
column8: that we may be received into his house, which is the Church, though we should all the days of our lives, be but hirelings.

column7: Quia melior est dies vnus in atrijs tuis super milia.
column8: Quia melior est dies vnus in atrijs tuis super milia.

column7: One daye (Oh Lorde) is better spente in thy house than a thousande otherwyse.
column8: One day (O Lord) is better spent in thy house than a thousande otherwise.

column7: Fynallye yf we contynew obedyente chyldren, in the bosome of our mother, the holye churche:
column8: Finally if we continue obedient children, in the bosom of our mother, the holy Church:

column7: we shall be fedde wyth lyuely faythe, oute of whyche wyll sprynge in vs, muche holynesse of lyfe, and quietnes of conscience:
column8: we shall be fed with lively faith, out of which will spring in us, much holiness of life, and quietness of conscience:

column7: and yf at any tyme throughe our frailnes, we happen to fall, we haue readye, to rayse vs vp agayne, the holye Sacramentes:
column8: and if At any time through our frailness, we happen to fallen, we have ready, to raise us up again, the holy Sacraments:

column7: throughe the comfortable helpe whereof, we be made stronge:
column8: through the comfortable help whereof, we be made strong:

column7: and so daye by daye more able to procede in al kynde of vertue:
column8: and so day by day more able to proceed in all kind of virtue:

column7: and thus hauynge vpon earthe oure mother, the holye churche, whiche is the spouse of Iesus Christe the Sonne of God, we maye be bolde to call vpon GOD our father:
column8: and thus having upon earth our mother, the holy Church, which is the spouse of jesus Christ the Son of God, we may be bold to call upon GOD our father:

column7: and be assured, that he wyll heare vs, as hys dearebeloued chyldren, and gyue vs the inheritaunce of heauen, whyche is prepared for vs, through our sauiour Iesus Christe.
column8: and be assured, that he will hear us, as his dearebeloued children, and gyve us the inheritance of heaven, which is prepared for us, through our Saviour jesus Christ.

column7: To whoe wyth the father, and ye holy ghost, be honour, prayse and glory, world without ende.
column8: To who with the father, and you holy ghost, be honour, praise and glory, world without end.

column7: Amen. H. Pendilton sacrae theologiae professoris.
column8: Amen. H. Pendilton Sacrae Theologiae Professoris.

column7: An Homelye of the Primacy, or supreame power, of the highest gouernor of the militant Churche.
column8: an Homely of the Primacy, or supreme power, of the highest governor of the militant Church.

column7: AS in euery naturall, and polytyke body, so in the churche militat, (which is a misticall body) superioritie, and inferiority, must nedes be amogest ye members thereof, or ells it cannot endure.
column8: AS in every natural, and politic body, so in the Church militat, (which is a mystical body) superiority, and inferiority, must needs be Amongst you members thereof, or Else it cannot endure.

column7: And for thys cause speciallye, our Sauiour Chryste, when he was here conuersaunte, on the Earth, dyd, hymselfe, appoynte his Apostles,
column8: And for this cause specially, our Saviour Christ, when he was Here conversant, on the Earth, did, himself, appoint his Apostles,

column7: & Disciples, and there successours, to haue the ouersyght, cure, and high gouernement of his church, to the worldes ende.
column8: & Disciples, and there Successors, to have the ouersyght, cure, and high government of his Church, to the world's end.

column7: And to the intente, that no man should contempne theyr aucthoritie, he doth saye in the thyrtenth of Saynt Ihon,
column8: And to the intent, that no man should contemn their Authority, he does say in the thyrtenth of Saint John,

column7: Amen, Amen, Dico vobis, qui accipit si quem misero,
column8: Amen, Amen, Dico vobis, qui accipit si Whom misero,

column7: me accipit.
column8: me accipit.

column7: Qui autem me accipit, accipit eum qui me misit That is to say:
column8: Qui autem me accipit, accipit Eum qui me misit That is to say:

column7: Veryly Veryly, I saye vnto you, who that receyueth him whome I sende, receyueth me And he that receiueth me, receyueth hym that sent me.
column8: Verily Verily, I say unto you, who that receiveth him whom I send, receiveth me And he that receiveth me, receiveth him that sent me.

column7: And in the tenth of Luke he sayth,
column8: And in the tenth of Luke he say,

column7: Qui uos audit me audit,
column8: Qui uos audit me audit,

column7: & qui uos spernit, me spernit.
column8: & qui uos spernit, me spernit.

column7: Qui autem me spernit, spernit eum qui misit me.
column8: Qui autem me spernit, spernit Eum qui misit me.

column7: <NOTE> That is to saye:
column8: That is to say:

column7: He that heareth you, heareth me, and he that dispiseth you dispiseth me, and he that dispiseth me, dispiseth hym that sent me.
column8: He that hears you, hears me, and he that despiseth you despiseth me, and he that despiseth me, despiseth him that sent me.

column7: Of the Apostles also and theyr successours, and of theyr charge ouer Christes flocke, doth Saynt Paule speake, in the fourthe chapiter to the Ephesyans, saying. Ipse dedit quosdam quidem Apostolos, quosdam autem Prophetas, alios uero Euangelistas, alios autem pastores, et doctores, ad consummationem sanctorum, in opus ministerii, in edificationem Corporis Christi, donec occurramus omnes in unitatem fidei,
column8: Of the Apostles also and their Successors, and of their charge over Christ's flock, does Saint Paul speak, in the Fourth chapter to the Ephesians, saying. Ipse dedit Quosdam quidem Apostles, Quosdam autem Prophets, Alioth uero Evangelists, Alioth autem Pastors, et Doctors, ad consummationem sanctorum, in opus Ministerii, in edificationem Corporis Christ, donec occurramus omnes in unitatem fidei,

column7: & agnitionis filii dei, in uirum perfectum, in mensuram etatis plenitudinis Christi, ut iam non simus paruuli fluctuantes, neque circuferamur omniuento doctrine, in nequitia hominum, in astutia ad circumuentionem erroris. That is to saye:
column8: & agnitionis Sons dei, in uirum perfectum, in mensuram etatis plenitudinis Christ, ut iam non Simus Parvuli fluctuantes, neque circuferamur omniuento Doctrine, in Nequitia hominum, in Astutia ad circumuentionem Error. That is to say:

column7: He (meanyng Chryste) hath giuen or appointed some to be Apostles, some,
column8: He (meaning Christ) hath given or appointed Some to be Apostles, Some,

column7: Prophets some Euangelistes, some pastores, and teachers, to the perfytynge, or consummating, of the holyons, to doo the worke of the mynistery, to edyfye the body of Chryst, vntyll we all come together, in one vnitie of fayth, and knowledge of the sonne of God, vnto the estate of a perfecte man, after ye measure of the age of the fulnes of Chryst, that from henceforth, we should not be as babes, waueryng, neyther should we be caryed aboute with euery blaste of doctryne, in the wickednes of men, in the wylynes of them, who go aboute to deceyue vs
column8: prophets Some Evangelists, Some Pastors, and Teachers, to the perfytynge, or consummating, of the holyons, to do the work of the mynistery, to edyfye the body of Christ, until we all come together, in one unity of faith, and knowledge of the son of God, unto the estate of a perfect man, After you measure of the age of the fullness of Christ, that from henceforth, we should not be as babes, wavering, neither should we be carried about with every blast of Doctrine, in the wickedness of men, in the wylynes of them, who go about to deceive us

column7: This place of Saynt Paule most playnelye setteth before our eyes, the authoritie, and gouernemet which our sauiour hath appoynted, to contynue to the ende of the worlde, in his churche, and howe ye Apostles,
column8: This place of Saint Paul most plainly sets before our eyes, the Authority, and gouernemet which our Saviour hath appointed, to continue to the end of the world, in his Church, and how you Apostles,

column7: Prophetes, Euangelistes, Preachers, and teachers, are giuen of Chryst, to his people, to gouerne them.
column8: prophets, Evangelists, Preachers, and Teachers, Are given of Christ, to his people, to govern them.

column7: And therewith al Saynt Paule, in the sayde place, sheweth to what ende, suche gouernement, and authoritie is instituted, it is to wytte, for the spiritual edifieng of the hole body, in the fayth,
column8: And therewith all Saint Paul, in the said place, shows to what end, such government, and Authority is instituted, it is to wit, for the spiritual edifying of the hold body, in the faith,

column7: & for the defense of the hole bodye, from the poyson of heresye.
column8: & for the defence of the hold body, from the poison of heresy.

column7: And in dede no one thing can so muche suppresse heresye, as yf the Authoritie, and gouernment Ecclesiasticall, be accordingly therevnto estemed,
column8: And in deed not one thing can so much suppress heresy, as if the authority, and government Ecclesiastical, be accordingly thereunto esteemed,

column7: & obeyed, as witnesseth Saynte Ciprian, the blessed Martyr, in hys fyrst boke, and third Epystle saieng.
column8: & obeyed, as Witnesseth Faint Cyprian, the blessed Martyr, in his fyrst book, and third Epistle saying.

column7: Neque aliunde hereses obortae sunt, aut nata sunt scismata, quam inde, quod sacerdoti dei non obtemperatur.
column8: Neque aliunde heresies obortae sunt, Or Nata sunt scismata, quam inde, quod Sacerdoti dei non obtemperatur.

column7: Nec unus in ecclesia ad tempus sacerdos,
column8: Nec Unus in Church ad Tempus sacerdos,

column7: & ad tempus iudex, uice Christi cogitatur, cui si secundum magisteria diuina, obtemperaret fraternitas uniuersa, nemo aduersus sacerdotum collegia quicquam moueret.
column8: & ad Tempus Judge, vice Christ cogitatur, cui si secundum magisteria Divine, obtemperaret fraternitas uniuersa, nemo Adversus Sacerdotum collegia quicquam moueret.

column7: That is to saye: Neyther other where, or by other meanes, are heresyes sprong vp, and scismes rysen, than hereof, yt obedience is not gyuen to the preist of God.
column8: That is to say: Neither other where, or by other means, Are heresies sprung up, and Sicms risen, than hereof, that Obedience is not given to the priest of God.

column7: Nor one is considered, or thought, to be in ye churche, for the tyme, the preist, and for the time the iudge, in Christes stede, vntowhich one, yf the hole fraternitie dyd (according to the heauenly commaundements) obeye, no man woulde stirre, or moue anye thinge against the Colleges or copanies of preistes.
column8: Nor one is considered, or Thought, to be in you Church, for the time, the priest, and for the time the judge, in Christ's stead, vntowhich one, if the hold fraternity did (according to the heavenly Commandments) obey, no man would stir, or move any thing against the Colleges or copanies of Priests.

column7: Hereby you may perceyue, that saynt Cypryans coclusion, or iudgemet is, that the gouernment Ecclesiasticall, and especially of one, to be taken, and reputed as Christes vicar, is the best meane, to let and suppresse heresies, and that such one gouernor, is to be obeyed, of all chrysten people, which thinge maye be proued very playnely, and euidently, by the holy scryptures themselues.
column8: Hereby you may perceive, that saint Cyprians conclusion, or Judgement is, that the government Ecclesiastical, and especially of one, to be taken, and reputed as Christ's vicar, is the best mean, to let and suppress heresies, and that such one governor, is to be obeyed, of all christen people, which thing may be proved very plainly, and evidently, by the holy Scriptures themselves.

column7: This processe of Scripture, hath in it, many circumstaunces to be noted.
column8: This process of Scripture, hath in it, many Circumstances to be noted.

column7: The fyrst is, that (other Apostles beynge than present, and amongest them, euen he of whom Christ did euer make very much of, that is to say,
column8: The fyrst is, that (other Apostles being than present, and amongst them, even he of whom christ did ever make very much of, that is to say,

column7: S. Iohn) yet our Sauiour Christ, dyd dyrecte his speach, and talke, but to Peter onelye, signifienge the matter, wherof he dyd speake, to appertayne to Peter chieflye, and pryncipallye, and not in so speciall a sorte, to anye one of the apostles els.
column8: S. John) yet our Saviour christ, did dyrecte his speech, and talk, but to Peter only, signifienge the matter, whereof he did speak, to appertain to Peter chiefly, and principally, and not in so special a sort, to any one of the Apostles Else.

column7: Another, and seconde circumstaunce to be here considered, is that oure sauioure, dyd aske Peter moost earnestly, whether he loued him, more than did the other apostles.
column8: another, and seconde circumstance to be Here considered, is that our Saviour, did ask Peter most earnestly, whither he loved him, more than did the other Apostles.

column7: And the thyrde cyrcumstaunce is, in that Christe dyd commytte both his lambes, and his shepe, vnto hym.
column8: And the Third cyrcumstaunce is, in that Christ did commit both his Lambs, and his sheep, unto him.

column7: These cyrcumstaunces (I saye) and other suche like, well considered, doo conuince, and clearelye proue, that the hyghe charge, ouer all the churche militant, was especially committed, to Peter.
column8: These cyrcumstaunces (I say) and other such like, well considered, do convince, and clearly prove, that the high charge, over all the Church militant, was especially committed, to Peter.

column8: & whatsoever thou shalt loose upon the earth, shall be loosed also in heave.

column7: These wordes of Christ were spoke longe before yt Christe gaue yt other comaudemet to Peter, to feede hys flocke, and that thynge, whyche is perfourmed in the other woordes, is here promysed, in these woordes.
column8: These words of christ were spoke long before that Christ gave that other comaudemet to Peter, to feed his flock, and that thing, which is performed in the other words, is Here promised, in these words.

column8: & whatsoever you shall loose upon the earth, shall losed also in heave If our Saviour christ had not intended to gyve unto Peter a special Authority, above the rest, what need was there to speak this, severally, unto Peter, sing he had spoken it generally to them all before?

column7: All whyche places of scrypture oughte to perswade euery godlye harte, to thynke that oure sauiour dyd gyue vnto sainct Peter, that authoritie, aboue all the reste of the Apostles, vpon hys hoole churche, for an vnytye, and good order, to be kepte in the same.
column8: All which places of scripture ought to persuade every godly heart, to think that our Saviour did gyve unto saint Peter, that Authority, above all the rest of the Apostles, upon his hoole Church, for an vnytye, and good order, to be kept in the same.

column7: And yet for your better contentation herein, you shal here the authorities of the Aunciente fathers in this behalfe.

column7: Chapiter of S. Paules Epistle, to the Romaynes, wryteth thus.
column8: Chapter of S. Paul's Epistle, to the Romans, writes thus.

column7: Petro cum summa rerum de pascendis ouibus traderetur, et super ipsum tanquam super terram fundaretur ecclesia, nullius confessio uirtutis alterius, nisi charitatis exigitur. (That is to saye,) when the hyghest authoritie, or feedinge of christes sheepe, was committed vnto Peter, and the churche was builded vpon hym, as vpon a sure grounde, there was requyred, or exacted of hym, the profession of none other vertue saue onely of charitie.
column8: Peter cum summa rerum de pascendis ouibus traderetur, et super ipsum tanquam super terram fundaretur Church, Nullius confessio uirtutis alterius, nisi charitatis exigitur. (That is to say,) when the highest Authority, or feeding of Christ's sheep, was committed unto Peter, and the Church was built upon him, as upon a sure ground, there was required, or exacted of him, the profession of none other virtue save only of charity.

column7: <NOTE> The blessed martyr, sainct Cipriane, in many places, affyrmeth the same, and amongest other, in hys Epistle written.

column8: Nam dominus primum Peter, super Whom edificauit Church suam, et vnde vnitatis originem Instituit, et ostendit, potestatem istam dedit:

column7: That is to saye. It is manyfest where, and by whome, remission of synnes maye be gyuen, for oure Lorde fyrste vnto Peter (vpon whome he buylded hys churche, and from whome he dyd ordeyne, and shewe, the begynnynge of the vnitye, to procede) dyd gyue that power, or authoritie.
column8: That is to say. It is manifest where, and by whom, remission of Sins may be given, for our Lord First unto Peter (upon whom he builded his Church, and from whom he did ordain, and show, the beginning of the unity, to proceed) did gyve that power, or Authority.

column7: And in the same Epistle, (within a whyle after) he sayeth.
column8: And in the same Epistle, (within a while After) he Saith.

column7: Ecclesiam, que vna est, fundauit super vnum, that is to saye,
column8: Church, que Una est, fundauit super One, that is to say,

column7: He dyd founde his churche, which is but one, vpon one.
column8: He did found his Church, which is but one, upon one.

column7: Sainct Basyll, in hys booke against Tauonius writeth thus Per hanc vocem intelligimus Ionae filium, qui fuit ex Bethsaida,
column8: Saint Basil, in his book against Tavonius Writeth thus Per hanc vocem intelligimus Jonah Son, qui fuit ex Bethsaida,

column7: Andreae fratrem, qui ex piscatore, in Apostolatus ministerium vocatus est Qui quoniam fide praestabat, ecclesiae in se aedificationem suscepit.
column8: Andrew fratrem, qui ex Piscatore, in Apostolatus ministerium Vocatus est Qui quoniam fide praestabat, ecclesiae in se aedificationem suscepit.

column7: That is to saye, by this voice, we vnderstade the sonne of Ionas, which was of Bethsaida, the brother of Andrewe, which sonne of Ionas was called from a fysher, to the ministerye of the Apostleshyp and bycause he excelled in faith, he had the churche buylded vpon hym.
column8: That is to say, by this voice, we vnderstade the son of Jonah, which was of Bethsaida, the brother of Andrew, which son of Jonah was called from a fisher, to the Ministry of the Apostleship and Because he excelled in faith, he had the Church builded upon him.

column7: Sainct Ambrose in hys fourthe sermon sayeth.
column8: Saint Ambrose in his Fourth sermon Saith.

column7: Petrus denique pro soliditate deuotionis, ecclesiarum petra dicitur, sicut ait dominus.
column8: Peter denique Pro soliditate deuotionis, ecclesiarum Petra dicitur, sicut ait dominus.

column7: Tu es petrus, et super hanc petram aedificabo ecclesiam meam.
column8: Tu es Peter, et super hanc Petram Aedificabo Church meam.

column7: Petra enim dicitur, quod primus in nationibus fidei fundamenta posuerit, et tanquam saxum immobile, totius operis Christiani compagem molemque contineat (That is to saye,) Fynally, or for a conclusion,
column8: Petra enim dicitur, quod primus in nationibus fidei Fundamenta posuerit, et tanquam saxum immobile, totius operis Christians compagem molemque contineat (That is to say,) Finally, or for a conclusion,

column7: Peter, for the soundenes, or substancialnes of his deuotion, is called the rocke of the churches, as oure Lorde sayeth Thou arte Peter, or of a rocke, and vpon this rocke wil I buylde my churche.
column8: Peter, for the soundenes, or substancialnes of his devotion, is called the rock of the Churches, as our Lord Saith Thou art Peter, or of a rock, and upon this rock will I build my Church.

column7: In dede he is called a rocke, bicause he was the fyrste that did laye the foundation of faythe amongest the gentiles,
column8: In deed he is called a rock, Because he was the First that did say the Foundation of faith amongst the Gentiles,

column7: & as a stone, or a rocke, that cannot be moued, he doeth conteine or kepe, the frame, and weight of the hole christen woorke.
column8: & as a stone, or a rock, that cannot be moved, he doth contain or keep, the frame, and weight of the hold christen work.

column7: S. Augustine hath the lyke in his syxe and twenty sermon, de sanctis, and in his.xvi. sermon de tempore, but moost notably in hys. 124. sermon de tempore, where he maketh a large processe of sainct Peter, and emogest other thinges, speakyng of Peters denial of his maister, he wryteth thus of hym.
column8: S. Augustine hath the like in his syxe and twenty sermon, de sanctis, and in his xvi sermon de tempore, but most notably in his. 124. sermon de tempore, where he makes a large process of saint Peter, and emogest other things, speaking of Peter's denial of his master, he writes thus of him.

column7: Totius corporis morbum in ipso capite curat ecclesie, et in ipso vertice componit membrorum omnium sanitatem,
column8: Totius corporis morbum in ipso capite curate Churches, et in ipso vertice componit Members omnium sanitatem,

column7: That is to saye, He (meanyng Christ) doeth cure in the very heade of the churche (meaning Peter) the dysease, of the hole body, and in the very crowne, or toppe of the head, he frameth the healthe of all the members.
column8: That is to say, He (meaning christ) doth cure in the very head of the Church (meaning Peter) the disease, of the hold body, and in the very crown, or top of the head, he frameth the health of all the members.

column7: Here ommyttynge infynite, other authorities of the aunciente fathers, touchynge the primacye, or hyghest authoritie ecclesiasticall, to haue bene gyuen vnto sainct Peter of our sauiour Christ hym selfe,
column8: Here ommyttynge infinite, other authorities of the ancient Father's, touching the primacy, or highest Authority ecclesiastical, to have be given unto saint Peter of our Saviour christ him self,

column7: I exhorte you in consideration, partely of these testimonyes, some wherof are taken out of the very scripture, somme out of the aunciente and famous doctours of the churche, and partly, and mooste especially, in consyderation of the cosent of the hole catholike church herein, nothing to doute in this matter, but yt the holy Apostle S.
column8: I exhort you in consideration, partly of these testimonies, Some whereof Are taken out of the very scripture, sum out of the ancient and famous Doctors of the Church, and partly, and most especially, in consideration of the cosent of the hold catholic Church herein, nothing to doubt in this matter, but that the holy Apostle S.

column7: Peter was Christes vicar on earthe, and had hygher, and more authoritye generall, then anye one of the Apostles els, and that the speciall purpose, why that Christ woulde haue suche authoritie to be in one ma, was,
column8: Peter was Christ's vicar on earth, and had higher, and more Authority general, then any one of the Apostles Else, and that the special purpose, why that christ would have such Authority to be in one ma, was,

column7: & is, for the preseruation of vnitie in his church, whyche churche, is but one, and thus muche for thys tyme, shall nowe suffice you.
column8: & is, for the preservation of unity in his Church, which Church, is but one, and thus much for this time, shall now suffice you.

column7: In the nexte homely, you shall heare further of this matter.
column8: In the Next homely, you shall hear further of this matter.
