column8: your Lord god shall stir up among you of your own brethren a Prophet like unto me,

column7: & ye shall heare hym:
column8: & you shall hear him:

column7: and so Iohn answered truely, that he was not that prophete.
column8: and so John answered truly, that he was not that Prophet.

column7: For Christ hym self was he.
column8: For christ him self was he.

column7: They saye therfore vnto him.
column8: They say Therefore unto him.

column7: What art thou? that we may gyue an answere to them that sent vs.
column8: What art thou? that we may gyve an answer to them that sent us

column7: What sayest thou of thy selfe.
column8: What Sayest thou of thy self.

column7: These preestes & Leuites thought them selfe cunnynge in scripture, that if there had ben any mention made therein of the commynge of Iohn, they sholde haue knowen. wherfore now they say vnto hym:
column8: These Priests & Levites Thought them self cunning in scripture, that if there had been any mention made therein of the coming of John, they should have known. Wherefore now they say unto him:

column7: what sayeste thou of thy selfe:
column8: what Sayest thou of thy self:

column7: as who wolde saye: scripture dothe make no mention of the:
column8: as who would say: scripture doth make no mention of thee:

column7: therfore thou must declare thy selfe what thou art, suche is the learnynge & wysdome of man, when he stadeth in his owne conceyt, and thinketh that he can coprehende all mysteries, that then it turneth vnto very folyshnes. For Infatuauit dens sapientiam huius mundi & intellig^ ^tiam intelligentiu reiecit.
column8: Therefore thou must declare thy self what thou art, such is the learning & Wisdom of man, when he stadeth in his own conceit, and Thinketh that he can coprehende all Mysteres, that then it turns unto very foolishness. For Infatuauit dens sapientiam Huius mundi & intellig^ ^tiam intelligentiu reiecit.

column7: God hath made folysh the wysedome of this worlde, and hath reiected and cast away the learnynge of them that thinke them selues lerned, and do not acknowledge and rendre dew thankes vnto hym, that is the gyuer therof.
column8: God hath made foolish the Wisdom of this world, and hath rejected and cast away the learning of them that think them selves learned, and do not acknowledge and render due thanks unto him, that is the gyuer thereof.

column7: As it maye appere in these preestes, and Leuites, whiche weare cast in theyr owne turne:
column8: As it may appear in these Priests, and Levites, which wear cast in their own turn:

column7: for Ihon in his aunswere doth bewraye theyr ignoraunce, shewynge that Isai the prophete had prophesied of his commynge.
column8: for John in his answer does bewray their ignorance, show that Isaiah the Prophet had prophesied of his coming.

column7: He answereth therfore and faith.
column8: He Answers Therefore and faith.

column7: I am the voyce of a ^^ye^ in wyldernes, to prepare the waye of our lorde, as I faithe prophete sayde.
column8: I am the voice of a ye^ in Wilderness, to prepare the Way of our lord, as I faith Prophet said.

column7: I sayde before, that Iohn was no reede, that is not vnconstant, as it doth heare appere more playnly for he doth continewe stedfastlye in the humilitie and lowelynes of spirite, which in his aunswere maketh no mention of his owne worthines, althoughe he were more excellent then a prophete,
column8: I said before, that John was no reed, that is not unconstant, as it does hear appear more plainly for he does continue steadfastly in the humility and lowelynes of Spirit, which in his answer makes no mention of his own worthiness, although he were more excellent then a Prophet,

column7: <NOTE> & none more excellent then he amogest the children of wome.
column8: & none more excellent then he Amongst the children of wome.

column7: Neither he speketh of the nobilitie of his stocke:
column8: Neither he Speaketh of the Nobilt of his stock:

column7: although he was come of a greate stocke in dead, but he telleth what he is by offyce, forgettynge (as saynt Paule sayth) those thinges that were behinde him,
column8: although he was come of a great stock in dead, but he Telleth what he is by office, forgetting (as saint Paul say) those things that were behind him,

column7: <NOTE> loking all together at those thynges that were before him, he foloweth accordynge to the marke that was set him vp:
column8: looking all together At those things that were before him, he Followeth according to the mark that was Set him up:

column7: that he may get the rewarde of the heuenly vocation:
column8: that he may get the reward of the heavenly vocation:

column7: which less^^: I wolde to god yt all men in these dayes wolde learne of Iohn,
column8: which less^^: I would to god that all men in these days would Learn of John,

column7: & specially common offycers, which as it may be thought, be altogether vnlyke vnto Iohn for he (that he might more faithfully and truely execute his offyce, according to the wyl of his mayster) dyd forsake his parentes, wt their hole familie, yea & his patrimonie if that he sholde haue had any, as it is most like he sholde, he dyd also forsake and flye from idelnes, and the rest of the bodye, with delycate fare, and gorgious apparel he dyd take vpon him greate paynes, and labours, lyuynge hardly clothed in heare,
column8: & specially Common Officers, which as it may be Thought, be altogether unlike unto John for he (that he might more faithfully and truly execute his office, according to the will of his master) did forsake his Parents, with their hold family, yea & his patrimony if that he should have had any, as it is most like he should, he did also forsake and fly from idleness, and the rest of the body, with delicate fare, and gorgeous apparel he did take upon him great pains, and labours, living hardly clothed in hear,

column7: <NOTE> he dyd lyberallye and boldlye reprehende offenders of all sortes, he hunted after the fauour of no manne, nor feared no mans threatnynges, but officers in these our dayes, be of a contrarye sorte, for they doo not regarde nor requyre an office, but for this ende, that they may promote and exalte their frendes, enlarge theyr patrimonie, lyue idely, fare dylycately, be appareled gorgiously,
column8: he did liberally and boldly reprehend offenders of all sorts, he hunted After the favour of no man, nor feared no men threatnynges, but Officers in these our days, be of a contrary sort, for they do not regard nor require an office, but for this end, that they may promote and exalt their Friends, enlarge their patrimony, live idly, fare dylycately, be appareled gorgeously,

column7: & to bringe these thynges to pas, they flatter greate menne, the contempne, ye and polle poore men, if a ryche man of any parte do his dewtie, that he is commaunded to do, of his lorde, or kynge, by them he shalbe praysed, yea and well rewarded, but if the poore man do it with neuer so greate dylygence, there shall no worde be spoken of it:
column8: & to bring these things to pass, they flatter great men, the contemn, you and Poll poor men, if a rich man of any part do his duty, that he is commanded to do, of his lord, or King, by them he shall praised, yea and well rewarded, but if the poor man do it with never so great diligence, there shall no word be spoken of it:

column7: agayne if the poore man therin offende, he shall be streyghtly punyshed, if the riche man omitte the hole, eyther the offycers mouthes shalbe stopped with a bribe, or els for feare of displeasure, they wyll let it slyp, so that in them it shall not be punysshed:
column8: again if the poor man therein offend, he shall be streightly punished, if the rich man omit the hold, either the Officers mouths shall stopped with a bribe, or Else for Fear of displeasure, they will let it slip, so that in them it shall not be punished:

column7: these officers be be suche as Dauyd speakes on in his spalme, where he sayth,
column8: these Officers be be such as David speaks on in his spalme, where he say,

column7: Homo cum in honore esset, non intellexit coparatus est rumentis insipientibus:
column8: Homo cum in honore esset, non intellexit coparatus est rumentis insipientibus:

column7: & similis factus est illis.
column8: & Similis factus est illis.

column7: Man when he was promoted vnto dignite or offyce dyd not considre him selfe, he is compared to folyshe brute beastes, and he is euen lyke vnto the in deade, for as the brute beaste doth neither remember thynges past, nor consyder thinges to come but gyue them selues altogether to these thinges that be presente, euen soo these officers do, for they neyther remembre wherof they be come, nor what they haue ben, nor yet what they may come to, if they abuse their office, and their mayster take dyspleasure with them, but loke what thinge doth playst them for the tyme, and that they enbrace:
column8: Man when he was promoted unto dignity or office did not Consider him self, he is compared to foolish brutus beasts, and he is even like unto thee in dead, for as the brutus beast does neither Remember things past, nor Consider things to come but gyve them selves altogether to these things that be present, even so these Officers do, for they neither Remember whereof they be come, nor what they have been, nor yet what they may come to, if they abuse their office, and their master take displeasure with them, but look what thing does playst them for the time, and that they enbrace:

column7: And wel they may be likened vnto the noughtie seruaunt ye christ speaketh of which when his mayster had made ouerseer of his householde,
column8: And well they may be likened unto the naughty servant you Christ speaks of which when his master had made overseer of his household,

column7: <NOTE> and was gon vnto a straunge contrye, sayd with hym self:
column8: and was gone unto a strange country, said with him self:

column7: It wyl belong or my mayster come home agayne, and therefore he begonne to beate his fellow seruauntes, to eate and drincke with dronckerdes, euen so these offycers do thinke with them selues, that theyr actes can not come to ye eares of their lorde, or kynge, but let them take hede, for as it is a comon sayenge.
column8: It will belong or my master come home again, and Therefore he begun to beat his fellow Servants, to eat and drink with dronckerdes, even so these Officers do think with them selves, that their acts can not come to you ears of their lord, or King, but let them take heed, for as it is a Common saying.

column7: Multae sunt Regum autes, et oculi.
column8: Multitude sunt Regum autes, et oculi.

column7: Kynges haue manye eares, and eyes, and althoughe yt they can keape their factes close from the eares of a mortall kynge or lorde, yet they can not hyde the from him that is immortal:
column8: Kings have many ears, and eyes, and although that they can keape their facts close from the ears of a Mortal King or lord, yet they can not hide thee from him that is immortal:

column7: <NOTE> whose countenaunce is ouer all euell doers.
column8: whose countenance is over all evil doers.

column7: And he wyll come in that day that they leest weane, and that houre that they knowe not,
column8: And he will come in that day that they least wean, and that hour that they know not,

column7: <NOTE> and wyll cut them into peces and gyue them theyr rewarde, wt ypocrites, where shalbe waylynge ang knasshynge of tethe learne therfore you offycers, of Iohn to forget those thinges that be behynde you, that is the world with the pompe therof, and set youre eyes onelye vppon those thinges that be before you, that is your dewtie, and that that doth pertayne to the faythfull performynge of your offices.
column8: and will Cut them into Pieces and gyve them their reward, with Hypocrites, where shall wailing ang knasshynge of teeth Learn Therefore you Officers, of John to forget those things that be behind you, that is the world with the pomp thereof, and Set your eyes only upon those things that be before you, that is your duty, and that that does pertain to the faithful performing of your Offices.

column7: And it shalbe sayd vnto euery one of you well thou faythfull and good seruant,
column8: And it shall said unto every one of you well thou faithful and good servant,

column7: <NOTE> thou hast ben faythfull ouer a fewe thinges,
column8: thou hast been faithful over a few things,

column7: I shall constitute ye ouer many entre into the ioye of thy mayster for only that thynge dyd Iohn regarde:
column8: I shall constitute you over many entre into the joy of thy master for only that thing did John regard:

column7: wherefore ^e saith, that he is the voyce of a cryer in wyldernes.
column8: Wherefore e Says, that he is the voice of a crier in Wilderness.

column7: Christ in the gospell sayth vnto his Apostles, whe he sent them of preachynge, it shal not be you that shall speake, but the spyryte of my father shall speake in you, lykewise dauyd in his spalmes sayth.
column8: christ in the gospel say unto his Apostles, when he sent them of preaching, it shall not be you that shall speak, but the Spirit of my father shall speak in you, likewise David in his spalmes say.

column7: Lingua mea calamus scribae, velociter scribentis.
column8: Lingua mea calamus Scribae, Velociter scribentis.

column7: My tonge is the penne of a writer that writeth fast, signifyenge that his psalmes were not his, but they were the worke of the holy ghost:
column8: My tongue is the pen of a writer that Writeth fast, signifyenge that his psalms were not his, but they were the work of the holy ghost:

column7: so Iohn here sayth he is the voyce of a cryer, as and if he sholde saye,
column8: so John Here say he is the voice of a crier, as and if he should say,

column7: I speake nothynge of myne owne heade, but I speake those thinges that be commaunded me of my mayster to speake, lyberally vtterynge those thinges that my commission wylleth me to speake, and nothinge ther vnto addynge.
column8: I speak nothing of mine own head, but I speak those things that be commanded me of my master to speak, liberally uttering those things that my commission willeth me to speak, and nothing there unto adding.

column7: Wherfore if you reiecte my sayinge ye do not reiecte me, but rather hym that speaketh in me, for I am but a voyce whereby as by an instrument Christ doth declare vnto you his wyll.
column8: Wherefore if you reject my saying you do not reject me, but rather him that speaks in me, for I am but a voice whereby as by an Instrument christ does declare unto you his will.

column7: A voyce of * selfe is a sounde that goeth before the worde, so that if the worde do not folowe, the voyce is a vayne thinge, as it were brasse soundyng or a Cymball tincklynge.
column8: A voice of * self is a sound that Goes before the word, so that if the word do not follow, the voice is a vain thing, as it were brass sounding or a Cymbal tincklynge.

column7: And so was Iohn the voyce of Christ the euerlastynge worde of the father without whom Iohn sholde haue ben a vayne thinge, but now that the worde Christ dyd folowe the voyce is not vayne, but rather as Dauyd saith.
column8: And so was John the voice of christ the everlasting word of the father without whom John should have been a vain thing, but now that the word christ did follow the voice is not vain, but rather as David Says.

column7: Vox domini in virtute vox domini in magnificentia.
column8: Vox domini in virtute vox domini in Magnificence.

column7: <NOTE> The voyce of our Lorde is in vertue ye voyce of our Lorde is in pythe,
column8: The voice of our Lord is in virtue you voice of our Lord is in pythe,

column7: & in strength, the voyce of the lorde that pulleth downe the high trees of Libanus, whiche in dead Iohn dydde when he pulled downe the stoute hartes of the Iewes, so that by penaunce, they weare contente to be baptised of hym, yet it was not Iohn that dyd it, but it was he which stode the last great daye, of the feast and cryed sayenge,
column8: & in strength, the voice of the lord that pulls down the high trees of Lebanon, which in dead John did when he pulled down the stout hearts of the Jews, so that by penance, they wear content to be baptised of him, yet it was not John that did it, but it was he which stood the last great day, of the feast and cried saying,

column7: <NOTE> yf any man be a thyrste let him come vnto me, and drincke:
column8: if any man be a thirst let him come unto me, and drink:

column7: the Euangelyst saith that he cryed, whiche was bicause he wolde haue euery man to heare him, that euery man might be saued, <NOTE> & come to knoweledge of the truth, for it is not his wyl that any shold perysh.
column8: the Evangelist Says that he cried, which was Because he would have every man to hear him, that every man might be saved, & come to knowledge of the truth, for it is not his will that any should perish.

column7: Wherefore they erre whiche say, that of absolute necessite some must nedes be damned, for saynt Paule sayth.
column8: Wherefore they err which say, that of absolute necessity Some must needs be damned, for saint Paul say.

column7: Periunt, pro eo quod dilectionem veritatis non receperunt, in hoc vt salui fierent.
column8: Periunt, Pro eo quod dilectionem veritatis non receperunt, in hoc vt salui fierent.

column7: They do perishe, bicause they receiued not the loue of ye trueth, ye they myght haue bene saued, but peraduenture some wyll obiecte, and saye if he wolde haue euerye man saued then they shalbe saued for who can resiste his wyll:
column8: They do perish, Because they received not the love of you truth, you they might have be saved, but Peradventure Some will Object, and say if he would have every man saved then they shall saved for who can resist his will:

column7: vnto this is to be aunswered that we must consydre two wylles to be in in god, a wyll that goeth before & an other that cometh after:
column8: unto this is to be answered that we must Consider two wills to be in in god, a will that Goes before & an other that comes After:

column7: by his fyrste wyll he wolde haue all men to walke in his commaundementes:
column8: by his First will he would have all men to walk in his Commandments:

column7: and so come to euerlastynge lyfe, but when he seeth the vntowardnes of those that wyll folow their owne lustes, and wyll not obey his commaundementes, then by his later wyl he wyl haue them punished accordinge to their desertes:
column8: and so come to everlasting life, but when he sees the untowardness of those that will follow their own lusts, and will not obey his Commandments, then by his later will he will have them punished according to their deserts:

column7: as for an exemple. A man setteth a tree in his garden, wyllyng that it shall growe there manye yeares for to bringe forth fruyte, now within fewe yeares when he seeth that it wyll brynge forthe none, he commaundeth by and by contrary to his first wyll, to cutte it downe sayeng, where vnto doth it occupye the grounde in vayne.
column8: as for an exemple. A man sets a tree in his garden, willing that it shall grow there many Years for to bring forth fruit, now within few Years when he sees that it will bring forth none, he commandeth by and by contrary to his First will, to Cut it down saying, where unto does it occupy the ground in vain.

column7: It is not vnlike vnto this, that is writen in the psalme.
column8: It is not unlike unto this, that is written in the psalm.

column7: Vineam de Egipto transtulisti.
column8: Vineam de Egypt transtulisti.

column7: Thou haste brought out of Egypte a vine.
column8: Thou haste brought out of Egypt a vine.

column7: Thou haste caste out Gentyles,
column8: Thou haste cast out Gentiles,

column7: & planted it, whiche vine (as the Psalmis sheweth to be breefe) for a tyme dyd greatly encrease and growe, so that the shadowe therof dyd couer the hylles, but after the hedge was pulled downe, and the wylde beastes did destroye it, and why,
column8: & planted it, which vine (as the Psalms shows to be brief) for a time did greatly increase and grow, so that the shadow thereof did cover the hills, but After the hedge was pulled down, and the wild beasts did destroy it, and why,

column7: <NOTE> but bycause (as Esaie sayth) he loked yt it sholde haue brought grapes & it brought out thornes, so that the fault was in it, and not in him:
column8: but Because (as Isaiah say) he looked that it should have brought grapes & it brought out thorns, so that the fault was in it, and not in him:

column7: for god doth aske by Esaie and saythe:
column8: for god does ask by Isaiah and say:

column7: what sholde I haue done to my vineyard, that I haue not done:
column8: what should I have done to my vineyard, that I have not done:

column7: truly nothynge. For as I haue sayde, he cryeth vnto vs,
column8: truly nothing. For as I have said, he Cries unto us,

column7: wyllynge euery manne to amende his lyfe, and so to be saued.
column8: willing every man to amend his life, and so to be saved.

column7: Yea he hath cryed in olde tyme by his prophettes, after by hym selfe, his Apostels and disciples, and styll crieth vnto this daye, by his preachers, but we stoppe oure eares & wyll not heare, we be muche lyke vnto the people of London, which do heare after a sorte.
column8: Yea he hath cried in old time by his Prophets, After by him self, his Apostles and Disciples, and still cries unto this day, by his Preachers, but we stop our ears & will not hear, we be much like unto the people of London, which do hear After a sort.

column7: The belles of Paules, when they rynge to Matyns at mydnight, the belles do sounde in theyr eares, yet they wyll not ryse, but rather wyl tourne them on thother syde, and slepe agayne, for they thynke the daye is not as yet neare, euen soo do we heare the preachers of god, their voyce dothe sounde in oure eares, but we will not arise from our noughty lyfe:
column8: The Bells of Paul's, when they ring to Matins At midnight, the Bells do sound in their ears, yet they will not rise, but rather will turn them on tother side, and sleep again, for they think the day is not as yet near, even so do we hear the Preachers of god, their voice doth sound in our ears, but we will not arise from our naughty life:

column7: but styll slepe in synne thinkynge that the daye doth not drawe neare, when as we shall make accompte of our actes, but let vs not deceyue our selues, for saynt Paule sayth, it is tyme for vs to ryse from slepe, the night is past and the day draweth neare Nowe if the day were neare in the tyme of saynt Paule, that is.xv. hundreth yeare a goo we maye well thinke that it is nowe verye neare, lette vs therfore open oure eares and heare him cryenge:
column8: but still sleep in sin thinking that the day does not draw near, when as we shall make accompt of our acts, but let us not deceive our selves, for saint Paul say, it is time for us to rise from sleep, the night is past and the day draws near Now if the day were near in the time of saint Paul, that is xv Hundredth year a goo we may well think that it is now very near, let us Therefore open our ears and hear him crying:

column7: for yf we wyll not, we shall herafter crye, and he wyll not heare vs, but there shalbe other, that is to saye our noughty lyfe, and they vnto whom we haue done iniurye and wronge, accusynge vs, and they shalbe hearde. wherfore if we wyll stoppe the eares of god, that he shall not here oure accusars, we must here him when he cryeth, and also crye diligentely vnto hym by prayer, as Dauyd doth witnes of hym selfe that he dyd, sayenge.
column8: for if we will not, we shall hereafter cry, and he will not hear us, but there shall other, that is to say our naughty life, and they unto whom we have done injury and wrong, accusing us, and they shall heard. Wherefore if we will stop the ears of god, that he shall not Here our accusars, we must hear him when he Cries, and also cry diligently unto him by prayer, as David does witness of him self that he did, saying.

column7: De profundis clamaui ad te domine.
column8: De profundis clamaui ad te domine.

column7: <NOTE> Lord I haue cryed vnto the from the bothome of my harte,
column8: Lord I have cried unto thee from the bothome of my heart,

column7: Lorde heare my voyce: and agayn.
column8: Lord hear my voice: and again.

column7: Labo raui clamans, I haue taken greate paynes in cryenge, so that I am horse while I trust in my lorde.
column8: Labo raui Clamans, I have taken great pains in crying, so that I am horse while I trust in my lord.

column7: But euen as we wyll not heare hym when he cryeth, so we be very neglygent in cryinge agayne to him.
column8: But even as we will not hear him when he Cries, so we be very negligent in crying again to him.

column7: For surely I do thinke that syns the begynnynge of Christes churche, there was neuer so lyttle prayer vsed among christen men, wherfore it may be well sayd vnto vs, that saynt Iames sayde vnto those that he wrote his epystle vnto, ye desyre and ye haue not, that ye desyre, ye enuye and ye haue indignation one towardes an other and ye can not obteigne, ye fyght, ye warre, and haue not, because ye aske it not, ye aske and receyue not bycause ye aske it amysse, that ye maye spende in your voluptuousnes.
column8: For surely I do think that Sins the beginning of Christ's Church, there was never so little prayer used among christian men, Wherefore it may be well said unto us, that saint James said unto those that he wrote his epistle unto, you desire and you have not, that you desire, you envy and you have Indignation one towards an other and you can not obteigne, you fight, you war, and have not, Because you ask it not, you ask and receive not Because you ask it amiss, that you may spend in your voluptuousness.

column7: To stande long in this thing, the tyme wyll not suffre me, but onlye this I wyll saye, that where as we stande, neade of many thynges all ready, we shall stande nede of moo:
column8: To stand long in this thing, the time will not suffer me, but only this I will say, that where as we stand, neade of many things all ready, we shall stand need of moo:

column7: if we wyll not heare hym crye and be dylygente in cryenge agayne to hym:
column8: if we will not hear him cry and be dylygente in crying again to him:

column7: and that not onelye in mouthe, but also in harte, yea and in lyfe:
column8: and that not only in Mouth, but also in heart, yea and in life:

column7: For what shall it proffytte vs to call god oure father, yf we wyll not vse oure selues as louynge chyldren.
column8: For what shall it proffytte us to call god our father, if we will not use our selves as loving children.

column7: What shall it auayle vs, to desyre hym to delyuer vs from all euell, when as we oure selues wyllyngely, do fall hedlynges in to all wyckednesse.
column8: What shall it avail us, to desire him to deliver us from all evil, when as we our selves willingly, do fallen hedlynges in to all wickedness.

column7: But nowe lette vs heare what he cryeth by Iohn, he cryeth thus:
column8: But now let us hear what he Cries by John, he Cries thus:

column7: prepare and make readye the waye of oure Lorde.
column8: prepare and make ready the Way of our Lord.

column7: There be two wayes of our Lord, one is, whereby he commethe vnto vs, an other is whereby we goo vnto hym:
column8: There be two ways of our Lord, one is, whereby he cometh unto us, an other is whereby we goo unto him:

column7: and bothe these muste be prepared of vs, after that we haue hard his voyce, as touchinge the fyrste, the condycyon and state of man is so myserable,
column8: and both these must be prepared of us, After that we have heard his voice, as touching the First, the condition and state of man is so miserable,

column7: <NOTE> that he of hym selfe can not ones thyncke of the preparynge of this waye, nor of goynge vnto god.
column8: that he of him self can not ones think of the preparing of this Way, nor of going unto god.

column7: But the loue, mercy, and gentylnesse of god towarde man, is so great, that he wyllynglye of hym selfe dothe come vnto vs:
column8: But the love, mercy, and gentleness of god toward man, is so great, that he willingly of him self doth come unto us:

column7: yea beynge his extreme enemyes, serchynge yf he can haue anye entraunce into our hertes, but yet althoughe that he commeth of his owne free wylle vnto vs withoute all oure desertes, we muste molyfye, yea and open our hartes, that he maye haue enteraunce, or elles he wyll departe agayne:
column8: yea being his extreme enemies, searching if he can have any Entrance into our herts, but yet although that he comes of his own free will unto us without all our deserts, we must molyfye, yea and open our hearts, that he may have Entrance, or Else he will depart again:

column7: he saythe him selfe. Ecce sto ad ostium,
column8: he say him self. Ecce Sto ad ostium,

column7: & pulso. Beholde I stande at the doore, and I knocke, and yf anye manne wyll heare my voyce, and open the doore I wyll come into hym, and I wyl suppe with him.
column8: & pulso. Behold I stand At the door, and I knock, and if any man will hear my voice, and open the door I will come into him, and I will sup with him.

column7: Marke he sayeth he standeth at the doore of oure hartes, and knocketh, but nowe it is oure parte, to heare his voyce, and open oure doores, for if we so do he wyll (as he sayth) come in, yf we wyll not, he wyl not brust the doores, and come in, whether we wyll or no, for he wyll saue no man agaynst hys wyll.
column8: Mark he Saith he Stands At the door of our hearts, and knocketh, but now it is our part, to hear his voice, and open our doors, for if we so do he will (as he say) come in, if we will not, he will not burst the doors, and come in, whither we will or no, for he will save no man against his will.

column7: But nowe it is necessarye to knowe howe we sholde open this doore, this same Iohn dothe teache vs sayenge. Penitentiam agite vitae prioris.
column8: But now it is necessary to know how we should open this door, this same John doth teach us saying. Penitentiam Agitate vitae prioris.

column7: Do penaunce for youre olde lyfe, for penaunce, yf it be perfaict with the three partes whiche be well ynoughe knowen,
column8: Do penance for your old life, for penance, if it be perfaict with the three parts which be well enough known,

column7: Contrycyon, confessyon, and satysfactyon.
column8: Contrition, Confessi, and satysfactyon.

column7: It is of suche streyngthe, that by Chryste, it makethe a manne of the seruaunte and bondeman of the deuyll, the sonne and heyre of god and fellowe heyre with Christ,
column8: It is of such streyngthe, that by Christ, it maketh a man of the servant and bondman of the Devil, the son and heir of god and fellow heir with christ,

column7: <NOTE> it makethe also (yf that by it hye hylles be pulled downe, and lowe places be exalted, yf croked wayes be made streyghte, and sharpe wayes made playne) the harte of man of a fylthye lake, or denne of synne and the deuyll, a temple and dwellyng place of the holye Ghoste.
column8: it maketh also (if that by it high hills be pulled down, and low places be exalted, if crooked ways be made straight, and sharp ways made plain) the heart of man of a filthy lake, or den of sin and the Devil, a temple and Dwelling place of the holy Ghost.

column7: But nowe when as this way is thus prepared by penauce we must beware & take hede yt we do not retourne agayne into Egipt, but rather remember what we be now become, yt is that we be made the temple of the holye ghost whiche temple if any manne prophane, god wyll destroye him, <NOTE> we must therfore nowe streight enter into the other waye, whiche is spoken of in the Psalme:
column8: But now when as this Way is thus prepared by penance we must beware & take heed that we do not return again into Egypt, but rather Remember what we be now become, that is that we be made the temple of the holy ghost which temple if any man profane, god will destroy him, we must Therefore now straight enter into the other Way, which is spoken of in the Psalm:

column7: Beati immaculati in via.
column8: Beati immaculati in via.

column7: Blissed be they that be vndefyled in the waye, that is to saye, that walke in the way of our Lorde, in the latter ende of this verse, it dothe appere bothe what the way is, and also how we shold vse our selues in it.
column8: Blessed be they that be undefiled in the Way, that is to say, that walk in the Way of our Lord, in the latter end of this verse, it doth appear both what the Way is, and also how we should use our selves in it.

column7: Fyrst the way is ye lawe or comaundementes of god, whiche yf we kepe will bryng vs to the heuely kyngdome where as Christ is gon before to prepare vs a place, but we muste marke that the Psalmiste saith, that we must walke in the waye, for we be straungers & haue not here a bydynge citie,
column8: Fyrst the Way is the law or Commandments of god, which if we keep will bring us to the heuely Kingdom where as christ is gone before to prepare us a place, but we must mark that the Psalmist Says, that we must walk in the Way, for we be Strangers & have not Here a biding City,

column7: <NOTE> but we loke after one to come:
column8: but we look After one to come:

column7: wherfore we muste not stande styll, but rather walke and go forther from vertue to vertue.
column8: Wherefore we must not stand still, but rather walk and go further from virtue to virtue.

column7: Now if the tyme wold suffre me,
column8: Now if the time would suffer me,

column7: I wolde speake here of the fashyons of men now in these dayes, for many there be, as I thynke whiche do not walke in this way, but do rune as it were in a circuit, and maye be lykened to a dogge that runneth in a whele, whiche styll goeth and laboreth,
column8: I would speak Here of the fashions of men now in these days, for many there be, as I think which do not walk in this Way, but do rune as it were in a circuit, and may be likened to a dog that Runneth in a wheel, which still Goes and Laboureth,

column7: & when he maketh an ende, he is euen where he begonne.
column8: & when he makes an end, he is even where he begun.

column7: And so I do feare that men do in these dayes:
column8: And so I do Fear that men do in these days:

column7: theyr tyme goeth, and they growe in age, and yet loke how they lyued the laste yeare,
column8: their time Goes, and they grow in age, and yet look how they lived the laste year,

column7: & euen so they lyue this yeare, and so wyll do the nexte:
column8: & even so they live this year, and so will do the Next:

column7: nothyng at all increasynge in vertue nor godlynes, but do as vittelars vse to do, whiche take bread and drincke of bakers and brewers, to a daye, not payenge money in hande, but tayle with them:
column8: nothing At all increasing in virtue nor godliness, but do as vittelars use to do, which take bred and drink of bakers and brewers, to a day, not payenge money in hand, but tail with them:

column7: & when the day of payment cometh, they paye theyr money,
column8: & when the day of payment comes, they pay their money,

column7: & strike of the olde tayles, and begynne agayne to tayle of newe.
column8: & strike of the old tails, and begin again to tail of new.

column7: And eue so do we:
column8: And eve so do we:

column7: we be very bold with god all the yeare longe, and tayle with hym tyll lente comme:
column8: we be very bold with god all the year long, and tail with him till Lente comme:

column7: and then we be confessed, kepynge abstinence for a tyme, and receyue the holy Sacrament, and so sone as Easter is past, we begyn euen to tayle of newe, and fall agayne to our olde kynde of lyuyng.
column8: and then we be confessed, keeping abstinence for a time, and receive the holy Sacrament, and so soon as Easter is past, we begin even to tail of new, and fallen again to our old kind of living.

column7: But such be not these that Dauid called in this place, happy:
column8: But such be not these that David called in this place, happy:

column7: for they do not walke vndefyled in this way.
column8: for they do not walk undefiled in this Way.

column7: This same Dauid doth teache in an other place saieng:
column8: This same David does teach in an other place saying:

column7: Si mei dominati non fuerint tunc immaculatus ero:
column8: Si mei dominati non fuerint tunc immaculatus Ero:

column7: yf that the deuell & synne did not ouercome me, then I shall be vndefyled.
column8: if that the Devil & sin did not overcome me, then I shall be undefiled.

column7: He that wyll endeuour him selfe to walke thus in this waye, must take the counsell of Dauid in the first Psalme, that he do remebre and meditate this lawe bothe daye and nyghte, and be lyke vnto a tree that is set nigh vnto a ryuer to brynge forth fruit in dewe tyme.
column8: He that will endeavour him self to walk thus in this Way, must take the counsel of David in the First Psalm, that he do Remember and meditate this law both day and night, and be like unto a tree that is Set High unto a river to bring forth fruit in dew time.

column7: And not onely he must remembre this waye or lawe in his mouthe, in speakynge and talkynge of it, but also he muste haue it in his harte.
column8: And not only he must Remember this Way or law in his Mouth, in speaking and talking of it, but also he must have it in his heart.

column7: And then as Dauid saithe in an other place.
column8: And then as David Saith in an other place.

column7: Non subplantabuntur gressus eius.
column8: Non subplantabuntur gressus eius.

column7: <NOTE> He shall be sure that he can not be ouerthrowen. yet not withstandynge Christe saith that this is a narrowe and a streyght way, and that there be but a fewe that finde it:
column8: He shall be sure that he can not be overthrown. yet not withstanding Christ Says that this is a narrow and a straight Way, and that there be but a few that find it:

column7: For although that there be no other thynge, yea not the deuell hym selfe, that can pulle vs out of this waye, or ouerthrowe vs agaynst our wyll yet not withstandynge,
column8: For although that there be no other thing, yea not the Devil him self, that can pull us out of this Way, or overthrown us against our will yet not withstanding,

column7: we our selfes if we walke not circumspectly, may soone fall,
column8: we our selves if we walk not circumspectly, may soon fallen,

column7: & go out of it:
column8: & go out of it:

column7: Wherfore we muste prouide for thre thyngis.
column8: Wherefore we must provide for Three things.

column7: Fyrst one to teache vs this waye,
column8: Fyrst one to teach us this Way,

column7: Secondaryly a candle to se how to walke in it.
column8: Secondarily a candle to see how to walk in it.

column7: Thyrdely and laste a staffe to holde vp when we comme to slypper places.
column8: Thirdly and laste a staff to hold up when we comme to slypper places.

column7: It is god that muste teache vs this way, vpon whome we must diligently call with Dauid, and say:
column8: It is god that must teach us this Way, upon whom we must diligently call with David, and say:

column7: Vias tuas domine demostra mihi,
column8: Ways tuas domine demostra mihi,

column7: & semitas tuas edoce me Lorde shewe me thy wayes, and teache me thy pathes.
column8: & semitas tuas edoce me Lord show me thy ways, and teach me thy paths.

column7: The candel that muste gyue vs lyght, is the scripture of god, as Salamon witnesseth sayenge:
column8: The candle that must gyve us Light, is the scripture of god, as Solomon Witnesseth saying:

column7: Mandatum lucerna,
column8: Mandatum Lucerne,

column7: & lex, lux. The commaundement of god is a candell, and the lawe is lyght.
column8: & lex, lux. The Commandment of god is a candle, and the law is Light.

column7: The staffe that we must walke by, is to lyue soberly, ryghtuously, and godly.
column8: The staff that we must walk by, is to live soberly, ryghtuously, and godly.

column7: For as Iohn saith there lyeth in our way thre stumblyng stones,
column8: For as John Says there lies in our Way Three stumbling stones,

column7: <NOTE> that is the concupiscence of the fleshe, <NOTE> the concupiscens of the eyes, whiche is couetousnes, and pryde.
column8: that is the concupiscence of the Flesh, the concupiscens of the eyes, which is covetousness, and pride.

column7: And if yt we stumble at none of these thre, we shall walke saue in this waye, whiche thyng we shall do, yf we obserue and keape ye thre vertues before mencyoned whiche must be gotten and preserued by thre meanes:
column8: And if that we Stumble At none of these Three, we shall walk save in this Way, which thing we shall do, if we observe and keape you Three Virtues before mentioned which must be got and preserved by Three means:

column7: To lyue soberly, the meane is fastynge.
column8: To live soberly, the mean is fasting.

column7: To lyue ryghtuously, ye meane is to gyue almes.
column8: To live ryghtuously, you mean is to gyve alms.

column7: To liue godly, ye meane is to be occupyed in prayer:
column8: To live godly, you mean is to be ocupied in prayer:

column7: which thynges yf ye diligently obserue, and kepe:
column8: which things if you diligently observe, and keep:

column7: we shal walke vndefiled in this way, and so come home agayn at the length to our heauenly countrey, frome whence we were banished and exiled.
column8: we shall walk undefiled in this Way, and so come home again At the length to our heavenly country, from whence we were banished and exiled.

column7: There euer to continewe, with the fathe, and the sonne, and the holy gooste:
column8: There ever to continue, with the fathe, and the son, and the holy ghost:

column7: to whome be laude, and prayse in worlde without ende.
column8: to whom be laud, and praise in world without end.

column8: Audite coeli, percipe auribus tuis terra, quonia Dominus loquutus est

column7: W Ho dooth not meruayle or counte it a thing very straunge, that a mortall man, of the generation of Adam, conceyued in synne, borne in wyckednes, brynge no creatour, but a creature, yea dust and ashes, shuld so boldly speak vnto al states and degrees of men, commanding them to heare.
column8: WHo WHo doth not marvel or count it a thing very strange, that a Mortal man, of the generation of Adam, conceived in sin, born in wickedness, bring no creator, but a creature, yea dust and Ashes, should so boldly speak unto all states and Degrees of men, commanding them to hear.

column7: Some peraduenture do not only meruayle, but accuse the Prophet, that he should say being but a man,
column8: some Peradventure do not only marvel, but accuse the Prophet, that he should say being but a man,

column7: But deere christians, meruail not, neyther charge you gods elect prophet with any euel, or breache of ciuilitie, least happely in faultyng them, whom god sendeth vnto you with the worde of reconciliation, ye procure to your selues the same rebuke, whych our Sauiour Christ gaue to the catchyng Phariseis, namelye,
column8: But deer Christians, marvel not, neither charge you God's elect Prophet with any evil, or breach of civility, least happily in faultyng them, whom god sends unto you with the word of reconciliation, you procure to your selves the same rebuke, which our Saviour christ gave to the catching Pharisees, namely,

column7: Quare vos malum cogitatis in cordibus vestris?
column8: Quare vos malum cogitatis in cordibus vestris?

column7: For although Esay spake woordes <NOTE> of commandyng and of auctoritye, yet hee spake theym not of hym selfe, neither in hys owne name, but in the name of the lyuynge god, which called him to be his prophet, and made hym a messaunger vnto the people, to call them to the obedience of the fayth.
column8: For although Isaiah spoke words of commanding and of Authority, yet he spoke them not of him self, neither in his own name, but in the name of the living god, which called him to be his Prophet, and made him a Messenger unto the people, to call them to the Obedience of the faith.

column7: Seynge therfore, that almighty God, the lorde of all creatures sent him to speake vnto the, he gaue him power to say,
column8: Sing Therefore, that almighty God, the lord of all creatures sent him to speak unto thee, he gave him power to say,

column7: Audite: and seing he sent him not to speake his owne wordes, but the wordes of God, he also gaue hym power to saye,
column8: Audite: and sing he sent him not to speak his own words, but the words of God, he also gave him power to say,

column7: Quoniam Dominus loquutus est.
column8: Quoniam Dominus loquutus est.

column7: For as the penne is the instrument, that formeth the lettre, whereby the mynde of the writer doth appeare vnto them that read it, not through the pen only, but by the writer that vseth the pen:
column8: For as the pen is the Instrument, that formeth the lettre, whereby the mind of the writer does appear unto them that read it, not through the pen only, but by the writer that uses the pen:

column7: euen so the prophet Esay,
column8: even so the Prophet Isaiah,

column7: & al thei that haue ye ministery of the word of god, are but the instrumets which god vseth according to his godly pleasure, to make his wil to be knowe vnto the hearers:
column8: & all they that have the Ministry of the word of god, Are but the instrumets which god uses according to his godly pleasure, to make his will to be know unto the hearers:

column7: Which cometh not of theselues, but of god, which speketh in them.
column8: Which comes not of themselves, but of god, which Speaketh in them.

column7: Dauid not forgetting that he was the instrumet of god, although called to the dignitie of a prophet, vnable of himselfe to set forth the inestimable riches of Gods wisdom, wtout the aide of his holy spirit, said Lingua mea calam us scribae, velociter scribentis.
column8: David not forgetting that he was the instrumet of god, although called to the dignity of a Prophet, unable of himself to Set forth the inestimable riches of God's Wisdom, without the aid of his holy Spirit, said Lingua mea Calam us Scribae, Velociter scribentis.

column7: S. Paule wel remebring that y ministratio of ye word was honorable, whereof God had made him a chose instrument,
column8: S. Paul well remebring that y ministratio of the word was honourable, whereof God had made him a chosen Instrument,

column7: & on the other side, not forgetful howe lytle he had deserued at ye lords hands such a promocion, whan he heard ye people of Corinth fallen into such a phrenetical contention, yt thei wold (as me do now a daies) either comende or lothe ye word for the instrument sake, bicause he wold not haue the to regard his person, but almighty God yt spake in him:
column8: & on the other side, not forgetful how little he had deserved At you Lords hands such a promotion, when he herd you people of Corinth fallen into such a phrenetical contention, that they would (as me do now a days) either commend or loath the word for the Instrument sake, Because he would not have thee to regard his person, but almighty God that spoke in him:

column7: Therfore to declare him self to be but an instrumet to set forth y glory of God, he sayd:

column8: Ego plantaui, Apollo r^gauit, sed Deus deditincrementu.

column7: Itaque neque qui plantat est aliquid, neque qui rigat, sed qui dat incrementum Deus.
column8: Itaque neque qui plantat est Aliquid, neque qui rigat, sed qui that Incrementum Deus.

column7: Esay vpo like consideracio entendinge to drawe the Israelites from the deceauable affections of flesh and bloud vnto the worthy receiuyng and reuerent embrasyng of the woord of lyfe, that they shuld not thynke on the person, but on the Lorde that spake in him, sayed:
column8: Isaiah upon like consideracio intending to draw the Israelites from the deceauable affections of Flesh and blood unto the worthy receiving and reverent embrasyng of the word of life, that they should not think on the person, but on the Lord that spoke in him, said:

column7: Audite coeli, percipe auribus tuis terra, quoniam Dominus loquutus est.
column8: Audite coeli, percipe auribus tuis terra, quoniam Dominus loquutus est.

column7: The lyke mynde ought to be at this daye in all them that either preache or heare the woord of the Lord, that the preachers may acknowledge themselues to bee but instruments, and the hearers to seeke nothyng in them, but god, speakyng in them the wordes of eternall lyfe.
column8: The like mind ought to be At this day in all them that either preach or hear the word of the Lord, that the Preachers may acknowledge themselves to be but Instruments, and the hearers to seek nothing in them, but god, speaking in them the words of Eternal life.

column7: Now therfore that almighty God speaketh by his instrumentes, the true preachers of his word, thorow the operation of his holy spirit, which in times past spake immediately from himself, by the patriarkes and prophetes to the world:
column8: Now Therefore that almighty God speaks by his Instruments, the true Preachers of his word, thorough the operation of his holy Spirit, which in times past spoke immediately from himself, by the Patriarchs and Prophets to the world:

column7: Let vs giue eare with diligence that we may vnderstand his heauenly mynd, and beware that we despise not, neglect and abandon this high treasure of the wisedome of god, the word of faith, although it seeme to come from a base & poore instrument, but hartely receiue it, ioyfully accept it, obediently folow it, and faithfully persist in it to the ende, that the may reape with great comfort thie promise of God,
column8: Let us give ear with diligence that we may understand his heavenly mind, and beware that we despise not, neglect and abandon this high treasure of the Wisdom of god, the word of faith, although it seem to come from a base & poor Instrument, but heartily receive it, joyfully accept it, obediently follow it, and faithfully persist in it to the end, that the may reap with great Comfort Thief promise of God,

column7: Qui perseue^ auerit vsque in finem, hic saluus erit.
column8: Qui perseue^ auerit vsque in finem, hic saluus erit.

column7: For <NOTE> without doubt god wylleth his word spoken by those who he choseth to this sacred function,
column8: For without doubt god willeth his word spoken by those who he chooses to this sacred function,

column7: to be receiued with lyke worthynes and estimacion, euen as though hee spake it him self.
column8: to be received with like worthiness and estimation, even as though he spoke it him self.

column7: And therfore he sayth: Qui uos audit, me audit. qui uos spernit me spernit.
column8: And Therefore he say: Qui uos audit, me audit. qui uos spernit me spernit.

column7: As the mouth of the kinges embassadour is (for the time he speaketh the woordes of the kyng) the verye mouthe of the kynge, so the mouth of the preacher, speakyng syncerely the woorde of God, is ye mouth of god for the time he preacheth.
column8: As the Mouth of the Kings ambassador is (for the time he speaks the words of the King) the very Mouth of the King, so the Mouth of the preacher, speaking sincerely the word of God, is the Mouth of god for the time he Preacheth.

column7: And therfore the Prophets wha they had spoken to the people, vnto whome they were sent, the mynd and woord of God, they for the moste parte concluded their matters with these wordes, saying:
column8: And Therefore the prophets wha they had spoken to the people, unto whom they were sent, the mind and word of God, they for the most part concluded their matters with these words, saying:

column7: Quoniam os Domini loquutum est. Wherfore as they that despise the kinges emdassadour, lytle regard or esteme the kyng. so lykewise they that despise the true preachers of the worde of god as much as in them lyeth, despise god.
column8: Quoniam os Domini loquutum est. Wherefore as they that despise the Kings emdassadour, little regard or esteem the King. so likewise they that despise the true Preachers of the word of god as much as in them lies, despise god.

column7: Now derely beloued christias, although Esay speaketh not vnto you, but a synful man, one vnwoorthy to beare Esayes bookes after hym, either for the dexteritie of life that was in hym, eyther for the deepe knowledge in the mysteries of God, yet bycause it hath pleased oure heauenlye father to call me at this tyme to this place, truely wythout couloure to speake hys truth, and nothing but hys truthe,
column8: Now dearly Beloved Christians, although Isaiah speaks not unto you, but a sinful man, one unworthy to bear Isaiah books After him, either for the dexterity of life that was in him, either for the deep knowledge in the Mysteres of God, yet Because it hath pleased our heavenly father to call me At this time to this place, truly without couloure to speak his truth, and nothing but his truth,

column7: I shall defyre yow in the name of God to dee dylygent hearers.
column8: I shall defyre you in the name of God to dee diligent hearers.

column7: Wherefore hopyng to haue you lyke attentiue nowe, as the true worshippers of God were in Esayes time,
column8: Wherefore hoping to have you like attentive now, as the true worshippers of God were in Isaiah time,

column7: I vse the same introduction to my matter as Esay did, saiynge vnto you, as he didde vnto them:
column8: I use the same introduction to my matter as Isaiah did, saying unto you, as he did unto them:

column7: Audite coeli, percipe auribus tuis terra, quonia Dominus loquutus est:
column8: Audite coeli, percipe auribus tuis terra, quonia Dominus loquutus est:

column7: Hear O heauens, harke O earth hear ye that be riche, and ye that be poore:
column8: Hear Oh heavens, hark Oh earth hear you that be rich, and you that be poor:

column7: ye that be honorable, & ye that be miserable:
column8: you that be honourable, & you that be miserable:

column7: ye bothe good and badde,
column8: you both good and bad,

column7: Audite, Audite. But peraduenture so me man museth what I do meane, thus earnestly to wyl you to heare, declaryng nothing what you shuld heare,
column8: Audite, Audite. But Peradventure so me man museth what I do mean, thus earnestly to will you to hear, declaring nothing what you should hear,

column7: Cum audire non possitis sine predicante:
column8: Cum Audire non possitis sine predicante:

column7: If here were no manne to speake vnto, then although I should saye audite, yet mighte I chose whether I wold speak furder, bicause it is wrytten,
column8: If Here were no man to speak unto, then although I should say audite, yet might I chosen whither I would speak further, Because it is written,

column7: Auditus vbi non est, non effundas sermonem.
column8: Auditus vbi non est, non effundas sermonem.

column7: I can make no such excuse, seing here is so goodly an audience, so learned an auditory, so diligently bent to hear that that shalbe spoken, but am compelled for conscience sake to speak that that the lord wylleth to be spoke by me:
column8: I can make no such excuse, sing Here is so goodly an audience, so learned an auditory, so diligently bent to hear that that shall spoken, but am compelled for conscience sake to speak that that the lord willeth to be spoke by me:

column7: (wherfore) as it is written Qui habet aures ad audiendum, audiat.
column8: (Wherefore) as it is written Qui habet aures ad audiendum, audiat.

column7: Speake on therfore, what would you that we shoulde <NOTE> heare?
column8: Speak on Therefore, what would you that we should hear?

column7: Verely ye shall heare the wholsome, comfortable and sweet exhortacion, yea rather the humble supplicacion that the holye Apostle S.
column8: Verily you shall hear the wholesome, comfortable and sweet exhortation, yea rather the humble supplication that the holy Apostle S.

column7: Paul made vnto the Corinthias But I wold not haue you to heare for your belies sake, or to satisfy the wanton lustes of your fleshe, as dyd the Epicures:
column8: Paul made unto the Corinthians But I would not have you to hear for your belies sake, or to satisfy the wanton lusts of your Flesh, as did the Epicureans:

column7: neither to tryppe the preachers in their wordes, as dyd the Phariseis or cursed Herodians:
column8: neither to tryppe the Preachers in their words, as did the Pharisees or cursed Herodians:

column8: lest the Sing plague, I would say, the Sin plague of.

column7: Aegypte fall vppon you, as it dyd vppon theym for theyr so wylfulle enterprise:
column8: Egypt fallen upon you, as it did upon them for their so wylfulle enterprise:

column7: Auditu audietis & non intelligebitis,
column8: Auditu audietis & non intelligebitis,

column7: & videtes uidebitis, & non uidebitis.
column8: & See uidebitis, & non uidebitis.

column7: But I wold wyshe you so to heare, that ye myght learn. so to attend, that ye myght comprehende your dutie towardes our merciful god.
column8: But I would wish you so to hear, that you might Learn. so to attend, that you might comprehend your duty towards our merciful god.

column7: To this end do they heare that are either wyse, or religious:
column8: To this end do they hear that Are either wise, or religious:

column7: As Salomon witnesseth: Auris sapientu
column8: As Solomon Witnesseth: Auris sapientu

column7: quaerit doctrinam, non calumnia, as those that be vndiscrete do, to who to speke of knowlege it auaileth not, bycause they refuse to be lerned therin:
column8: Query Doctrinam, non Calumny, as those that be undiscrete doe, to who to speak of knowledge it avails not, Because they refuse to be learned therein:

column7: vnto whom Salomo forbiddeth to speake, saying:
column8: unto whom Solomon forbiddeth to speak, saying:

column7: In auribus insipientiu ne loquaris, despicient enim doctrina eloquij tui. hopyng therfore that ye seke to knowe with the wise,
column8: In auribus insipientiu ne loquaris, despicient enim Doctrina eloquij tui. hoping Therefore that you seek to know with the wise,

column7: & not to carp wt the folish, that ye seke to learn & not to lurch, to sauor the truth,
column8: & not to carp with the foolish, that you seek to Learn & not to lurch, to savour the truth,

column7: & not to snare them y seke the prosperitie of your soules.
column8: & not to snare them y seek the Prosperity of your Souls.

column7: I am bolde at this instant through the permission of god, to open my mouthe in the truthe.
column8: I am bold At this instant through the permission of god, to open my Mouth in the truth.

column7: Beyng well assured, yt if ye disceaue me herein, yet can you not deceyue the lorde who seeth clerely in the darkenesse,
column8: Being well assured, that if you disceaue me herein, yet can you not deceive the lord who sees clearly in the darkness,

column7: <NOTE> who knoweth the very secretes of all mens hertes, vnto whom no thyng is hyd, but knowen, as it is written:
column8: who Knoweth the very secrets of all men's herts, unto whom no thing is hid, but known, as it is written:

column7: ^mnia nuda sunt illius oculis, de quo agimus, who can not be begiled,
column8: ^mnia nuda sunt Illius oculis, de quo agimus, who can not be beguiled,

column7: <NOTE> bycause he made man, and all that is in man.
column8: Because he made man, and all that is in man.

column8: As the Prophet say, Shall not he that made the ear, hear, or he that made the eye, shall not he see, and he that made the heart shall not he understand and know?

column7: yea verely. Wherfore without all hypocrisy bowe your eares to the Lord, and obediently lerne to serue hym, that your soule maye lyue.
column8: yea verily. Wherefore without all hypocrisy bow your ears to the Lord, and obediently Learn to serve him, that your soul may live.

column7: As the Lorde hym selfe sayth:
column8: As the Lord him self say:

column8: Ear uestram inclinate, & uenite ad me, audite,

column7: & uiuet anima uestra. To this end sainct Paule made this supplication vnto the Corinthias, that they myght lyue.
column8: & Vivet anima uestra. To this end saint Paul made this supplication unto the Corinthians, that they might live.

column7: Therfore to declare how carefull he was ouer theyr lyfe, and fearefull lest thorow theyr owne foly they shoulde fall to death, he sayde.
column8: Therefore to declare how careful he was over their life, and fearful lest thorough their own folly they should fallen to death, he said.

column7: Quin adiuuantes obsecramus, ne in uacuum gratia dei receperitis. Dicit enim, in tepore accepto exaudiuite,
column8: Quin adiuuantes Obsecramus, ne in uacuum Gratia dei receperitis. Dicit enim, in tepore accepto exaudiuite,

column8: & in die Salutis su^curri tibi.
