column8: Ecce nunc Tempus acceptum, ecce nunc dies Salutis.

column7: Ne quam demus offensionem, ne reprehendatur ministerium nostrum, sed in omnibus commendemus nos^psos vt Dei ministri, &c.
column8: Ne quam Demos offensionem, ne reprehendatur ministerium nostrum, sed in omnibus commendemus nos^psos vt Dei ministri, etc.

column7: After this humble and louely maner, dyd saynt Paule exhort the Corinthians, which were citisyns of the head citie of Achaia, of whom they had theyr names, and were called Corinthians, wyllyng them, as a tender father dooth his beloued chyldern, that they shuld not receyue the abundant grace of god, mynystred vnto them by his preachynge, in vayne.
column8: After this humble and lovely manner, did saint Paul exhort the Corinthians, which were citisyns of the head City of Achaia, of whom they had their names, and were called Corinthians, willing them, as a tender father doth his Beloved children, that they should not receive the abundant grace of god, ministered unto them by his preaching, in vain.

column7: Wherfore he sayth, We as helpers exhorte <NOTE> you. not that he ment by those wordes, to helpe god, which needeth not the helpe of men, bycause he is a perfect God, holy, iust and good, vnto whom nothing can be added nor any thyng diminished, but that he holpe the Corinthians in this that he slacked not the ministration of the worde toward them, neyther behaued hym selfe vnfaythfully towards God, by whom he was chosen to be an instrumente to beare his name vnto the Gentiles.
column8: Wherefore he say, We as helpers exhort you. not that he meant by those words, to help god, which needs not the help of men, Because he is a perfect God, holy, just and good, unto whom nothing can be added nor any thing diminished, but that he help the Corinthians in this that he slacked not the ministration of the word towards them, neither behaved him self unfaithfully towards God, by whom he was chosen to be an Instrument to bear his name unto the Gentiles.

column7: No neither vnkyndly toward the Corinthians, whom he had conuerted vnto the truthe from their gentilitie and vngodlynes.
column8: No neither unkindly towards the Corinthians, whom he had converted unto the truth from their gentility and ungodliness.

column7: For as it appeareth by auncient and godly wryters, he lyued among the Corinthians one hole yere and sixe monethes:
column8: For as it appears by ancient and godly writers, he lived among the Corinthians one hold year and sixe months:

column7: in the which he laboured with all diligent preachynge, to bryng theym from all lettes that hyndered Christes religion, vnto the obedience of the fayth, wherwith, before his commyng, they were not a lyttell infected.
column8: in the which he laboured with all diligent preaching, to bring them from all lets that hindered Christ's Religion, unto the Obedience of the faith, wherewith, before his coming, they were not a little infected.

column7: What mischief was there to be sene amog any people, that coulde not be bothe sene and founde among the Corinthians before his prechyng?
column8: What mischief was there to be seen Among any people, that could not be both seen and found among the Corinthians before his preaching?

column7: Were they not deuout ydolaters, execrable blasphemers, vnmercifull oppressers, violent exactours, beastly aduoutters, full of enuy, pride, dronkennes, gluttonye, strife, sedition and vnspeakeable villanye agaynst God and his dere son Iesus Christ?
column8: Were they not devout Idolaters, execrable blasphemers, unmerciful Oppresses, violent Exactours, beastly aduoutters, full of envy, pride, Drunkenness, gluttony, strife, sedition and unspeakable villainy against God and his dear son jesus christ?

column7: Dyd they not through ignorance, the chiefe enemy to knowledge, abuse all the good giftes of god?
column8: Did they not through ignorance, the chief enemy to knowledge, abuse all the good Gifts of god?

column7: But the Lorde entendyng to set forth mercy towardes them, lyke as he hath doon to all the hole worlde, dyd moue saynte Paule by his holy spirite to go preache vnto them the glad tydynges of saluation,
column8: But the Lord intending to Set forth mercy towards them, like as he hath done to all the hold world, did move faint Paul by his holy Spirit to go preach unto them the glad tidings of salvation,

column7: & call theim to repentaunce, that they myght by grace through faith in Iesus Christ, obtein the crowne of immortalitie and euerlastyng lyfe. whyche thynge, whan he lyued familiarly among theym, thorough the spirite of grace in preachyng, he performed.
column8: & call them to Repentance, that they might by grace through faith in jesus christ, obtain the crown of immortality and everlasting life. which thing, when he lived familiarly among them, through the Spirit of grace in preaching, he performed.

column7: Wherefore by trewe preachyng he layd a sure foundation among them, vt sapiens archytectus, namely the Lord Iesus, y they beyng buylt vpon hym, myght grow to an holy temple in the Lorde.
column8: Wherefore by true preaching he laid a sure Foundation among them, vt sapiens archytectus, namely the Lord jesus, y they being built upon him, might grow to an holy temple in the Lord.

column7: Howbeit the dyuel, the anciet enmy of God, endeuouryng to destroy that that God worketh, labouryng to euert that that God buyldeth, and to roote vp that that God planteth, bycause he may not abyde the creatures of God to tourne from synne, and faythefully to serue their God.
column8: Howbeit the Devil, the Ancient enemy of God, endeavouring to destroy that that God works, labouring to evert that that God buildeth, and to root up that that God plants, Because he may not abide the creatures of God to turn from sin, and faythefully to serve their God.

column7: Therfore soone after saynct Paules departure from Corynth, the dyuell (woorkyng in the children of vnbelefe) styrred the Corinthians to theyr old vomite agayn, that they myght peryshe.
column8: Therefore soon After saint Paul's departure from Corinth, the Devil (working in the children of unbelief) stirred the Corinthians to their old vomit again, that they might perish.

column7: And to bryng this matter to passe, he laboured to cause the heathen people that had concurse thyther, not onely by theyr heathenyshe manners, to corrupt the people, but also thorough false Apostles, to brynge theym frome the truthe to paganry, from the gospell to the lawe, from the rightuousnes of Christe, to theyr owne ryghtuousnes, and from the true worshyppynge of god, to adore their owne inuention, that the knowledge of God myght cleane bee rooted out amonge the people,
column8: And to bring this matter to pass, he laboured to cause the heathen people that had concourse thither, not only by their Heathenish manners, to corrupt the people, but also through false Apostles, to bring them from the truth to paganry, from the gospel to the law, from the righteousness of Christ, to their own righteousness, and from the true worshipping of god, to adore their own invention, that the knowledge of God might clean be rooted out among the people,

column7: Saynct Paule beyng moued with godly zeale ouer them, and lothe to see them desolate, whom god of his fre mercy for Christes sake, through his preching had couerted vnto the truth, althogh he had moued theym with one epistle to beware of suche deceyuers, yet ceassed he not with an other (signifyeng his carefulnes) to exhort theim that they shuld not receiue the grace of god in vayn, neyther synne against so mercyfull a God.
column8: Saint Paul being moved with godly zeal over them, and loath to see them desolate, whom god of his from mercy for Christ's sake, through his preaching had coverted unto the truth, although he had moved them with one epistle to beware of such deceivers, yet ceased he not with an other (signifying his carefulness) to exhort them that they should not receive the grace of god in vain, neither sin against so merciful a God.

column7: Is there any thynge that maye deserue more commendation, thanne in the tyme of punysshemente,
column8: Is there any thing that may deserve more commendation, than in the time of punishment,

column7: to forgyue? and whan sentence of deathe is pronounced, to pardon?
column8: to forgive? and when sentence of death is pronounced, to pardon?

column7: This dyd our heauenly father for them, and not for theim alone, but also for vs, sendyng his deere and only begotten sonne to be a raunsom for our synnes, in whom all that beleue, haue remission of theyr synne, and lyfe euerlastyng.
column8: This did our heavenly father for them, and not for them alone, but also for us, sending his deer and only begotten son to be a ransom for our Sins, in whom all that believe, have remission of their sin, and life everlasting.

column7: He alone is our Redemption and Iustification.
column8: He alone is our Redemption and Justification.

column7: In hym only are our synne purged and done <NOTE> away.
column8: In him only Are our sin purged and done away.

column7: He is our reconciliation & mercy seate in whom God is pacified toward vs, conteted towardes vs, agreed with vs to take vs for his sonnes.
column8: He is our reconciliation & mercy seat in whom God is pacified towards us, Contented towards us, agreed with us to take us for his Sons.

column7: Therfore it is writen, Christus pax nostra:
column8: Therefore it is written, Christus pax nostra:

column7: And again, Abluti sumus, sanctificati sumus, iustificati sumus per nome Iesu Christi,
column8: And again, Ablution sumus, sanctificati sumus, iustificati sumus per nome Jesu Christ,

column7: &
per spiritu dei nostri:
column8: per spiritu dei Our:

column7: Per quem habemus redemptionem, per sanguinem ipsius, remissione peccatorum, de qua ubertim nobis impartiuit, in omni sapientia & prudentia, patefacto nobis arcano voluntatis suae iuxta beneplacitum suum, quod proposuerat in seipso &c.
column8: Per Whom habemus redemptionem, per sanguinem Himself, remission peccatorum, de qua ubertim nobis impartiuit, in omni sapientia & Prudence, patefacto nobis Arcano voluntatis suae Next beneplacitum suum, quod proposuerat in Seipso etc.

column7: This worde of reconciliation dyd saincte Paule vnto the Corinthians, wherby the grace of god was manifested vnto theim in Christ Iesu, for the remission of theyr synnes, wyllynge them not to be vnthankfull receyuers therof, neyther suche as by fauourynge theyr olde synnes, shulde neglect the benefit of theyr saluation, but bryng foorth fruite agreable to the same gospell, which he had so long tyme preached amog them, and not to giue eare to the subtyll sophistry of the deceauer.
column8: This word of reconciliation did saint Paul unto the Corinthians, whereby the grace of god was manifested unto them in christ Jesu, for the remission of their Sins, willing them not to be unthankful Receivers thereof, neither such as by favouring their old Sins, should neglect the benefit of their salvation, but bring forth fruit agreeable to the same gospel, which he had so long time preached Among them, and not to give ear to the subtle sophistry of the deceauer.

column7: For well knew saynt Paule the damnable policie of the dyuell, that he cared not though the word were muche preached, so that he myght bryng to passe to destroye in the people the fruites of the gospell.
column8: For well knew saint Paul the damnable policy of the Devil, that he cared not though the word were much preached, so that he might bring to pass to destroy in the people the fruits of the gospel.

column7: Wherfore he exhorted them, not to receyue the grace of God in vayne, but to be faythfull folowers of Christ, and lyue after the gospell.
column8: Wherefore he exhorted them, not to receive the grace of God in vain, but to be faithful followers of christ, and live After the gospel.

column7: Bycause the grace of God <NOTE> hath apeared, teachyng vs to deny vngodlynes and worldely luste, and to lyue iustly, sobrely, and rightuously in this present world, lookyng for that blessed hope and apearyng of our Lorde Iesus &c.
column8: Because the grace of God hath appeared, teaching us to deny ungodliness and worldly lust, and to live justly, soberly, and rightuously in this present world, looking for that blessed hope and appearing of our Lord jesus etc.

column7: But haue not we as much nede at this tyme to learne this lesson as had the Corinthians?
column8: But have not we as much need At this time to Learn this Lesson as had the Corinthians?

column7: Hath not almighty god shewed as muche mercye vnto vs as he dyd vnto them, or rather more?
column8: Hath not almighty god showed as much mercy unto us as he did unto them, or rather more?

column7: God sent to the Corinthians one preacher to conuert them to the truthe:
column8: God sent to the Corinthians one preacher to convert them to the truth:

column7: God hath sent to vs many.
column8: God hath sent to us many.

column7: The worde was preached by one whole yere and a half to the Corinthians:
column8: The word was preached by one Whole year and a half to the Corinthians:

column7: It hath bene preached many yeares vnto vs.
column8: It hath be preached many Years unto us

column7: God taught the Corinthians the trewe worshippyng of god, he also hath taught vs to worshyp god truly.
column8: God taught the Corinthians the true worshipping of god, he also hath taught us to worship god truly.

column7: God remoued from the Corinthians by syncere preachyng, that whych hyndred godly religion:
column8: God removed from the Corinthians by sincere preaching, that which hindered godly Religion:

column7: The same God hath also remoued frome vs that that hyndered godly religion.
column8: The same God hath also removed from us that that hindered godly Religion.

column7: But as the goodnes of God hath bene more abundant to vs than to the Corinthians, so haue our synnes farre exceded the synnes of the Corinthians:
column8: But as the Goodness of God hath be more abundant to us than to the Corinthians, so have our Sins Far exceed the Sins of the Corinthians:

column7: wherby if Paule seared that they woulde take the grace of God in vayne, muche more it is to be seared that we receiue it not in vayn.
column8: whereby if Paul seared that they would take the grace of God in vain, much more it is to be seared that we receive it not in vain.

column7: For the same dyuell that laboured to make the Corinthians enemies to grace, at this day ceasseth not to make vs the same, as saynet Peter sayth:
column8: For the same Devil that laboured to make the Corinthians enemies to grace, At this day ceaseth not to make us the same, as Saint Peter say:

column7: Diabolus aduersarius noster tanqleo
column8: Diabolus Adversary Noster tanqleo

column7: rugiens circuit, quaerens quem deuoret:
column8: rugiens circuit, Seeking Whom devoret:

column7: He is not ydell, but styll laboureth to roote out of mans hart the feare of god and knowlege of the truthe, that they myght folowe hym lyke captiues, snared in the bandes of darkenes to pardicion:
column8: He is not idle, but still Laboureth to root out of men heart the Fear of god and knowledge of the truth, that they might follow him like captives, snared in the bands of darkness to pardicion:

column7: For as saynt Iohn saith,
column8: For as saint John Says,

column7: Diabolus peccat ab initio, and therfore studyeth to make all men to haue pleasure in syn, that they myght enioy his inheritance, the lake that burneth with fyre and brymstone.
column8: Diabolus peccat ab initio, and Therefore studieth to make all men to have pleasure in sin, that they might enjoy his inheritance, the lake that burns with fire and brimstone.

column7: As God hathe pleasure in lyfe, so hath he pleasure in murderyng and kyllyng the soules of me.
column8: As God hath pleasure in life, so hath he pleasure in murdering and killing the Souls of me.

column7: Not without cause therfore hath our sauioure Christe thus spoken of hym:
column8: Not without cause Therefore hath our Saviour Christ thus spoken of him:

column7: Diabolus homicida erat ab initio,
column8: Diabolus Homicide erat ab initio,

column7: & in veritate non stetit, quia non est veritas in eo.
column8: & in veritate non Stetit, quia non est veritas in eo.

column7: By errors <NOTE> therfore and false suggestions he goth about to make men alwayes disobedient and vnfaithfull against god.
column8: By errors Therefore and false suggestions he Goes about to make men always disobedient and unfaithful against god.

column7: To atchiue this hys detestable purpose, he putteth into their hartes strong delusions, that they should beleeue lies, and attempt thynges woorthy of condemnacion.
column8: To achieve this his detestable purpose, he putteth into their hearts strong delusions, that they should believe lies, and attempt things worthy of condemnation.

column7: As he did into Iudas heart, as sayth S.
column8: As he did into Judas heart, as say S.

column7: Iohn: Diabolus immisit in cor Iudae ve proderet Christum.
column8: John: Diabolus immisit in cor Judea ve proderet Christ.

column7: Many waies the diuel did seke to bring the Corinthians into gods displeasure, after they had receaued the gospel, but chiefly either in corrupting theselues with a conuersation moste contrary to their profession, eyther by steryng theym by false apostels In Iudaismum, ut exciderent gratia.
column8: Many ways the Devil did seek to bring the Corinthians into God's displeasure, After they had received the gospel, but chiefly either in corrupting themselves with a Conversation most contrary to their profession, either by steering them by false Apostles In Judaism, ut exciderent Gratia.

column7: <NOTE> Euen so he doth labour diuersly and manye waies to bring vs into Goddes displeasure, but principally by two waies, wherin he spedeth no small labour in these daies, not altogyther without bringing his cursed purpose to passe. Thone way is by speaking wel, and lyuing abhominably:
column8: Even so he does labour diversely and many ways to bring us into Goddess displeasure, but principally by two ways, wherein he speedeth no small labour in these days, not altogether without bringing his cursed purpose to pass. Thone Way is by speaking well, and living abominably:

column7: thother is by liuinge well (as farre forth as men can iudge) and speakyng euell, that is, teaching or maintaynyng vnsure doctrine. By one of these twoo wayes the dyuell at this daye deceiueth the soules of men. If thone serueth not, he doth attempt with the other.
column8: tother is by living well (as Far forth as men can judge) and speaking evil, that is, teaching or maintaining unsure Doctrine. By one of these twoo ways the Devil At this day deceiveth the Souls of men. If thone serveth not, he does attempt with the other.

column7: To speake well and lyue carnally, it displeaseth him very lyttle:
column8: To speak well and live carnally, it displeaseth him very little:

column7: but to lyue well, that is not for the dyuels dyet:
column8: but to live well, that is not for the Devils diet:

column7: nothyng is so contrary to his pestilent tooth, it is to hote for him to swalow vp such a morsell, onlesse he play the cooke, and take in hand to season the matter hymself.
column8: nothing is so contrary to his pestilent tooth, it is to hight for him to swallow up such a morsel, unless he play the cook, and take in hand to season the matter himself.

column7: That that is most difficyle to bryng to passe, that doth the dyuell fyrst enterprise, most hardlye assault, most busely seeketh to conquer, and beyng conquerer therof, more reioyseth than ouer that y is but small maistery to wynne.
column8: That that is most difficyle to bring to pass, that does the Devil fyrst enterprise, most hardly assault, most busily seeks to conquer, and being conqueror thereof, more Rejoiceth than over that y is but small mastery to win.

column7: The dyuell doth thynke it easyer to continue an hundreth well speakers in a fylthy conuersation, than to ouercome one man that exerciseth himself in vertue and godlynesse.
column8: The Devil does think it Easier to continue an Hundredth well Speakers in a filthy Conversation, than to overcome one man that Exerciseth himself in virtue and godliness.

column7: First therfore he byddeth battail to the vertuous man, as to his most aduersary, whose castell he knoweth to bee so stronge and vnsaultable, that without diligent beatynge of his diuelish wittes, he can by no meanes win it.
column8: First Therefore he biddeth battle to the virtuous man, as to his most adversary, whose castle he Knoweth to be so strong and vnsaultable, that without diligent beating of his devilish wits, he can by no means win it.

column7: Stronge is that munition whose walles are brasse, but stronger is that soule whose walle is the word of God:
column8: Strong is that munition whose walls Are brass, but Stronger is that soul whose wall is the word of God:

column7: inuincible is that forte, whose rampyres are strongly couched to the walles, and of great quantitye, but more inuincible is that soule, whose faith is suerly lynked to the woorde of God, and in great quantity expresseth the frutes thereof thorowe vndefyled charitie. yet is there no bastylion so stronge, but by some meanes it may be ouercome.
column8: invincible is that fort, whose rampyres Are strongly couched to the walls, and of great quantity, but more invincible is that soul, whose faith is surely lynked to the word of God, and in great quantity Expresses the fruits thereof thorough undefiled charity. yet is there no bastylion so strong, but by Some means it may be overcome.

column7: For that that force often mysseth, that doothe prodition brynge to passe:
column8: For that that force often mysseth, that doth prodition bring to pass:

column7: and that that canne not bee doone by other, is often thorowe pollicy doune by oure selues.
column8: and that that can not be done by other, is often thorough policy down by our selves.

column7: Of this the subtyle Satanas is not ignoraunte, whose practise it hathe beene frome the beginnynge agaynst mans soule, and wyll bee (I feare mee) vnto the ende.
column8: Of this the subtle Satanas is not ignorant, whose practice it hath been from the beginning against men soul, and will be (I Fear me) unto the end.

column7: We haue exaumple in Scripture, that somme tyme by force of other hee caused menne to synne, and sometyme he prouoked theymselues to be cause of their owne myschief.
column8: We have Exampl in Scripture, that sum time by force of other he caused men to sin, and sometime he provoked theymselues to be cause of their own mischief.

column7: Whylest Moyses was in the Mounte wyth God, the dyuell knewe that the gouernmente of the people hanged vppon Aarons shoulders, wherefore thoroughe the ignoraunce of God, hee styrred vppe the heartes of the Israelytes, to cause Aaron to make theym a molten Calfe after <NOTE> the manner of Egypte.
column8: Whilst Moses was in the Mount with God, the Devil knew that the government of the people hanged upon Aaron's shoulders, Wherefore thorough the ignorance of God, he stirred up the hearts of the Israelites, to cause Aaron to make them a melted Calf After the manner of Egypt.

column7: Thus by force hee caused Aaron to bee their ymage maker, contrarye to Goddes wyll.
column8: Thus by force he caused Aaron to be their image maker, contrary to Goddess will.

column7: But where thys feate serueth not, hee occupieth the other, namelye to make men betraye theim selues.
column8: But where this feat serveth not, he occupieth the other, namely to make men betray them selves.

column7: What needeth me to rehearse the good Kynge Ezechias, whome the dyuell so myghtilye assaulted <NOTE> thorowe his cruell instrumentes, the capitayn of Sennacherib kyng of Assyria, tempting him with outragious blasphemy agaist god, to giue ouer his heart with the people thorowe incredulitye, into the handes of the king of Assyria?
column8: What needs me to rehearse the good King Hezekiah, whom the Devil so myghtilye assaulted thorough his cruel Instruments, the captain of Sennacherib King of Assyria, tempting him with outrageous blasphemy aghast god, to give over his heart with the people thorough incredulity, into the hands of the King of Assyria?

column7: Yet could not the dyuell by these his ministers ouercome good Ezechias but the more thei proudly bragged, the more <NOTE> Ezechias humbled himselfe. The more they callyd to the people, fearyng them with the name of the kyng of Assyria, with his gestes and marciall feates to tourne their heartes from their kyng (that kyng and people may fall into his hande) so muche the more good kynge Ezechias called vnto God in feruent prayer, to be defended from Gods enemye,
column8: Yet could not the Devil by these his Ministers overcome good Hezekiah but the more they proudly bragged, the more Hezekiah humbled himself. The more they called to the people, fearing them with the name of the King of Assyria, with his gests and martial feats to turn their hearts from their King (that King and people may fallen into his hand) so much the more good King Hezekiah called unto God in fervent prayer, to be defended from God's enemy,

column7: & the enemye of his people, the kyng of Assyria.
column8: & the enemy of his people, the King of Assyria.

column7: And god of his free mercy heard his prayer, strengthened the peoples hearts, and delyuered Ierusalem from the spoyle.
column8: And god of his free mercy herd his prayer, strengthened the peoples hearts, and Delivered Jerusalem from the spoil.

column7: O victory of Faith. Sathan therfore perceiuing that by this waies he could not preuayle agaynst Ezechias, whose munition was so strong, thorow Iesu Christe, he wente an other way to woorke, namely by prodicion to cause him to betray himself, that hee myght by som mean cause him to offend.
column8: O victory of Faith. Sathan Therefore perceiving that by this ways he could not prevail against Hezekiah, whose munition was so strong, thorough Jesu Christ, he went an other Way to work, namely by prodition to cause him to betray himself, that he might by Some mean cause him to offend.

column7: After that god had giuen him peace, and destroyed the hoste of Assyria, the kynge of Babylon sente <NOTE> guiftes to Ezechias.
column8: After that god had given him peace, and destroyed the host of Assyria, the King of Babylon sent Gifts to Hezekiah.

column7: The dyuell therwithall made him to forget his humilitie, and thrust into his heart opinion of himself, whereby he dydde not onely reioyse that so famous a kyng shuld seeke friendship at his handes by guiftes, but also to ostentate his ryches and power, hee shewed the messangers hys treasure house, for the which the Prophete was sent to rebuke him:
column8: The Devil therewithal made him to forget his humility, and thrust into his heart opinion of himself, whereby he did not only rejoice that so famous a King should seek friendship At his hands by Gifts, but also to ostentate his riches and power, he showed the messengers his treasure house, for the which the Prophet was sent to rebuke him:

column7: & he repented. This hath been his fetche of olde (as we here se) & this doth he practise nowe at this daye, againste those that couette to leade a vertuous life, whose fall is his only ioy, because he is a deuourer.
column8: & he repented. This hath been his fetch of old (as we Here se) & this does he practise now At this day, against those that covet to lead a virtuous life, whose fallen is his only joy, Because he is a devourer.

column7: Therfore where he perceyueth anye that haue pleasure in godlynes, and to walk in the orcharde of Gods eternal woorde, by whose pleasaunt sauours their soules might be consolated, to infect those is his whole industrye, which he can by no meanes doo, but by makynge theim receiue the grace of God in vaine.
column8: Therefore where he perceiveth any that have pleasure in godliness, and to walk in the orchard of God's Eternal word, by whose pleasant savours their Souls might be consolated, to infect those is his Whole industry, which he can by no means do, but by making them receive the grace of God in vain.

column7: Seyng then that hee can not corrupt them with grosse synnes, which thorow custome and exercise of vertu do continually watche that they may escape them, he desyreth to corrupt them therin, wherin they lest suspect to fall, namely in doctrine, and that bycause he seeth them greedy of knowledge, and of the sweete sauour of the truth.
column8: Sing then that he can not corrupt them with gross Sins, which thorough custom and exercise of virtue do continually watch that they may escape them, he desireth to corrupt them therein, wherein they lest suspect to fallen, namely in Doctrine, and that Because he sees them greedy of knowledge, and of the sweet savour of the truth.

column7: Therefore he gathereth togither a great heape of noysome floures, which are beautifull to the eye, and seme for their glosse and coulour to haue growen in the orcharde of the Lorde, yet is their styncke deathly and pestiferous to theym, that obstinately delyte in theyr sauoure, and declareth theym not to be of the orchyarde of God, but of the contagious palude of hell.
column8: Therefore he gathereth together a great heap of noisome flowers, which Are beautiful to the eye, and seem for their gloss and colour to have grown in the orchard of the Lord, yet is their styncke deathly and pestiferous to them, that obstinately delight in their savour, and Declareth them not to be of the orchyarde of God, but of the contagious palude of hell.

column7: Those hee straweth before the godly lyuer, that by their yll sauour he may be an euell speaker, and so receiue the grace of God in vayne.
column8: Those he straweth before the godly liver, that by their ill savour he may be an evil speaker, and so receive the grace of God in vain.

column7: For as good sauour is comfortable to the body, and a preseruer of his health, so is sounde doctrine the preseruatiue of the soule.
column8: For as good savour is comfortable to the body, and a preserver of his health, so is sound Doctrine the preservative of the soul.

column7: As it is written: Verba quae ego loquor, spiritus & vita sunt.
column8: As it is written: Verba Quae ego Loquor, spiritus & vita sunt.

column7: <NOTE> But as nothynge soeuer corrupteth the body, than stynkyng sauour and impure ayre:
column8: But as nothing soever corrupteth the body, than stinking savour and impure air:

column7: so nothynge soeuer kylleth the soule, than impure doctrine.
column8: so nothing soever killeth the soul, than impure Doctrine.

column7: As it is wrytten: Erratis, quia nescitis scripturas.
column8: As it is written: Erratus, quia Nescitis scripturas.

column7: Seing that the <NOTE> dyuell straweth such flowers before good lyners, prouokyng them by their couloure to poyson them self with their sauour, charitye willeth that ye declare them, least happelye anye man thorow ignoraunce shoulde smell there vnto, and so receiue the grace of God in vaine.
column8: Sing that the Devil straweth such flowers before good lyners, provoking them by their couloure to poison them self with their savour, charity wills that you declare them, least happily any man thorough ignorance should smell there unto, and so receive the grace of God in vain.

column7: Geue eare therefore, and yee shall perceiue these flattering floures of the dyuell wherwith he laboureth to deceyne, and beeware of them.
column8: Give ear Therefore, and ye shall perceive these flattering flowers of the Devil wherewith he Laboureth to deceyne, and beware of them.

column7: Fyrste, That all menne bee so saued, that none at length shalbe dampned.
column8: First, That all men be so saved, that none At length shall dampened.

column7: This floure seemeth to haue a goodlye colour,
column8: This flower seems to have a goodly colour,

column7: & the dyuell by the deceitfull beautye thereof, entiseth some to put it to their nose, that with smellyng therto, their souls might be fylled with blyndnes and errour.
column8: & the Devil by the deceitful beauty thereof, enticeth Some to put it to their nose, that with smelling thereto, their Souls might be filled with blindness and error.

column7: For it seemeth to be buylt vpon the mercy of God, but so, that vtterly it destroyeth his iustyce, breedeth in manne a false securitie, cleane rooteth oute of hys hearte the feare of God and obedience to hys woorde:
column8: For it seems to be built upon the mercy of God, but so, that utterly it Destroyeth his Justice, breeds in man a false security, clean roots out of his heart the Fear of God and Obedience to his word:

column7: wherefore it is as Cycute, and mortifyeth the soule.
column8: Wherefore it is as Execute, and mortifyeth the soul.

column7: For althoughe God bee mercifull (as hee is in deede) by the which he wylleth <NOTE> not the death of a synner,
column8: For although God be merciful (as he is in deed) by the which he willeth not the death of a sinner,

column7: Sed magis vt viuat & conuertatur, yet is hee also iuste, by the whiche hee condemneth the vnbeleuers and impenitente.
column8: said magis vt viuat & conuertatur, yet is he also just, by the which he Condemneth the unbelievers and impenitente.

column7: Therefore it is wrytten: Ne dica^, Miseratio Domini magna est, multitudis peccatorum meorum miserabitur.
column8: Therefore it is written: Ne dica^, Miseratio Domini Magna est, multitudis peccatorum meorum miserabitur.

column7: Misericordia & ira abillo cito proximant,
column8: Misericordia & ira abillo Quick proximant,

column7: & in peccatores respicit ira illius:
column8: & in Peccatores respicit ira Illius:

column7: Non tardes conuerti ad Dominu,
column8: Non tardes conuerti ad Dominu,

column7: & ne differas de die in diem.
column8: & ne differas de die in diem.

column7: Subito eni venitira illius, & in die vindictae disperdet &c.
column8: Subito eni venitira Illius, & in die vindictae disperdet etc.

column7: The worde of God therfore dooth declare God to bee bothe iuste and mercifull, and that hys mercye destroyeth not hys iustice, neyther his iustice diminisheth his mercye.
column8: The word of God Therefore doth declare God to be both just and merciful, and that his mercy Destroyeth not his Justice, neither his Justice diminisheth his mercy.

column7: For hee hathe declared in hys woorde their lymites and boundes in suche sorte, that wee maye assure oure selues either of saluacion or of condemnacion.
column8: For he hath declared in his word their lymites and bounds in such sort, that we may assure our selves either of salvation or of condemnation.

column7: Notwithstandynge that hys Mercye reacheth vnto the heauens, and is ouer of all his woorkes, yet are none therof partakers, but those in whom Christ dwelleth by lyuely faith, as S.
column8: Notwithstanding that his Mercy reaches unto the heavens, and is over of all his works, yet Are none thereof partakers, but those in whom christ dwells by lively faith, as S.

column7: Paule writeth: Christus Iesus in vobis est, ni reprobi estis.
column8: Paul Writeth: Christus jesus in vobis est, ni Reprobate Ye are.

column7: And again: Iustus ex fide uiuit.
column8: And again: Justus ex fide uiuit.

column7: To the faithfull <NOTE> therefore God hath, for Christes sake, promised mercye, whyche are penitente and conuerte vnto the Lorde, but the vnfaithfull and impenitent that dye in their <NOTE> synnes, shall bee confounded and perishe:
column8: To the faithful Therefore God hath, for Christ's sake, promised mercy, which Are penitent and convert unto the Lord, but the unfaithful and impenitent that die in their Sins, shall be confounded and perish:

column7: Quoniam nouit Dominus viam iustorum,
column8: Quoniam Novit Dominus viam Just,

column7: & iter impiorum peribit. As the vnbeleuers and impenitent therefore haue promised to them iudgement, so to the faythfull and penytent,
column8: & iter Impious Peribit. As the unbelievers and impenitent Therefore have promised to them judgement, so to the faithful and penytent,

column7: God, for Christes sake onely, hathe promysed mercye, and wyll not enter into iudgemente wyth theym, bycause they bee grafted in Christ, vppon whome Saynte Paule sayeth, there is no condemnacion.
column8: God, for Christ's sake only, hath promised mercy, and will not enter into judgement with them, Because they be grafted in christ, upon whom Faint Paul Saith, there is no condemnation.

column7: Lyfe euerlastynge is the guyfte of Godde thoroughe Christe, and it belongeth to true christians, whyche vnfaynedlye beleeue in Chryste, whereof they maye bee gladde:
column8: Life everlasting is the guyfte of God thorough Christ, and it belongeth to true Christians, which unfeignedly believe in Christ, whereof they may be glad:

column7: But eternall deathe is the inheritaunce of the vnbeleuers, whome Godde wyll cutte of frome his face with the swearde of Iustyce, that they shall bee destroyed. as Dauid sayeth.
column8: But Eternal death is the inheritance of the unbelievers, whom God will Cut of from his face with the sword of justice, that they shall be destroyed. as David Saith.

column7: Exurgat Deus & dissipentur inimici eius,
column8: Exurgat Deus & dissipentur Inimici eius,

column7: & fugiant qui oderunt eum, facie eius.
column8: & Fortnight qui oderunt Eum, fancy eius.

column7: Sicut deficit fumus, deficiant:
column8: Sicut deficit Fumes, deficiant:

column7: sicut fluit cera facie ignis, sic pereant peccatores facie Dei.
column8: sicut fluit Wax fancy ignis, sic pereant Peccatores fancy Dei.

column7: Et iusti epulentur, exultent in conspectu dei,
column8: Et Justi epulentur, exultent in conspectu dei,

column7: & delectentur in laetitia. &c.
column8: & delectentur in Laetitia. etc.

column7: Our sauior Christ enteding to set before the peoples eyes the limites of his mercy,
column8: Our Saviour christ enteding to Set before the peoples eyes the Limits of his mercy,

column7: & boundes of his iustice, y they might certify them of whether thei wer partakers, not withstandyng the vniuersal preching of his most blessed word, said:
column8: & bounds of his Justice, y they might certify them of whither they were partakers, not withstanding the universal preaching of his most blessed word, said:

column7: Euntes in mundu
column8: Euntes in Mundus

column7: vniuersum, praedicate euangelium omni creaturae:
column8: vniuersum, predicate Evangelium omni creaturae:

column7: Qui crediderit & baptizatus fuerit, hic saluue erit:
column8: Qui crediderit & Baptized fuerit, hic saluue erit:

column7: qui non crediderit, condemnabitur.
column8: qui non crediderit, condemnabitur.

column7: These are the limites that Christ hath sette to his mercy and iudgement, whiche are moste certayn, of the whiche euery man shal taste, accordyng to his deedes, as saint Paul saith:
column8: These Are the Limits that christ hath Set to his mercy and judgement, which Are most certain, of the which every man shall taste, according to his Deeds, as saint Paul Says:

column7: Hijs quidem qui secundum patientiam boni operis, gloriam & honorem & incorruptione quaerentibus,
column8: Hijs quidem qui secundum patientiam boni operis, gloriam & Honor & incorruptione quaerentibus,

column7: uitam aeternam:
column8: uitam aeternam:

column7: hijs qui sunt ex contentione,
column8: hijs qui sunt ex contention,

column7: & qui non acquiescunt ueritati, credunt autem iniquitati, ira & indignatio, tribulatio & angustia, in omnem animam hominis perpetrantis malum,
column8: & qui non acquiescunt Veritati, credunt autem iniquitati, ira & indignatio, tribulatio & angustia, in omnem animam hominis perpetrantis malum,

column7: Iudaei primum & Graeci. If therfore gods mercye towardes all menne in Iesus Christe, saueth none but the true beleuers, and that for Christes sake, as it is most certayn:
column8: Judea primum & Greeks. If Therefore God's mercy towards all men in jesus Christ, Saveth none but the true believers, and that for Christ's sake, as it is most certain:

column7: and in the contrary part, gods iudgement condemneth none but the vnbeleuers,
column8: and in the contrary part, God's judgement Condemneth none but the unbelievers,

column7: <NOTE> that dye without repentance, as that is not to be doubted:
column8: that die without Repentance, as that is not to be doubted:

column7: Therefore it is a stynkynge floure most pestilent to say, that he will saue al, for the scripture doth certify vs, that some dyed impenitently in theyr vnbeliefe, for the <NOTE> whych cause they wer condemned:
column8: Therefore it is a stinking flower most pestilent to say, that he will save all, for the scripture does certify us, that Some died impenitently in their unbelief, for the which cause they were condemned:

column7: as Cain, Saul, Sennacheryb, the Sodomites, and the cursed congregation of Corath and Abyron, whiche wente quycke downe into bell, with other mo, of whom we reade in the old testament.
column8: as Cain, Saul, Sennacherib, the Sodomites, and the cursed congregation of Corath and Ebron, which went quick down into bell, with other more, of whom we read in the old Testament.

column7: Also in the newe Testamente we rede of Iudas the loste sonne, with many other.
column8: Also in the new Testament we rede of Judas the lost son, with many other.

column7: <NOTE> If some therfore are all redy condemned, then abhominable is this erroure, that at length all men shall be saued.
column8: If Some Therefore Are all ready condemned, then abominable is this error, that At length all men shall be saved.

column7: O pernicious heresy so farre agaynst god and his holy testament, through who vnbeleuyng Cayn is promoted to saluation as well as faithful Abell:
column8: O pernicious heresy so Far against god and his holy Testament, through who unbelieving Cain is promoted to salvation as well as faithful Abel:

column7: and cursed Iudas as well as blessed Peter, contrary to the purpose of God, declared in his worde.
column8: and cursed Judas as well as blessed Peter, contrary to the purpose of God, declared in his word.

column7: O subtyll deuill, that with the stynke of this deathly floure poysonnest mans soule with vayne hope and hellyshe securitie, cleane peruertynge hym frome the truthe, that he shoulde receyue the grace of god in vayne.
column8: O subtle Devil, that with the stink of this deathly flower poysonnest men soul with vain hope and hellish security, clean perverting him from the truth, that he should receive the grace of god in vain.

column7: For surely as God hathe expressed his iustice from the beginnyng vpon the vnbeleuynge, and his mercye vppon the faythfull, so wyll he doo to the ende and conclusion of the world.
column8: For surely as God hath expressed his Justice from the beginning upon the unbelieving, and his mercy upon the faithful, so will he do to the end and conclusion of the world.

column7: As whan he commeth to iudgement, it shall apeare.
column8: As when he comes to judgement, it shall appear.

column7: For than wyll he separate the lambes from the goates, the one on his right hande, to lyfe, and the other on his lefte hande, to death.
column8: For than will he separate the Lambs from the Goats, the one on his right hand, to life, and the other on his left hand, to death.

column7: Beati igitur qui
column8: Beati igitur qui

column7: seruant mandata illius, ut sit potestas corum in ligno vitae:
column8: servant Commandments Illius, ut sit potestas corum in ligno vitae:

column7: foris auteni canes ve nefici, homicidae & impudici & idolis seruientes,
column8: Foris auteni canes ve nefici, Homicidae & impudici & Idolis servientes,

column7: & omnis qui amat mendatiu.
column8: & omnis qui amat mendatiu.

column7: For the time shall come, that the faythfull shall heare this swete voyce,
column8: For the time shall come, that the faithful shall hear this sweet voice,

column7: Venite benedicti patris mei, in regnu preparatu pro uobis ab initio.
column8: Venite Blessing patris mei, in regnu preparatu Pro uobis ab initio.

column7: And the vnfaythfull shall heare,
column8: And the unfaithful shall hear,

column7: A bite in ignem aeternum &c. ergo non omnes saluentur.
column8: A bite in Ignem aeternum etc. ergo non omnes saluentur.

column7: But if this flowre will not serue, than he bryngeth an other of no lesse poyson than this was, wherwithall he wold persuade by a common order, that none shall be saued.
column8: But if this flower will not serve, than he bringeth an other of no less poison than this was, wherewithal he would persuade by a Common order, that none shall be saved.

column7: And this is his flowre.
column8: And this is his flower.

column7: That there is no predestination of God:
column8: That there is no predestination of God:

column7: O deceauable dyuel, that leuest no stone vnrolled to drowne men in to perdytion.
column8: Oh deceauable Devil, that levest no stone unrolled to drown men in to perdytion.

column7: By this cotagious floure, he laboreth to make men deny the holy Predestination of God, and theyr election in Iesus Christe, in whome the faythefull are sealed to eternall lyfe.
column8: By this cotagious flower, he Laboureth to make men deny the holy Predestination of God, and their election in jesus Christ, in whom the faithful Are sealed to Eternal life.

column7: That in denyenge thereof, hee myghte wype oute of theyr sowle the comforte of theyr Iustyfycation, and gloryfycation, the effectes of the Predestynation of God, the whyche Saynet Paule soo strongely confyrmethe vnto the Romaynes,
column8: That in denying thereof, he might wipe out of their soul the Comfort of their Justification, and gloryfycation, the effects of the Predestination of God, the which Saint Paul so strongly confyrmethe unto the Romans,

column7: sayenge: Scimus autem quod hijs qui diligunt deum, omnia cooperantur in bonum, nimiru hos qui iuxta propositu vocati sunt &c.
column8: saying: Scimus autem quod hijs qui Love God, omnia cooperantur in bonum, nimiru hos qui Next propositu vocati sunt etc.

column7: Porro quos praedestinauit, eosdem & vocauit:
column8: Porro quos praedestinauit, eosdem & vocauit:

column7: & quos uocauit, cos & iustificauit:
column8: & quos uocauit, cos & iustificauit:

column7: quos autem iustificauit, eos & glorificauit.
column8: quos autem iustificauit, eos & glorificauit.

column7: Thus we see, that the effectes of predestination, is iustification and glorification:
column8: Thus we see, that the effects of predestination, is justification and glorification:

column7: the which if the diuell coulde make vs to deny, he would soone make vs renouce our iustificatio:
column8: the which if the Devil could make us to deny, he would soon make us renounce our Justification:

column7: if he could make vs renouce our iustification, then wold he easyly persuade vs that ther wer no Christ, or that he died in vayne.
column8: if he could make us renounce our justification, then would he Easily persuade us that there were not christ, or that he died in vain.

column7: If he coulde cause vs to deny Christe, or to thynke that he died in vayne, then wolde he destroy the fayth:
column8: If he could cause us to deny Christ, or to think that he died in vain, then would he destroy the faith:

column7: if no man had fayth, that none shuld be saued:
column8: if no man had faith, that none should be saved:

column7: Qui non crediderit, condemnabitur.
column8: Qui non crediderit, condemnabitur.

column7: Take heed <NOTE> therfore that no man smell to this daungerous floure, least he erre agaynst the truth, and denye that whiche is confirmed by the truthe.
column8: Take heed Therefore that no man smell to this dangerous flower, lest he err against the truth, and deny that which is confirmed by the truth.

column7: For saynt Paule confirmynge oure election and predestination in Iesus Christ gaue harty thankes to god for it, as for the sweete conserue of the soule, and principall medicine to theym that by faithe cleane to Goddes promyse made in Christ, sayenge:
column8: For saint Paul confirming our election and predestination in jesus christ gave hearty thanks to god for it, as for the sweet conserve of the soul, and principal medicine to them that by faith clean to Goddess promise made in christ, saying:

column7: Benedictus deus et pater domini nostri Iesu Christi, qui benedixit nos i omni benedictioe spirituali
column8: Benedictus deus et pater domini Our Jesu Christ, qui benedixit nos i omni benedictioe Spiritual

column7: in coelestibus i Christo:
column8: in coelestibus i Christ:

column7: sicut elegit nos in ipso ante mundi constitutionem, ut essemus sancti & immaculati in conspectu eius in charitate.
column8: sicut elegit nos in ipso ante mundi constitutionem, ut essemus sancti & immaculati in conspectu eius in charitate.

column7: Qui praedestinauit nos in adoptionem filioru per^^sum Christum &c.
column8: Qui praedestinauit nos in adoptionem filioru per^^sum Christ etc.

column7: If there had ben no predestination, then wold not S.
column8: If there had been no predestination, then would not S.

column7: Paul haue giuen thanks to God for it.
column8: Paul have given thanks to God for it.

column7: But out of doubt ther is a predestynation, the whych is certayn in God, although it be vncertayne in vs, and none otherwyse knowen, but in that we fele the spirite of grace workyng fayth and obedience in our hartes vnto the word of god:
column8: But out of doubt there is a Predestination, the which is certain in God, although it be uncertain in us, and none otherwise known, but in that we feel the Spirit of grace working faith and Obedience in our hearts unto the word of god:

column7: and that is the true token wherby the spirite of god certifieth our spirites, that we at the electe sonnes of God.
column8: and that is the true token whereby the Spirit of god certifieth our spirits, that we At the elect Sons of God.

column7: Let no man therfore rashely iudge of gods holy predestination, but let euery man submyt his iudgement to the word of God, without curiositie, sekyng that ende in predestination, whiche sayncte Paul wylled the Ephesians to lerne, namely Elegit nos in ipso ut sancti essemus & immaculati in conspectu eius in charitate,
column8: Let no man Therefore rashly judge of God's holy predestination, but let every man submit his judgement to the word of God, without curiosity, seeking that end in predestination, which saint Paul willed the Ephesians to Learn, namely Elegit nos in ipso ut sancti essemus & immaculati in conspectu eius in charitate,

column7: That felyng this mynde and desyre in theim selues, they may reioyce in theyr election, and geue thaiskes with saint Paul.
column8: That feeling this mind and desire in them selves, they may rejoice in their election, and give thaiskes with saint Paul.

column7: Who so euer than ther be, that is faythfull, and coueteth rightly to vnderstande predestination, let hym attende vpon Christ, that he may fynde hym selfe in hym, without whom there can be found no worthy toke of Predestinatio.
column8: Who so ever than there be, that is faithful, and covets rightly to understand predestination, let him attend upon christ, that he may find him self in him, without whom there can be found no worthy took of Predestinatio.

column7: & beware that no man be so blynde, that he shulde deny the predestination of God, for so shoulde he declare hym selfe to be infected with this stynkyng floure of the dyuell.
column8: & beware that no man be so blind, that he should deny the predestination of God, for so should he declare him self to be infected with this stinking flower of the Devil.

column7: Nowe as it is a wycked errour to deny the Predestination of God, and our election in Christ, and a floure not to be found among christen men, so it is a moste damnable heresy, and an execrable flowre of hell, wherein may be smelled the poyson blasphemy of the dyuell agaynste the sonne of God Iesus Christe, to affirme and holde that by predestination God is the author of syn, where as we may learne in scripture, that the holy Predestination of God neuer passeth, but alwayes continueth within the boundes of Godlynes and ryghteousnes:
column8: Now as it is a wicked error to deny the Predestination of God, and our election in christ, and a flower not to be found among christian men, so it is a most damnable heresy, and an execrable flower of hell, wherein may be smelled the poison blasphemy of the Devil against the son of God jesus Christ, to affirm and hold that by predestination God is the author of sin, where as we may Learn in scripture, that the holy Predestination of God never passes, but always Continueth within the bounds of Godliness and righteousness:

column7: where by all myghty God at no tyme moueth any man to sinne:
column8: where by all mighty God At no time moves any man to sin:

column7: Vniuersae enim viae domini misericordia & veritas.
column8: Universae enim Viae domini misericordia & veritas.

column7: Saynt Iames therfore to declare <NOTE> that God is not the author of synne, sayth that God tempteth no man to euyll.
column8: Saint James Therefore to declare that God is not the author of sin, say that God tempts no man to evil.

column7: Satan is the cause of synne, and synne the cause of our punyshemente, what bryngeth the wrathe of God vpon vs, and maketh his anger so fierse ouer vs?
column8: Satan is the cause of sin, and sin the cause of our punishment, what bringeth the wrath of God upon us, and makes his anger so fierce over us?

column7: Syn. What is the cause that Gods truthe taketh no place in vs, and that we receyue the grace of god in vayne?
column8: Sin What is the cause that God's truth Takes no place in us, and that we receive the grace of god in vain?

column7: Synne. Therefore it is written,
column8: Sin. Therefore it is written,

column7: In cor maleuolu, non introibit sapientia:
column8: In cor maleuolu, non introibit sapientia:

column7: nec habitabit in corpore subdito peccatis.
column8: nec habitabit in corpore subdito peccatis.

column7: &c. Esai cofirmeth the same, saying:
column8: etc. Isaiah cofirmeth the same, saying:

column7: Your sinnes haue separate you frome god.
column8: Your Sins have separate you from god.

column7: Sainct Paule also teachig the Romains, wherwith God was and is displeased, sayd:
column8: Saint Paul also teachig the Romans, wherewith God was and is displeased, said:

column7: Reuelatur ira Dei de coelo super omnem iniustitiam & impietatem hominum.
column8: Reuelatur ira Dei de coelo super omnem iniustitiam & impietatem hominum.

column7: &c. If God bee than displeased at synne (as his word doth declare hym to be) than is he not the authour of syn, onlesse we shuld grant (as God forbyd) that he is both a mutable god or a dissembling God, which coueteth or alloweth that, which he saith by his word, he doth hate.
column8: etc. If God be than displeased At sin (as his word does declare him to be) than is he not the author of sin, unless we should grant (as God forbid) that he is both a mutable god or a dissembling God, which covets or alloweth that, which he Says by his word, he does hate.

column7: For he is the author of nothyng but of that whiche he aloweth.
column8: For he is the author of nothing but of that which he alloweth.

column7: As he therfore is good only, and goodnes it selfe, contrarye to all iniquitie:
column8: As he Therefore is good only, and Goodness it self, contrary to all iniquity:

column7: so is he author of all godlynes and vertue, and no syn.
column8: so is he author of all godliness and virtue, and no sin.

column7: For this cause hath he comanded vs to flee from all syn, as from a serpent:
column8: For this cause hath he commanded us to flee from all sin, as from a serpent:

column7: declaryng in his blessed testament, that they be blynd, as concernyng the knowlege of god, yea strangers from al truth, that say, thei haue felowship with the light,
column8: declaring in his blessed Testament, that they be blind, as Concerning the knowledge of god, yea Strangers from all truth, that say, they have fellowship with the Light,

column7: & yet walke in darkenes. <NOTE>
column8: & yet walk in darkness.

column7: Therfore he willeth al men to absteyn from syn, wherof he is not the author, but the hater:
column8: Therefore he wills all men to abstain from sin, whereof he is not the author, but the hater:

column7: not the cause, but aueger:
column8: not the cause, but aueger:

column7: & with a liuely faith to withstand the diuel, the author & only <NOTE> cause of syn, as it is writen:
column8: & with a lively faith to withstand the Devil, the author & only cause of sin, as it is written:

column7: Diabolus mendax est, & pater eius.
column8: Diabolus mendax est, & pater eius.

column7: Awai therfor with this pestilent floure & creping pestilece in ye dark, wherby ye diuell busily sekig our destruction,
column8: Away Therefore with this pestilent flower & creeping Pestilence in you dark, whereby you Devil busily sekig our destruction,

column7: laboureth to persuade vs litell to regard the lawe of God, to neglecte our conscience, to eschue no euyll, to folowe all mischiefe lyke vnbrideled horses:
column8: Laboureth to persuade us little to regard the law of God, to neglect's our conscience, to eschew no evil, to follow all mischief like unbridled Horses:

column7: and that bicause God is displeased at no synne, whiche is the author of all (as the dyuell teacheth.) But lette vs buylde our fayth vpon the word of god, sanctified and sealed with the bloud of Christe, wherby we are taught that God is holy, iust and good, and the cause of no synne, as it is wryten:
column8: and that Because God is displeased At no sin, which is the author of all (as the Devil Teaches.) But let us build our faith upon the word of god, sanctified and sealed with the blood of Christ, whereby we Are taught that God is holy, just and good, and the cause of no sin, as it is written:

column7: Quoniam non Deus uolens iniquitate tu es. Neque habitabit iuxta te malignus, neque permane bunt iniusti ante oculos tuos.
column8: Quoniam non Deus uolens iniquitate tu es. Neque habitabit Next te Malignus, neque permane bunt iniusti ante Eyes tuos.

column7: Odisti omnes qui operantur iniquitatem.
column8: Odisti omnes qui operantur iniquitatem.

column7: &c. Therefore by predestination god doth not prouoke or allure any man to synne, bycause he is god, and playeth not the part of the dyuel:
column8: etc. Therefore by predestination god does not provoke or allure any man to sin, Because he is god, and plays not the part of the Devil:

column7: but he hath predestinate his iudgement, wherwith he wyll reward euery man as he hath done, either lyfe or death, vnto whose predestination nothyng appertayneth, but iust condemnation to the vnbeleuers, and vndeserued mercy to the faythfull.
column8: but he hath predestinate his judgement, wherewith he will reward every man as he hath done, either life or death, unto whose predestination nothing appertaineth, but just condemnation to the unbelievers, and undeserved mercy to the faithful.

column7: Christe came to take away our synne, and there was no synne in hym.
column8: Christ Come to take away our sin, and there was no sin in him.

column7: As there was no synne in hym, so was there no synne of hym:
column8: As there was no sin in him, so was there no sin of him:

column7: that that was not of hym, was not his woorke:
column8: that that was not of him, was not his work:

column7: that whiche was not in his work, was not in his predestination. a damnable floure of the diuels orchard.
column8: that which was not in his work, was not in his predestination. a damnable flower of the Devils orchard.

column7: But if this flowre serue not, he hath an other ready in store, the smell whereof no lesse infecteth than thother. That is,

column7: For the poisonyng of this, ought to be to you a perpetuall warnyng, to beware the engins of the diuel, that he at no time bewitch you to fall into such an errour so farre against the truthe.

column7: By this blynd suggestio the dyuel goth to appeach Christs innocency, righteousnes & death, and to make hym an insufficient Sauiour, whereby he myghte make vs opynion, that the law were not satisfied for vs, neither yet God contented towardes vs.
column8: By this blind suggestio the Devil Goes to appeach Christ innocency, righteousness & death, and to make him an insufficient Saviour, whereby he might make us opinion, that the law were not satisfied for us, neither yet God contented towards us

column7: For God coulde not bee pleased towardes vs, vntyll his lawe were satisfied.
column8: For God could not be pleased towards us, until his law were satisfied.

column7: And the lawe coulde not bee satisfied, vntyll one that had not transgressyd the law, shuld be propitiation for their synnes, that were condemned by the law.
column8: And the law could not be satisfied, until one that had not transgressyd the law, should be propitiation for their Sins, that were condemned by the law.

column7: Seyng therfore that none could be found of the synfull generation of Adam, that hadde not in Adam transgressed the law,
column8: Sing Therefore that none could be found of the sinful generation of Adam, that had not in Adam transgressed the law,

column8: Factum sub lege, vt eos qui sub lege Erant, redimeret. which thing he could not do, if he had not been innocent and without sin.

column7: Moyses therefore to represente his innocency and puritie without syn, caused the chyldren of Israell whan they celebrated the passeouer, which represented the sacrifice of Christes bodye, to take a Lambe of one yeare, withoute spotte, in token that Christ was without synne.
column8: Moses Therefore to represent his innocency and purity without sin, caused the children of Israel when they celebrated the passover, which represented the sacrifice of Christ's body, to take a Lamb of one year, without spot, in token that christ was without sin.

column8: Isaiah also say: Christus Iniquitatem non fecit, neque dolus inuentus est in over

column8: eius. Christ Therefore being without sin, how could he die for his own sin?

column8: Oh subtle Devil, that so Canst enchant the minds of simple men, to make them so judge of the immaculate lamb jesus Christ

column7: But nowe that hee seeth hys enterpryse so shamelesse and wylfull, yea and open to all mennes eyes that it is espyed, hee passeth frome the boddye of Chryste, and blasphemeth hys holly Spirite.
column8: But now that he sees his enterprise so shameless and wilful, yea and open to all men's eyes that it is espied, he passes from the body of Christ, and Blasphemeth his holly Spirit.

column7: Therefore hee sheweth manne an other flower, where thoroughe hee woulde haue his foule perishe. Whych flower is thys.
column8: Therefore he shows man an other flower, where thorough he would have his foul perish. Which flower is this.

column7: That a manne hauynge the spirite of God, maye haue his neyghboures wyfe in common.
column8: That a man having the Spirit of God, may have his neighbours wife in Common.

column7: Thys flower is so fyltbye and so blasphemous an erroure againste God and hys hollye spyryte, that the abhominacion therof abhorrynge the verye lawe of nature, so condempneth it, that it needeth no farther confutacion.
column8: This flower is so fyltbye and so blasphemous an error against God and his holly Spirit, that the abomination thereof abhorring the very law of nature, so Condemneth it, that it needs no farther confutation.

column7: For what other thing meaneth the dyuell by thys flower, but to make whooredome and all suche abhominacions to bee frutes of Goddes spirit?
column8: For what other thing means the Devil by this flower, but to make whoredom and all such abominations to be fruits of Goddess Spirit?

column8: But now if the Devil can not persuade men to commit whoredom by the Spirit of God, whereby God in his wrath may take his holy Spirit from them, that they may perish, than he Takes an other shameful flour, to detestable to be spoken, whereby he Teaches men to affirm that, which God's word flatly Condemneth: namely

column7: That the inwarde manne synneth not, whan the vtter man synneth.
column8: That the inward man Sinneth not, when the utter man Sinneth.

column8: For while he promises him self;

column8: life, thorough a vain hope,

column8: & gyveth his members over to serve sin, he Becometh the servant of sin, whose reward is death.

column7: For ye outward ma neuer sinneth vnto deth, althogh no good thig dwelleth in it, but whan the inward manne consenteth thereto.
column8: For you outward ma never Sinneth unto death, although no good thig dwells in it, but when the inward man consenteth thereto.

column7: Therefore the serpent entrynge by oure fleshe assaulteth the soule with wycked temptacions, to make it obediente to the lustes of our flesh.
column8: Therefore the serpent entering by our Flesh assaulteth the soul with wicked temptations, to make it obedient to the lusts of our Flesh.

column7: Wherefore althoughe wee haue participate thorowe Adames disobedience the poysonned nature of the dyuell, whiche dwelleth in oure fleshe, and alwaies byddeth battayle against our soule, yet the dyuell obtaineth not hys praye, vntyll the soule of man (neglecting the grace of God) gyueth it selfe ouer wyth consence to serue the wycked apperytes of the fleshe.
column8: Wherefore although we have participate thorough Adams disobedience the poisoned nature of the Devil, which dwells in our Flesh, and always biddeth battle against our soul, yet the Devil obtaineth not his pray, until the soul of man (neglecting the grace of God) gyveth it self over with consence to serve the wicked apperytes of the Flesh.

column7: Sayncte Paule therefore wyllynge manne to contynue Goddes warryar agaynste synne both in body and soule, cryeth to the Romaynes:
column8: Saint Paul Therefore willing man to continue Goddess warryar against sin both in body and soul, Cries to the Romans:

column7: Lette not synne <NOTE> raygne in youre mortall boddyes, that yee shoulde fulfyll the lustes thereof.
column8: Let not sin Reign in your Mortal bodies, that ye should fulfil the lusts thereof.

column7: Whan raigneth it, but when the soule is be come the bonde slaue to the fleshe?
column8: When Reigneth it, but when the soul is be come the bond slave to the Flesh?

column7: whyche oughte thoroughe the spyrite of grace, to raigne and rule.
column8: which ought thorough the Spirit of grace, to Reign and Rule.

column7: Therefore Sayncte Paule saith: Looke to whome yee giue ouer youre selues to obeye, his seruauntes yee are to whom yee obeye, whether it bee synne vnto deathe, or righteousnes vnto lyfe.
column8: Therefore Saint Paul Says: Look to whom ye give over your selves to obey, his Servants ye Are to whom ye obey, whither it be sin unto death, or righteousness unto life.

column7: To gyue ouer and obeye what meaneth it, but when thorow grace we serue God in soule and body, or els serue the dyuell in soule and body?
column8: To gyve over and obey what means it, but when thorough grace we serve God in soul and body, or Else serve the Devil in soul and body?

column7: Dauid the prophete not infected with thys floure, but knowing that the bodye sinning, the soule coulde not be free, yea rather confessyng al mischief to procede from the inward man, ouercomme and obeying the dyuell, cried vnto the Lorde, who onely coulde helpe him:
column8: David the Prophet not infected with this flower, but knowing that the body sinning, the soul could not be free, yea rather confessing all mischief to proceed from the inward man, overcome and obeying the Devil, cried unto the Lord, who only could help him:

column8: & Spiritum rectum innoua in visceribus meis.

column8: Which petition he would never have made, if he had Thought, that the inner man sinned not, when the outward man sinned.

column7: Why shoulde the Prophet Ioel haue wylled the people of Israell to rente their hartes and not their cloths, yf he had thought, (as the dyuell wolde haue men thynke,) that the inwarde man synned not?
column8: Why should the Prophet Joel have willed the people of Israel to rend their hearts and not their clothes, if he had Thought, (as the Devil would have men think,) that the inward man sinned not?

column8: another flour the Devil hath in store, if this serveth not to infect men soul withal, whereby he would have him presume of him self, to do that which is not in him self.

column8: This flour is a pestilent flower, wherewith the Devil hath in time past deceived many.

column8: This flour is, that by free will, sprung of our own nature, we may believe the gospel, and do all things pleasing to God.

column8: God's word does prove, willing all men to beware of them, for as as by them, sinful man is Set in the place of our righteous God, and may come to heaven, if this were not an error, whither God will or no.

column8: But the word of God does not allow any man to cotemne or mislike any public order, Set forth by his superiors authorised thereunto, which order is consonant to the word of god, whither it be in ceremonies, or any thing apertainyng to godly Religion,
