column8: Paul, Omnis anima potestatibus sublimioribus

column7: subdita sit, &c. Who soeuer therfore, eyther in ceremonies or godly religion, dooth not conforme hym selfe to the comon order;
column8: subdita sit, etc. Who soever Therefore, either in ceremonies or godly Religion, doth not conform him self to the Common order;

column7: but mislykyng the comon order, choose ceremonies and doctrines of theyr owne inuentions, are authours of sectes.
column8: but misliking the Common order, choose ceremonies and doctrines of their own Inventions, Are Authors of Sects.

column7: I doo not here counte it vnlaufull, neyther cause of diuision for any man to vse in his house any priuate order, for the tradynge vp of his youthe in vertue and godlynesse, so that it be consonant to the woord of God, and in no contempt of the common order.
column8: I do not Here count it unlawful, neither cause of division for any man to use in his house any private order, for the trading up of his youth in virtue and godliness, so that it be consonant to the word of God, and in no contempt of the Common order.

column7: But if the diuell can not cause men by his crafty illusyons, to condemne thynges done by the superyour powers conuenable to the truthe, and make innouations contrarye to the lawes, than hee laboureth to poyson men with the stinkyng floure of separation or segregation from other, as from wycked and damned men, not worthy to communicate the sacramentes, or to eate and drynke with them.
column8: But if the Devil can not cause men by his crafty illusyons, to condemn things done by the superyour Powers convenable to the truth, and make innovations contrary to the laws, than he Laboureth to poison men with the stinking flower of separation or segregation from other, as from wicked and damned men, not worthy to communicate the Sacraments, or to eat and drink with them.

column7: This flowre howe farre it dissenteth from the exaumple of Christe, it easyly may be perceyued to them, whiche with humble hartes reade the woord of god.
column8: This flower how Far it dissenteth from the Exampl of Christ, it Easily may be perceived to them, which with humble hearts read the word of god.

column7: For Christ although he were the sonne of God, rightuous, holy, and voyde of al synne, whiche of his iustyce coulde not but hate synne and wyckednes, yet of his mercy he soughte theim that were all togyther vnrightuous, and dyd not separate hym selfe from theim.
column8: For christ although he were the son of God, righteous, holy, and void of all sin, which of his Justice could not but hate sin and wickedness, yet of his mercy he sought them that were all together unrighteous, and did not separate him self from them.

column7: As wel he entred into the house of the Pharisey <NOTE> as into the house of the Publican, and eate as well with the one, as he dyd with the other.
column8: As well he entered into the house of the Pharisee as into the house of the Publican, and eat as well with the one, as he did with the other.

column7: Whiche thyng if it had been vnlauful for a true christian to do, we shuld haue had in hym no suche example But when he eate or dranke with them, or came into their company, he endeuored to bryng them by charitable persuasion to the obedience of faythe,
column8: Which thing if it had been unlawful for a true christian to doe, we should have had in him not such Exampl But when he eat or drank with them, or Come into their company, he endeavoured to bring them by charitable persuasion to the Obedience of faith,

column7: & to the vnitie of the spirit, from their impietie and vngodlynes.
column8: & to the unity of the Spirit, from their impiety and ungodliness.

column7: Bicause he came to saue,
column8: Because he Come to save,

column7: & not to lose, as it is written:
column8: & not to loose, as it is written:

column7: The son of man cam not into the world, to condemn ye world, but that the worlde shulde haue lyfe by hym.
column8: The son of man cam not into the world, to condemn you world, but that the world should have life by him.

column7: It is therefore laufull for any true christian, to come into the company of the vngodly, so longe as he foloweth the example of Iesus Christ.
column8: It is Therefore lawful for any true christian, to come into the company of the ungodly, so long as he Followeth the Exampl of jesus christ.

column7: Yea we ought to haue y same mynd in vs, that was in Christe Iesu, namely to seke to draw the vngodly from synne to vertue, from corrupt maners to a godly conuersation, and not vtterly to condemne them as cast awaies, in respect of our selues.
column8: Yea we ought to have y same mind in us, that was in Christ Jesu, namely to seek to draw the ungodly from sin to virtue, from corrupt manners to a godly Conversation, and not utterly to condemn them as cast aways, in respect of our selves.

column7: A daungerous thyng it is to take Goddes office in hand, or to iudge this ma or that ma condened without any exception:
column8: A dangerous thing it is to take Goddess office in hand, or to judge this ma or that ma condened without any exception:

column7: Seyng it is to vs vncertayn who perisheth in his syn.
column8: Sing it is to us uncertain who Perishes in his sin.

column7: We must therfore leaue that to God.
column8: We must Therefore leave that to God.

column7: Cleere he ought to be that shulde condemne an other, least haply it be said to him, as was sayd to the Phariseis:
column8: Clear he ought to be that should condemn an other, lest haply it be said to him, as was said to the Pharisees:

column7: Cast the first stone. and so he go away ashamed.
column8: Cast the First stone. and so he go away ashamed.

column7: Therefore it is written, Iuge not, lest ye be iudged.
column8: Therefore it is written, Judge not, lest you be judged.

column7: But it is forbidden by the worde of God, that any christen man shuld kepe company with the vngodly to folow their vngodlynes, or to communicate with them in their synnes:
column8: But it is forbidden by the word of God, that any christian man should keep company with the ungodly to follow their ungodliness, or to communicate with them in their Sins:

column7: that dyd we not see in the Lorde Iesus, neither maye a christian man doo so without blame.
column8: that did we not see in the Lord jesus, neither may a christian man do so without blame.

column7: Example we haue in Iosaphat, who was blamed of the Lord for goyng with wicked Achab, and doyng the same enterprise with hym, whiche Achab was forbidden to doo.
column8: Exampl we have in Josaphat, who was blamed of the Lord for going with wicked Ahab, and doing the same enterprise with him, which Ahab was forbidden to do.

column7: Salomon sayth, Si te lactauerint peccatores, ne ^cquiescas. And Paul sayth,
column8: Solomon say, Si te lactauerint Peccatores, ne ^cquiescas. And Paul say,

column7: Peccatis alienis ne communicaueritis. When the vngodly do declare them selues to be ennemies of God, and of all goodnes (Ex fruct^bus ipsoru^, cognoscetis eos, and by none other way) then a christen man must vse that order, whyche Christe hath apointed in his holy testament belongyng to a priuate man, that is,
column8: Peccatis alienis ne communicaueritis. When the ungodly do declare them selves to be enemies of God, and of all Goodness (Ex fruct^bus ipsoru^, You will know eos, and by none other Way) then a christian man must use that order, which Christ hath appointed in his holy Testament belonging to a private man, that is,

column7: Fyrste secretely to admonyshe the offendant, than to call two or thre witnesses:
column8: First secretly to admonish the offendant, than to call two or Three Witnesses:

column7: if he than doothe not amende, publyshe hym to the congregacion, or to the authorised disciplinatours:
column8: if he than doth not amend, publish him to the congregation, or to the authorised disciplinatours:

column7: and he excommunicated by them out of the congregation, shall separate hym selfe frome the good christians, and they shall also separate them selues from him, as from an Ethnike, vntill he by repentance be admittted agayne.
column8: and he excommunicated by them out of the congregation, shall separate him self from the good Christians, and they shall also separate them selves from him, as from an Ethnic, until he by Repentance be admitted again.

column7: But if the churche or authorised disciplinatours be in this their office negliget, and wyl not excommunicate suche as be notorious & manyfest euyl workers, than must the priuate man comitte the matter to god, desyryng hym to redresse suche an abuse, beyng contented to lyue in the church, and receyue the sacramentes, without separation, assured that the wyckednes of the wycked, can not make an holy thyng vnholy or vnprofitable to hym, so long as he beleueth in Christe, and kepeth hym selfe vnspotted fro their vnrightousnes.
column8: But if the Church or authorised disciplinatours be in this their office negliget, and will not excommunicate such as be notorious & manifest evil workers, than must the private man comitte the matter to god, desiring him to redress such an abuse, being contented to live in the Church, and receive the Sacraments, without separation, assured that the wickedness of the wicked, can not make an holy thing unholy or unprofitable to him, so long as he Believeth in Christ, and Keepeth him self unspotted from their unrighteousness.

column7: Scripture muche commendeth vnitie and concorde. therfore lette vs cast away all diuision, and growe to the vnitie of the holy spirite.
column8: Scripture much commends unity and concord. Therefore let us cast away all division, and grow to the unity of the holy Spirit.

column7: Let those that bee spirituall, helpe to amend them that are out of the way, in the spirite of mekenes, consyderyng them selues that they may fall.
column8: Let those that be spiritual, help to amend them that Are out of the Way, in the Spirit of meekness, considering them selves that they may fallen.

column7: Labour therefore by a godly conuersation and gostely councell to call them to repentance that do yll, charitably seke them that go astray, without condemnyng them as cast awaies, or iustifyeng your selues.
column8: Labour Therefore by a godly Conversation and ghostly council to call them to Repentance that do ill, charitably seek them that go astray, without condemning them as cast aways, or iustifyeng your selves.

column7: But yet I will no man to neglect circumspection, although I reproue vncharitable separation.
column8: But yet I will no man to neglect circumspection, although I reprove uncharitable separation.

column7: The wysedome of God dooth not teache me to seke an other, and lose my selfe.
column8: The Wisdom of God doth not teach me to seek an other, and loose my self.

column7: Wherfore if any man perceyue the fragilitie of his nature to be suche, or rather his weaknes, that by occasyons he is apt to forgette hym selfe, to offend god, and to tourne backe to his vomite agayne by kepyng company or familiaritie with them that will not bee warned to leaue their beastly behauiour, than I thinke it good for that man to withdrawe him selfe from those occasions, and grow stroger.
column8: Wherefore if any man perceive the fragility of his nature to be such, or rather his weakness, that by occasions he is apt to forget him self, to offend god, and to turn back to his vomit again by keeping company or familiarity with them that will not be warned to leave their beastly behaviour, than I think it good for that man to withdraw him self from those occasions, and grow stroger.

column7: For to this end dothe the scriptures tend, which treate of eschewyng euyll company, that no man by keepynge therin companye, shoulde fall to lyke vngodlynesse, and not to separate them selues from other, as though thei alone were onely iust, and all other condemned.
column8: For to this end doth the Scriptures tend, which Treat of Eschewing evil company, that no man by keeping therein company, should fallen to like ungodliness, and not to separate them selves from other, as though they alone were only just, and all other condemned.

column7: Who so commytteth herein, dooth declare him self to be infected with this naughty floure.
column8: Who so Committeth herein, doth declare him self to be infected with this naughty flower.

column7: But truly I know none that vseth any suche separation:
column8: But truly I know none that uses any such separation:

column7: yf there bee any, God reduce them into the way of truthe.
column8: if there be any, God reduce them into the Way of truth.

column7: Where this peuyshe floure serueth not, he hath an other very fowle and stynkynge, to corrupte mans soule withall.
column8: Where this peuyshe flower serveth not, he hath an other very fowl and stinking, to corrupt men soul withal.

column7: As these are to pestylent to be founde among christians:
column8: As these Are to pestilent to be found among Christians:

column7: Namely to deny that childern be borne in originall synne:
column8: Namely to deny that children be born in original sin:

column7: or that a manne after baptisme can not fall into deadely synne:
column8: or that a man After Baptism can not fallen into deadly sin:

column7: or beynge so fallen, canne not be renewed agayne by repentaunce:
column8: or being so fallen, can not be renewed again by Repentance:

column7: or to denye the baptisme of infantes.
column8: or to deny the Baptism of Infants.

column7: Howe the worde of god doth confute these errours, and deface these floures,
column8: How the word of god does confute these errors, and deface these flowers,

column7: I woulde declare yf tyme serued:
column8: I would declare if time served:

column7: But bycause it is shorte, and I haue somewhat more to saye, lette it bee sufficient for you to knowe, that they are pestylent and vnwholsom floures.
column8: But Because it is short, and I have somewhat more to say, let it be sufficient for you to know, that they Are pestilent and unwholesome flowers.

column7: An other flowre the dyuell hath, wherwith he laboureth to make men breake godly order, whiche is this:
column8: an other flower the Devil hath, wherewith he Laboureth to make men break godly order, which is this:

column7: That it is laufull to be a publyke preacher in a christian comon welth, without the authoritie of the christen magistrates.
column8: That it is lawful to be a public preacher in a christian Common wealth, without the Authority of the christian Magistrates.

column7: But leaue this floure to the dyuell agayne, whyche is and euer wyll bee, an ennemye to christian order.
column8: But leave this flower to the Devil again, which is and ever will be, an enemy to christian order.

column7: And knowe you, that it is not laufull in a christian common weale to be a publyke preacher, without the authoritie of the hygher powers.
column8: And know you, that it is not lawful in a christian Common weal to be a public preacher, without the Authority of the higher Powers.

column7: An other flowre the dyuell hathe in store, wherwith he woulde perswade man, that in this lyfe he may attayne suche a perfection, that he shall synne in nothynge.
column8: an other flower the Devil hath in store, wherewith he would persuade man, that in this life he may attain such a perfection, that he shall sin in nothing.

column7: And this is that dotyng floure, that a ma may kepe the comandementes of god so perfectly and absolutely, that he shall synne in nothynge, nor haue nothyng wherof to aske Gods mercy.
column8: And this is that doting flower, that a ma may keep the Commandments of god so perfectly and absolutely, that he shall sin in nothing, nor have nothing whereof to ask God's mercy.

column7: But beware of this floure, whiche sauoureth more of imagination tha of knoweledge:
column8: But beware of this flower, which savoureth more of imagination tha of knowledge:

column7: more lyke a dreame than a truth:
column8: more like a dream than a truth:

column7: more of foly, than of godly wisedom.
column8: more of folly, than of godly Wisdom.

column7: For by it the dyuell goeth about, eyther to make vs forgetfull of oure imbecillitie, that we myght the lesse regard our strength and protection Iesus Christ:
column8: For by it the Devil Goes about, either to make us forgetful of our imbecility, that we might the less regard our strength and protection jesus christ:

column7: or els that in the ende whan our conscience doth accuse vs of offence agaynst God, and his holy comandementes (that they be not perfectly kepte) he may thrust vs downe headlong to desperation.
column8: or Else that in the end when our conscience does accuse us of offence against God, and his holy Commandments (that they be not perfectly kept) he may thrust us down headlong to desperation.

column7: We must therfore refuse the sauoure of this floure, and nouryshe oure soule with the swete odour of the truthe, by whom wee may learne our imbecillitie to bee suche, and the corruption of our nature so greate, that neither we can or may kepe gods holy commaundementes, so absolutely (no although we haue the grace of God) that here we shal synne in nothyng.
column8: We must Therefore refuse the savour of this flower, and nourish our soul with the sweet odour of the truth, by whom we may Learn our imbecility to be such, and the corruption of our nature so great, that neither we can or may keep God's holy Commandments, so absolutely (no although we have the grace of God) that Here we shall sin in nothing.

column7: The experience whereof he shal easyly haue ye beholdeth himselfe wel in the lawe of God, wherby he shall see how infirme he is to obserue the fyrst commaundement so perfectly, as the lawe requyreth, namely,
column8: The experience whereof he shall Easily have the beholdeth himself well in the law of God, whereby he shall see how infirm he is to observe the fyrst Commandment so perfectly, as the law requireth, namely,

column7: Diliges Dominum Deum tuum, ex toto corde,
column8: Diligent Dominum God tuum, ex toto cord,

column7: &c. Wherefore God of hys infinite goodnes, consydering our imperfection how we are letred thorow our weaknes, and want of our owne power, to keepe the commaundementes of God Yea althoughe our soule desyreth to keepe them, being therto moued by grace, he sent his deer son Iesus Christe to be the fulfillyng of the lawe in vs, as S.
column8: etc. Wherefore God of his infinite Goodness, considering our imperfection how we Are letred thorough our weakness, and want of our own power, to keep the Commandments of God Yea although our soul desireth to keep them, being thereto moved by grace, he sent his deer son jesus Christ to be the fulfilling of the law in us, as S.

column7: Paule sayth: Vt i^stitia legis impleretur in nobis, qui non secundum carnem versamur, sed secundum spiritum.
column8: Paul say: Vt i^stitia Legis impleretur in nobis, qui non secundum Carnem versamur, sed secundum spiritum.

column7: This is therefore to all faithfull christians no smalle consolation, that although our weaknes be such, that we can not heere so perfectly obserue gods commaundementes and synne in nothynge, yet we are assured by the promise of God, made in Christ, yf we be faithful, that he wil supply that which wanteth in vs, and wil make his perfection to be oures, in whom we shall bee presented before the throne of god, fauteles, as the membres of his precious bodye to eternal life.
column8: This is Therefore to all faithful Christians no small consolation, that although our weakness be such, that we can not Here so perfectly observe God's Commandments and sin in nothing, yet we Are assured by the promise of God, made in christ, if we be faithful, that he will supply that which Wants in us, and will make his perfection to be ours, in whom we shall be presented before the throne of god, fauteles, as the members of his precious body to Eternal life.

column7: So that we shall not feare in the ende thys stynkynge flour, or the dyuels accusation,
column8: So that we shall not Fear in the end this stinking flour, or the Devils accusation,

column7: seyng that our Sauioure Chryste <NOTE> is made of God, our wysedome, our righteousnes, our sanctification and redemption.
column8: sing that our Saviour Christ is made of God, our Wisdom, our righteousness, our sanctification and redemption.

column7: Let vs therefore committe our selues to the Lord wyth weldoyng, beyng out of doubt that it shall not perysh, that with an vnfayned hope is committed to hys charge.
column8: Let us Therefore commit our selves to the Lord with welldoing, being out of doubt that it shall not perish, that with an unfeigned hope is committed to his charge.

column7: Qui confidit in illo, non pudefiet.
column8: Qui confidit in illo, non pudefiet.

column7: But if the dyuell can not end aunger man soule wyth these floures, yet that hee make man offende in some thynge, hee seeketh by tri^les to moue seisme and contentio, that vnitye (which he so muche hateth) & concorde in the truthe, might fade and not growe.
column8: But if the Devil can not end anger man soul with these flowers, yet that he make man offend in Some thing, he seeks by Trifles to move seisme and Contention, that unity (which he so much hates) & concord in the truth, might fade and not grow.

column7: Therefore hee moueth muche strife, by the particular callyng of Brother & Syster, as thoughe Christes churche were dyuided, or that God fauoured suche particularitie and diuysion.
column8: Therefore he moves much strife, by the particular calling of Brother & Sister, as though Christ's Church were dyuided, or that God favoured such particularity and diuysion.

column7: But God is the god of peace, and hys delyghte is in godlye vnitie, whyche is the bonde of perfectnes, wherevnto hee willeth all true christians to contend, and wyth it to certifye theym selues, that they are in Christ, sonnes of God, and one an others brother, without all carnalitye or particularitie.
column8: But God is the god of peace, and his delyghte is in godly unity, which is the bond of perfectness, whereunto he wills all true Christians to contend, and with it to certify them selves, that they Are in christ, Sons of God, and one an Others brother, without all carnality or particularity.

column7: Whosoeuer therfore doth call any man or woman brother and syster otherwyse then he calleth all other christian men,
column8: Whosoever Therefore does call any man or woman brother and sister otherwise then he calls all other christian men,

column7: Peccat in vnitatem ecclesiae.
column8: Peccat in vnitatem ecclesiae.

column8: The other triflig flour of Schism & contetio is

column7: That it is deadly syn to play at any game for money.
column8: That it is deadly sin to play At any game for money.

column7: By this he laboreth to thrust into mas heart such a precisenes, that at length a good ma might iudg euery thing although it wer but indifferent, to be damnable sin.
column8: By this he Laboureth to thrust into mass heart such a preciseness, that At length a good ma might judge every thing although it were but indifferent, to be damnable since.

column7: Beware thee fore good christias of this subtle floor,
column8: Beware thee before good Christians of this subtle floor,

column7: & that to play at games of it self is not deadly syn, but the abusyng of our selfe in playinge, is damnable synne, and great wyckednes, who soeuer is permitted to playe at anye game by the lawe, as cardes and dyce and suche lyke, although the games of them selues be not deadlye synne, yet if hee blaspheme the name of God, maintaine in play a couetous hearte, vse his mouthe in fylthy communication, or suche lyke vngodlynes, no doubte he committeth deadly synne.
column8: & that to play At games of it self is not deadly sin, but the abusing of our self in playing, is damnable sin, and great wickedness, who soever is permitted to play At any game by the law, as cards and dice and such like, although the games of them selves be not deadly sin, yet if he Blaspheme the name of God, maintain in play a covetous heart, use his Mouth in filthy communication, or such like ungodliness, no doubt he Committeth deadly sin.

column7: Also hee that is forbydden by the lawe to playe, if he playe in the contempt of the Law, spendeth the time Gods creature in ydlenes, hys house beyng vnprouided for, which ought to be bestowed in hys honest labour or yf he teare the Lordes body with horrible othes, spend his goodes prodigally, or with crafty legerdemaine as byfoisting, cogging-girking or false dyce, wineth away his neighbours money, or rageth in wrath, swelleth with spite, deliteth in braulig, fightig & such like mischief, althogh ye game of it self be not deadly syn, yet they y thus abuseth themselues in play, sinne danably.
column8: Also he that is forbidden by the law to play, if he play in the contempt of the Law, spendeth the time God's creature in idleness, his house being unprovided for, which ought to be bestowed in his honest labour or if he tear the lords body with horrible Oaths, spend his goods prodigally, or with crafty legerdemain as byfoisting, cogging-girking or false dice, winneth away his neighbours money, or rages in wrath, Swells with spite, delighteth in braulig, fightig & such like mischief, although you game of it self be not deadly sin, yet they y thus abuseth themselves in play, sin danably.

column7: Pityfull it is to se how licentiously those that be forbidden by pollicy, spend their time in vnlawfull games, yea more lamentable it is to se ye the officers appointed for y search and correction of suche brothels and brothel houses, so neglecte theyr dutye.
column8: Pitiful it is to see how licentiously those that be forbidden by policy, spend their time in unlawful games, yea more lamentable it is to see you the Officers appointed for y search and correction of such brothels and brothel houses, so neglect's their duty.

column7: For thys is a common practise, that in euerye markette towne for the moste parte these haserders make their pryuye conuenticles and meetinges vppon the markette or fayre daye, where the one robbeth the other, both of wytte and monye.
column8: For this is a Common practice, that in every market town for the most part these haserders make their pryuye conventicles and meetings upon the market or fair day, where the one robbeth the other, both of wit and money.

column7: In the meane tyme whilest they bee at their merye fare, the wynes haue at home sorow ynough, whan they heare their chyldren trye:
column8: In the mean time whilst they be At their merry fare, the wines have At home sorrow enough, when they hear their children try:

column7: Mother gyue me bread, and they haue no crume to quench their hunger with all, yet these iollye rutters fare well, and thynke theym selues ryche in the dyce house, where as maister beggar ruleth the roaste at home, and pyncheth bothe wyfe and chyldren by the bellye.
column8: Mother gyve me bred, and they have no crume to quench their hunger with all, yet these jolly rutters fare well, and think them selves rich in the dice house, where as master beggar Ruleth the roast At home, and pyncheth both wife and children by the belly.

column7: But Saynct Paule sayeth: He that prouydeth not for his familye, is woorse thanne an infydell.
column8: But Saint Paul Saith: He that prouydeth not for his family, is Worse than an infydell.

column7: O myserye of myseries, to muche putte in practise in these oure dayes, as the eyes of poore wyues almost oute wyth weping, and the paale coulour and thynne cheekes of poore children can testifye.
column8: O misery of miseries, to much put in practice in these our days, as the eyes of poor wives almost out with weeping, and the paale colour and thin cheeks of poor children can testify.

column7: God graunte it maye bee amended in tyme, leaste worse euels happen thereby.
column8: God grant it may be amended in time, jest Worse evils happen thereby.

column7: These are the beautifull flouts of the dyuel, wherwith he seeketh nowe, as hee hathe doone in tymes paste, to blynde the eyes of theym that leade a sober lyfe.
column8: These Are the beautiful flouts of the Devil, wherewith he seeks now, as he hath done in times past, to blind the eyes of them that lead a Sobrium life.

column7: These he straweth before them to thys ende, that of good lyuers, they may become euell speakers, and so receiue to their confusio the grace of God in vayne.
column8: These he straweth before them to this end, that of good livers, they may become evil Speakers, and so receive to their Confusion the grace of God in vain.

column7: Wherefore good people, seynge the mysterye of these erronious or scismaticall floures is detected vnto you, wherein ye see as it were in a glasse, wyth what wylynes the dyuell goeth aboute to obscure vertue, by impure doctrine and erronious folly^, let this rude detection therefore be a warnynge vnto you, to flee from hys subtelty.
column8: Wherefore good people, sing the mystery of these erroneous or scismaticall flowers is detected unto you, wherein you see as it were in a glass, with what wylynes the Devil Goes about to Obscure virtue, by impure Doctrine and erroneous folly^, let this rude detection Therefore be a warning unto you, to flee from his subtlety.

column7: Cleane to the truthe, O thou louer of vertue,

column8: But God for their ypocrisy strake them with blindness & dasynes of heart, whereby they Thought they were well, when their case was miserable. they Thought themselves in Light, when they were in darkness. and to be the Sons of God, when they were (as their fruits did declare thee) children of the Devil.

column8: yea Some be (I Fear me) grown in such wilful wickedness, that neither the terrible Judgments of God, neither worldly shame will drive them from their sin, but as past graces, they never leave to work wickedness, till it forsake them, that is, till they can sin no more.

column7: Lefte the byshoppes commende theym selues as the mynisters of God, that no fault be found in theyr ministration, whan this iudge shall appeare.
column8: Left the Bishops commend them selves as the Ministers of God, that no fault be found in their ministration, when this judge shall appear.

column7: Let the iustices behaue theym selues as the ministers of God, in the true and iuste execution of the lawes, without all corrupte affections, defendyng the welldoer, and punishyng the yll, that no faulte bee founde in their ministrye.
column8: Let the Justices behave them selves as the Ministers of God, in the true and just execution of the laws, without all corrupt affections, defending the welldoer, and punishing the ill, that no fault be found in their Ministry.

column7: Let the other officers be dylygente & not slacke in their mynistry, neyther wink whan they ought to se, that no faulte be founde in their ministration.
column8: Let the other Officers be dylygente & not slack in their mynistry, neither wink when they ought to see, that no fault be found in their ministration.

column7: Ye husbandes loue your wiues, and bee <NOTE> not bytter vnto them, but dwell wyth theim accordyng to knowledge, gyuinge honoure vnto them, as vnto the weaker vessell, and coheare wyth you of grace, that your praiers be not letted.
column8: the Husbands love your wives, and be not bitter unto them, but dwell with them according to knowledge, gyving honour unto them, as unto the Weaker vessel, and coheare with you of grace, that your Prayers be not letted.

column7: Ye wemen be ye subiect to your own husbandes <NOTE> as to the Lord, and obey them euen as Sara obeyed Abraham, callynge hym Lord, whose daughters ye are, so long as yee doo well.
column8: You women be you Subject to your own Husbands as to the Lord, and obey them even as Sarah obeyed Abraham, calling him Lord, whose daughters you Are, so long as ye do well.

column7: Ye fathers prouoke not your children vnto <NOTE> wrath, but brynge theym vp in nourture and informacion of the Lord.
column8: You Father's provoke not your children unto wrath, but bring them up in nurture and information of the Lord.

column7: Ye children obey your parents in the lord,
column8: You children obey your Parents in the lord,

column7: <NOTE> for that is good.
column8: for that is good.

column7: Honour thy father and mother. that is the fyrst commanndement that hath any promise, that it may bee well wyth the, and that thou maist liue long vpo earth.
column8: Honour thy father and mother. that is the fyrst commanndement that hath any promise, that it may be well with thee, and that thou Mayest live long upon earth.

column7: Ye seruantes obey your bodylye maisters <NOTE> with feare and tremblyng, in the synglenes of your heart, as vnto Christe, not with eye seruyce as men pleasers, but as the seruants of Christ, doing the wil of God hartely with a good will, seruyng the lorde and not men, knowyng that what good euery man doth, therof he shalbe rewarded of the lorde, whether yt he be bond or free.
column8: You Servants obey your bodily masters with Fear and trembling, in the synglenes of your heart, as unto Christ, not with eye service as men pleasers, but as the Servants of christ, doing the will of God heartily with a good will, serving the lord and not men, knowing that what good every man does, thereof he shall rewarded of the lord, whither that he be bound or free.

column7: God work this in seruantes hearts in these our daies, for surely they had neuer more need to be amended.
column8: God work this in Servants hearts in these our days, for surely they had never more need to be amended.

column7: Ye maisters do the same to them without <NOTE> crueltye, knowynge that your mayster is in heauen, before whome there is no acception of persons.
column8: You masters do the same to them without cruelty, knowing that your master is in heaven, before whom there is no acception of Persons.

column7: Therefore to conclude (bycause I purpose to eschew redyousnes) let euery man in that office wherevnto hee is called, behaue hym selfe as the mynister of God, that in hys offyce no faulte bee founde.
column8: Therefore to conclude (Because I purpose to eschew redyousnes) let every man in that office whereunto he is called, behave him self as the minister of God, that in his office no fault be found.

column7: Than no doubt whan the housholder commeth frome farre, to take accompte and to vewe the dooynges of hys seruantes, these whyche hee fyndeth faythfull as hys true mynysters, occupyed in the dylygente execution of their ministration, hee wyll boun^efullye rewarde for hys promyse sake.
column8: Than no doubt when the householder comes from Far, to take accompt and to view the doings of his Servants, these which he findeth faithful as his true Ministers, ocupied in the dylygente execution of their ministration, he will boun^efullye reward for his promise sake.

column7: And they shall hear thys comfortable word,
column8: And they shall hear this comfortable word,

column7: Euge serue bone: where as they whyche deale vntruely in their mynystration, smyte their fellowes, waste theyr maysters good in voluptuousnes, shall bee not onlye rebuked wyth these sharpe woordes, serue nequam, but also heauylye rewarded with vtter darkenesse, where shall bee weepynge and gnasshyng of teethe.
column8: Euge serve bone: where as they which deal untruly in their mynystration, smite their Fellows, waste their masters good in voluptuousness, shall be not only rebuked with these sharp words, serve nequam, but also heavily rewarded with utter darkness, where shall be weeping and gnashing of teeth.

column7: God make vs of the noumbre of the faithfull seruauntes. Amen.
column8: God make us of the number of the faithful Servants. Amen.

column7: Now haue you heard deerly beloued chrystians the exhortacion or supplication of S.
column8: Now have you herd dearly Beloved Christians the exhortation or supplication of S.

column7: Paul made vnto the Corinthias,
column8: Paul made unto the Corinthians,

column7: Whereby as he willed them, so hath he done vs, not to receyue the grace of God in vayne.
column8: Whereby as he willed them, so hath he done us, not to receive the grace of God in vain.

column7: Also ye haue hearde howe the dyuell laboured to make them vnthankefull receyuers thereof:
column8: Also you have heard how the Devil laboured to make them unthankful Receivers thereof:

column7: and howe at this day he seeketh vs to be the same:
column8: and how At this day he seeks us to be the same:

column7: And that by two wayes pryncipally, eyther by corruptynge good lyuers with yll speakyng,
column8: And that by two ways principally, either by corrupting good livers with ill speaking,

column7: I mean doctrine, or els good speakers with yll lyuynge.
column8: I mean Doctrine, or Else good Speakers with ill living.

column7: I haue shewed you what floures he straweth afore me to bryng this his polycie to passe.
column8: I have showed you what flowers he straweth afore me to bring this his policy to pass.

column7: Then I declared howe the holy men in tyme past thankefully receyued the grace of God, and refused the delusions of the dyuell.
column8: Then I declared how the holy men in time passed thankfully received the grace of God, and refused the delusions of the Devil.

column7: Wherefore God of his great mercy hearde them in an accepted tyme, and succoured them.
column8: Wherefore God of his great mercy heard them in an accepted time, and succored them.

column7: In conclusyon: I told you, that nowe is that accepted tyme and day of saluation. wherin I exhorted you to walke as gods mynysters (that is faythfully and godly) in your ministrations, that you whiche faythfully beleue, maye (at the appearyng of our Lorde Iesus) receyue the reward, namely the croune of eternall lyfe.
column8: In conclusion: I told you, that now is that accepted time and day of salvation. wherein I exhorted you to walk as God's Ministers (that is faithfully and godly) in your ministrations, that you which faithfully believe, may (At the appearing of our Lord jesus) receive the reward, namely the crown of Eternal life.

column7: What now remayneth, but to desyre you in the name of our Lorde Iesus, that ye wyll (all scisme, discord and variance laid apart) growe to the vnitie of the spirite of Christe, that ye maye be lyke mynded in the truthe:
column8: What now remaineth, but to desire you in the name of our Lord jesus, that you will (all Schism, discord and variance laid apart) grow to the unity of the Spirit of Christ, that you may be like minded in the truth:

column7: Knowyng that nothyng is more acceptable in the sight of almighty god in Iesu Christ,
column8: Knowing that nothing is more acceptable in the sighed of almighty god in Jesu christ,

column7: then the vnitie of bretherne.
column8: then the unity of brethren.

column7: Herevnto the whole scriptures doo leade vs:
column8: Hereunto the Whole Scriptures do lead us:

column7: this they doo teache vs:
column8: this they do teach us:

column7: and this they wyll vs to folowe:
column8: and this they will us to follow:

column7: and that bycause God is the God of peace, and not of discord.
column8: and that Because God is the God of peace, and not of discord.

column7: He delyteth to see vnitie, dwell among christian men (whiche by liuely fayth ar graffed as membres into his precious bodye, and are his membres in deede) and not diuision,
column8: He delighteth to see unity, dwell among christian men (which by lively faith Are graffed as members into his precious body, and Are his members in deed) and not division,

column7: Christe oure heade is the peace offrynge, the attonement maker, and the God of Reconciliation.
column8: Christ our head is the peace offering, the atonement maker, and the God of Reconciliation.

column7: The membres beyng knyt to the head,
column8: The members being knit to the head,

column7: What ought they to expresse?
column8: What ought they to express?

column7: A contrarietie to the head?
column8: A contrariety to the head?

column7: No, that were a wonderfull disorder.
column8: No, that were a wonderful disorder.

column7: They must therfore expresse the qualitie of the head, by whom they bee gouerned.
column8: They must Therefore express the quality of the head, by whom they be governed.

column7: He is peace, wee must be peasable:
column8: He is peace, we must be peasable:

column7: he made attonement, wer muste bee attone:
column8: he made atonement, wer must be atone:

column7: he is the Reconciliation, we must be reconciled.
column8: he is the Reconciliation, we must be reconciled.

column7: He beyng the head, is knyt to his membres. al true christias be his membres, by his free sure holy and mercyfull promyse of oure partes vndeserued.
column8: He being the head, is knit to his members. all true Christians be his members, by his free sure holy and merciful promise of our parts undeserved.

column7: The membres are knyt to hym with a lyuely fayth, mightily working by loue, through whose operation, as S.
column8: The members Are knit to him with a lively faith, mightily working by love, through whose operation, as S.

column7: Paule proueth, wee ar membres one of an other.
column8: Paul Proves, we Are members one of an other.

column7: The head agreeth <NOTE> with the body, to teach the membres to agree togyther.
column8: The head agreeth with the body, to teach the members to agree together.

column7: The head is not diuided fro the body, no more must the membres therof be diuided.
column8: The head is not divided from the body, no more must the members thereof be divided.

column7: Wherfore to draw vs to the conformitie of his membres, and to alien ar from vs the ennemy of vnitie, he gaue vs a notable lesson by saynet Paule, saiyng:
column8: Wherefore to draw us to the conformity of his members, and to alien Are from us the enemy of unity, he gave us a notable Lesson by Saint Paul, saying:

column7: Let there be but one Lorde, one faythe, one baptisme, one god and father of all, whyche is aboue all, through all, and in you all.
column8: Let there be but one Lord, one faith, one Baptism, one god and father of all, which is above all, through all, and in you all.

column7: This is the rule of right christianite, whervnto we all thorough fayth must apply ourselues, and wherby we must be framed, yf we purpose to haue an euen and straighte buyldyng in the Lorde to eternall lyfe.
column8: This is the Rule of right christianity, whereunto we all thorough faith must apply ourselves, and whereby we must be framed, if we purpose to have an even and straight building in the Lord to Eternal life.

column7: From the whiche rule who so wylfully swarueth, and returneth not agayn by repentance, he hurteth hym selfe incurably, and shal be cast out of the vyne, as a withered branche forsaken of the vine, so drye that the swete moysture of the wyne wyll not enter.
column8: From the which Rule who so wilfully swerveth, and returns not again by Repentance, he hurteth him self incurably, and shall be cast out of the vine, as a withered branch forsaken of the vine, so dry that the sweet moisture of the wine will not enter.

column7: God drynge vs therefore to vnitie so muche commended in scripture, that we may as membres ruled by the vertu of the head, agree lyke membres, in the body of Christ, that we may all heare his ioyefulle voyce in the ende, sayinge:
column8: God drynge us Therefore to unity so much commended in scripture, that we may as members ruled by the virtue of the head, agree like members, in the body of christ, that we may all hear his ioyefulle voice in the end, saying:

column7: Venite benedicti patris mei in regnum praeparatum pro uobis ab initio. to the whyche God bryng vs for Christes sake.
column8: Venite Blessing patris mei in Kingdom praeparatum Pro uobis ab initio. to the which God bring us for Christ's sake.

column7: To whom with the father and the holy ghoste be all prayse, honoure, power and dominion, nowe and for euer.
column8: To whom with the father and the holy ghost be all praise, honour, power and dominion, now and for ever.

column7: Amen. God be praysed.
column8: Amen. God be praised.
